TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the scheduled fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws the attention of the House to the abolition of Medicare benefits for eye tests performed by Optometrists and Ophthalmologist on all members of the community except pensioners and Health Care Card Holders.
We request Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal Health Insurance System and that eye tests be covered.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PETITION.PARA: The United Nations declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on religious belief:
Prohibits all forms of religious discrimination thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief.
Could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols, or nativity scenes.
Has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups.
and that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
Gives wide rights to children in Articles 12-16, including the right to freedom of association.
Gives only the legally-weak term "respect" for the rights of parents in Article 5.
Could result in Government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:

PARA.TAB: Act to disallow these two international instruments from the HREOC Act.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This is simply the reintroduction of the bill I introduced into the Parliament on 26 March 1992 and which lapsed due to the dissolution of Parliament prior to the election.
The reasons for this amendment bill are still exactly the same as they were in March last year and have been strengthened by the evolution of the debate during the last twelve months.
This Bill seeks to repeal part of the Australian design rule No. 19.01 which deals with electrical connections on motor cycles.

The aim of the Australian design rule which has come into effect as of l March 1992 is to force all new motor cycles that are sold from 1 March onwards to have the headlight wired in such a way that when the engine is started the headlight will automatically come on.
We are dealing specifically with clause 19.6.106.9 of the Australian Design Rule No. 19.01 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Bill 1992 which we are moving to have repealed.

The Government seems to have neglected to consult with the users regarding this new regulation. In my experience no one single motor cyclist has been pleased to have this design rule forced upon them.

There has been much research into the pros and cons of having lights wired on. The key point is that when you look for the research evidence, both in Australia and overseas, you find that what is lacking is conclusive evidence that this measure actually adds to road safety. What this means is that the government hastily made this decision without properly researching the issue and has gone ahead without properly consulting those most directly affected.

The decision as to whether to turn on the motor cycle light during the day should be up to the rider. A responsibility, as with other vehicles, that is up to the driver. The majority of cyclists do turn their lights on for part of their day riding but surely experienced riders, who are quite adamant that having the light on can add to the risk, should be allowed to make their own decisions regarding safety.

Apart from the freedom of choice aspect there is the question of legal liability. It is not clear whether or not this bill will add to the liability of the motorcyclist who could be involved in an accident with a motor car. The difficulty lies in proving whether or not the light was actually on. The globe may have been smashed in the accident, it may have blown two minutes before the impact, or the day before. Along with the legal liability question there are the ramifications for insurance.

This new design rule could also add a false sense of security. People could believe that by having the light wired on it will somehow make them safer. This, in many cases, could be the exact opposite. Questions arise concerning the ability of some motorists to judge the speed and distance apart of an oncoming vehicle with its headlight on, thus adding to the danger, not to the safety on the roads.
But when this design rule is at its most ridiculous is with agbikes having to have their light wired on.

While I support most vehemently every effort to increase road safety, I believe that this issue of motor cyclists being forced to have their light on is a misguided move by the Minister, further highlighting that this Government is out of touch with the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. In its original form, this bill makes minor amendments to the principal act. A number of minor changes to the debt recovery provisions will be made, including clarifying family payment, overpayments and debts incurred over public holiday periods as a result of advanced payments. This bill will enable the department to recover certain debts relating to the child support scheme by way of direct deductions from benefits, pensions or allowances. Minor amendments will be made to the child disability allowance and these will limit backdating to 12 months, allow sharing of child disability allowance payments and clarify the 42-day temporary absence provisions.

PARA.TAB: In the House of Representatives, the shadow minister, Mr Ruddock, recognised that the backdating of the child disability allowance may be an area where some discretion may be warranted and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) undertook to look into this matter. I have noted their comments and I believe that honourable senators here should also note those comments.

This bill also allows partners of people in gaol to be paid at the single rate. I understand that further minor amendments relating to the commencement of this initiative will be put forward and these will not be opposed by the opposition. The threshold for sole parent pensioner employment entry payments will be amended to exclude add-ons for dependent children. This is a beneficial provision that is also supported by the opposition.

The bill excludes payments from the New South Wales Medically Acquired HIV Trust from the income test. The coalition supports this provision, and I have nothing but the deepest possible sympathy for the beneficiaries of this provision. I must admit that I do have some reservations about the precedent that this sets. However, we will not be opposing it. Without wasting the time of the Senate, all the remaining amendments including those in relation to investment income, the waiting periods for newly arrived residents, a more streamlined review process and overcoming possible dual payments will also be supported by the opposition.

The government is seeking to use amendments to this bill to facilitate its partial backdown last week on the pensioner and veterans' shares issue. Honourable senators are aware of last week's caucus meeting—I am almost tempted to use a freudian slip and call it the `raucous' meeting—at which up to a reported 70 members and senators confronted the Labor leadership demanding changes to its budget of betrayal. They are also changes, let me say, to last year's budget because these measures were in last year's budget. Not only are they amending this year's budget; they are going back patching up the mess that they made in last year's budget—a mess that has left pensioners up in the air for at least 12 months. Many of them were very concerned and very worried about what was going to be the financial impact of treating unrealised capital gains on shares as income for the purpose of assessing the pension. In his media release after this telling meeting—as I said the other day, I would have loved to have been a fly on the wall at that meeting—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that it had been decided to review implementation issues associated with the 1992-93 budget decision to assess capital gains and losses on shares for pensioners.

This in itself was a humiliating and embarrassing backdown for the Prime Minister, given that just over three months earlier he said in the House of Representatives, when he was debating some amendments we put through down there to try to have this unfair legislation repealed, that the opposition was `into revenge, obfuscation and just being villains'. He went on to call us `irresponsible, stupid people' because we dared seek to pass a private bill to repeal this harsh and inequitable measure. That is what the Prime Minister called us, villains; he said that we were obfuscating and that we were irresponsible, stupid people because we wanted that reviewed.

I put it again on the public record that, when the legislation went through, the opposition supported that clause of the legislation because we were in a bind. It was tagged to other legislation which gave benefits to pensioners. Those benefits were under threat and so we said that we would review it in government. We did not have that opportunity, unfortunately, and I am sure there are a lot of Australians now who regret the fact that we are not in government and so do not have that opportunity. The next best thing we could do was to do everything in our power, with the assistance of the Democrats, to bring this issue to a head and to have the government back down. It has backed down, but only partially.

After the Prime Minister made these statements, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was forced to make a monumental and embarrassing backdown of his own. He announced that all shares acquired before budget night, 18 August 1992, would be exempted from the shares provisions. The minister had stated repeatedly that the government did not intend to back down on this initiative. Over and over again he said, `We will not back down'. That was the message pensioners were getting.

While a Senate inquiry received nearly 200 submissions and over 2,000 letters virtually unanimously condemning the government's plan, the minister gave pensioners little or no hope that the government would relent. Despite the fact that in excess of 200 pensioners attended each of the committee's three public hearings, the minister stood firm in supporting his department's proposal. The message that pensioners were getting was that the government would not back down. In fact, as the community discontent became more pronounced, the minister and his parliamentary secretary moved to quell this disquiet by selling their shares plan through the media.

At no stage prior to last week's caucus meeting was any indication given by the minister that the government would back down. It is very important to understand this, because many pensioners, being concerned but believing that the government would not relent, had already sold all or part of their share portfolios prior to last week's backdown.
One such person was a woman called Nan Prior, from Glen Waverley. She sold her shares the week before the backdown. She told the Herald-Sun after the backdown:

SPEECH.PARA: I sold my shares solely on the basis of the Government's commitment to the plan and now they've turned around and changed their mind.

Over the weekend I was chatting to someone who told me that she had sold her shares. She said that she had had a small shareholding as a result of a very small superannuation package and that she had sold her shares. This is a friend of mine that I knew as a youth leader in my childhood. She was very concerned about it and said that one of her other friends had done the same.

PARA.TAB: Nan Prior, from Glen Waverley, as quoted in the Herald-Sun, believed that the proposal was `set in concrete'. She made her plans on that basis. Her reaction was obvious. She told the Herald-Sun:

SPEECH.PARA: I feel betrayed. The indecision from the Government is disgusting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer himself said that they were set in concrete.

—As Senator Short rightly says, the Treasurer himself said they were set in concrete. That is the message that the pensioners were getting. Nan Prior is not alone. I am informed that a number of angry pensioners inundated a Melbourne talkback radio station last week and a similar station in Sydney earlier this week.

PARA.TAB: Why would these people not be angry? They have every right to be angry. Unwittingly, they have become the victims of this ill-conceived proposal. They sold all or part of their share portfolios in order to avoid this unfair income test. Now, in the light of the government's backdown, they find that there was absolutely no need to sell these shares. If they rebuy the shares that they have sold, they will be caught up in the same unfair income test that they have been attempting to avoid, quite legally. So if the people who sold their shares because they thought the proposal was set in concrete—so that the unrealised capital gains would not be treated as income—were to buy back in, they would get caught up in this system. No-one can blame any pensioner for selling shares. The government provided no indication that it was willing to relent in the face of concerted community opposition.

In addition to this, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Con Sciacca, went around the country last month informing media outlets that selling shares was a way around the government's planned income test. On the Money show on 11 August, Patrick Lindsay questioned Mr Sciacca on two occasions about the lack of purchasing power of a notional profit. He was asking, `Here's a paper profit: what's the purchasing power of that?'. On each occasion Mr Sciacca's response was, `Not if you sell it'. So he was saying that, if you sell it, it has got purchasing power. On Derryn Hinch's show on the same day, Mr Sciacca stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We then expect that before they access the social security system that they go to the source of their investments, that they resource everything that they can of their resources before they come to us.

Pensioner after pensioner told me that they mainly use the dividends from their small holdings of a few thousand dollars to pay their private health insurance—to keep out of the long hospital queues that this government has created. So they were using that dividend and hoping that the capital gain on their shares would mean that that dividend would keep pace with the ever increasing costs of private health insurance, over time.

PARA.TAB: With health the way it is these days, many people of 65 or 70 are looking at 15 or 20 years more of life, and they need to have some capital gain on that investment to make sure that they can keep pace. But Mr Sciacca says, `Use up all of your resources before you come to us'. Many of them were using those resources to avoid being on the public purse, in terms of health. In the Canberra Times the following day, Mr Sciacca was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: If people save for their retirement. . . then they are expected to spend what they save. . . not to preserve the capital base that they have.

A great majority of these people have a very small capital base and, as I said, that dividend is basically being used to make sure that they stay as independent as possible, especially in terms of their health care. The Canberra Times article went on:

We believe that because stocks are easily and readily accessible in terms of realising it into cash, then a pensioner or retired person must first access the resources available to him or her before they come to the social security system.

In a radio interview with Matthew Abraham on 2CN the day before, Mr Sciacca made similar claims, both in the actual interview and also when answering a question put to him by a caller. In fact, Mr Sciacca has been making statements of this ilk for over four months now.

PARA.TAB: On 27 April of this year, he had an interview with Anna Reynolds on 4QR, in his home town of Brisbane, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If it looks like they might have to sell their shares and put it into other income bearing deposits, well that's fine because the end result as I say is the social security system is based on the question of need and if people can properly use their moneys or their investments to be able to get some income and that takes some of the strain off the social security system then everybody benefits.

The combination of the government stonewalling on this issue and the repeated statements by Mr Sciacca, in relation to pensioners accessing their own financial resources before using the social security system, is extremely relevant to this debate. This was the official advice that the government was giving to pensioners and to veterans. It was advice upon which pensioners and veterans quite rightly based their investment decisions. It now turns out that the advice provided by both the Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, and his parliamentary secretary, Mr Sciacca, was, in hindsight, hopelessly inaccurate.

PARA.TAB: Pensioners have sold their shares which, it turns out, would not have been subject to the revamped government proposal. They have followed the advice of Mr Sciacca and realised their share resources, and they find that they will be disadvantaged because of it. It is unconscionable for the government to leave pensioners and veterans in such a position. This is a problem of the government's own doing. There is only one way that it can ameliorate this problem totally. That avenue is by forgetting this ridiculous proposal altogether. The coalition will move an amendment at the committee stage seeking to replace the government's latest proposal with the total repeal of the shares provisions.

The shares provisions are in a complete shambles. Originally, the government claimed that these measures would result in net savings of $62 million in 1993-94, rising to $80 million in each of the two subsequent years. Now the government's own estimates are that gross savings will be only $5 million in 1993-94, $11.4 million in 1994-95 and $16.4 million in 1995-96. Given that the government has admitted that it will cost some $2.4 million to implement its revamped shares plan in 1993-94, the net savings from this controversial measure in this financial year will be no more than $2.6 million. Why the pensioners and veterans have had to face over a year of worry and concern for the sake of a mere $2.6 million this year is a matter for which the government will have to answer at the next election.

It must also be realised that the government's estimates are best estimates. Like the original estimates upon which they are based, these estimates take no account of any change in pensioners' and veterans' investment behaviour that may result from this measure. So all the savings are based on the fact that pensioners will not sell their shares. We know that they are selling their shares. We know that, when their shares go up and that is deemed to be income, those that are now caught up in this system, newly entering pensioners, et cetera, will sell their shares. It is quite feasible that the actual savings from this measure will be considerably lower than the government now claims.

It is not unreasonable that the government's latest position will actually have an adverse net impact on outlays, at least in the initial year. The government's own members of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs concluded in their report that the government's original costings were invalid. Importantly, they concluded that the government's plan was not fair, that it was not equitable and that it would create more inequity than it would save. Now, with the new measures, there is another inequity. There will be three classes of pensioners: the class of pensioners who bought shares prior to the budget in 1992; the class of pensioners who were in that situation, who then sold their shares, and who now, if they want to buy back into them, will be caught up; and the new class of pensioners who will be retiring with small amounts of superannuation and who will not be able to invest.

We will have two major classes and a subclass in between—that group of people who believed that this was set in concrete. How foolish they were! I do not mean that they were foolish but they were led to believe this by the government, and they believed the government. I suppose people of that era used to believe in governments. They spent most of their adult lives under Liberal governments and they had been fooled into believing that under this Labor government nothing would change, that the government would keep this legislation in place, and so they sold their shares.

The latest backdown does not remove the fundamental inequity of the original shares proposal. In fact, it creates more inequity. It simply sets an arbitrary commencement date, after which the inequitable proposal will apply. It does not remove any of the concerns about the way the formula will apply. It does not rectify any of the comparative disadvantages of shares as against other forms of investment such as real estate and collectables. It does not address the widespread concerns about the adverse impact on national savings.

Under pressure from caucus, from its own members of the Senate committee, from thousands of pensioners and veterans, and from the investment industry, this aloof, out-of-touch government has belatedly recognised the absolute futility of this flawed proposal. It must now have the political courage to dispose of the harsh and inequitable measure altogether.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin simply by noting that the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill has in it a number of positive measures. In particular, I mention the additional support for people who have partners in gaol or in psychiatric confinement and who will now be entitled to the full single pension; the payment for those who have acquired HIV medically in New South Wales; and also some changes to the sole parent pension threshold amount. I will be spending the bulk of my time now looking at a very late amendment to this bill, the final agreement to change what was to come into effect in only about 2 1/2 weeks time—that is, the way the increase in capital gains in shares was going to be treated for social security purposes.

PARA.TAB: I will run through the history of this measure, which begins with the budget last year, in 1992. On seeing this and hearing from a couple of pensioner organisations which also noticed the measure, we referred the matter off to a committee. The first committee to look at it was the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Unfortunately, in that committee the Liberal Party and the Labor Party could not be convinced. The Democrats brought down a minority report pointing out many of the points that were again pointed out, in the second inquiry, by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.
This measure came before the Senate. It could easily have been defeated at that stage. It could simply have been taken out as an amendment—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish, and you know it.

—I tell Senator Patterson that it is not rubbish, as anybody who bothers to go back and have a look at how it was presented can see. But those were the days when the Liberal Party was very reluctant to be in opposition. Those were the days when the Liberal Party believed that whatever was in the budget had to be supported. The budget could not be touched; it was all set in concrete or blocked in ice or whatever. In previous years when I have been in this chamber and in the time of former Senator Haines in this chamber—I was recently discussing this with her—the Liberal Party has rarely, if ever, opposed anything in the budget. One thing she could remember was the gold tax but other than that it was a very rare occurrence, partly, I suspect, because the Liberal Party is used to watching this Labor government pass what is really Liberal Party policy and is only too happy to be associated with it and indeed support it.

PARA.TAB: The legislation passed through very quietly, even without many of those in the press gallery noticing what happened. The only people who noticed were a couple of financial journalists who take an interest in this area. Off it went. As we headed towards the election we heard very little. Indeed, when the Democrats raised this it was seen as a non-issue and basically it disappeared in the period over Christmas.

However, I must commend my colleague Senator Bell, who in Tasmania began to get behind him more and more pensioners on that island who were actually aware of what was going on and were very concerned. The Democrats' campaign began slowly after Christmas, asking people initially to write to the Liberal Party. Senator Bell himself wrote to honourable senators in the Liberal Party asking them what they were going to do about this. The election came and went and, as we all know, the Liberal Party was not successful. So any suggestions that they had made—I acknowledge that Senator Patterson in this chamber said that it was something that they would review—came and went with the election result. We had this measure ticking away, with pensioners gradually becoming more and more concerned. As pensioners became concerned we saw the Liberal Party also, to its credit, changing its mind and deciding that it would also be opposing this measure in this place.

After writing successfully to Liberal Party senators, pensioners began to turn their attention to the Labor Party. We also began, through a wide range of pensioner organisations, to circulate petitions. I would argue now that this victory is not just a victory for the hard work of the Democrats and a belated victory also for the Liberal Party, which has recognised the error of its ways, but is a victory for ordinary Australians out there, for community action.

I believe the government was embarrassed by what it had done, particularly by the retrospective element of it. We had people—younger pensioners in their 60s and 70s but also older pensioners into their 80s, people who no longer took any great interest in their financial affairs and just presumed that everything was going along nicely—who suddenly had to start seeking advice. They sought advice from financial advisers and went down to the local DSS office—in my state, getting some quite unfortunate advice from FIS officers who as late as last week were actually telling them to sell their shares.

Through all this advice and through all these hassles, many pensioners have been put in a very difficult position. As has already been outlined, some have decided to sell. The government has taken us right to the wire; if we do not pass this today we get an even more draconian measure. Unfortunately, some of those pensioners are now regretting the actions that they have taken but it is too late. This measure does nothing for those pensioners who have bought since last year and it does nothing for those who are in managed investments. We heard before the Senate committee that many financial advisers actually recommend those packages to pensioners rather than individual parcels of shares on the stock exchange.

This measure also does nothing for pensioners when we look at the relationship between the income and assets tests as a whole. We also need to look at how, with the new push for people to have their own superannuation, superannuation relates to the pension system and what incentives, if any, are left for people to provide for themselves in retirement. What the Democrats are now calling for is a full and independent review of our retirement income system that includes not just pensioners but also part-pensioners and self-funded retirees. We need to look at how this fits together, where the incentives are and where the discrimination is. We need to look at the relationship between the income test and the assets test and look at what sorts of messages we are sending to people about how they plan for their retirement.

We need to make sure that, not only is the retirement system geared to support people fairly, but that we give them some peace of mind in retirement. We should not put them in a situation where, year by year, they have to run off to financial planners and keep checking with the Department of Social Security. One pensioner said to me that it is almost as if it deliberately makes these changes when she is on her annual fortnight's holiday because she now feels almost obliged to have a regular update as to what has changed since she last kept an eye on things. One thing the government certainly has done is to activate pensioners to the point where they are actively following the financial pages of some of our more notable publications, trying to keep abreast of changes to the pension and retirement income system.

I will just close by saying that, had this not been passed by the Liberal Party in the first place, we would not be in this position today. We are at the wire. If we do not pass this measure today it will go back to the House of Representatives and sit around. The government has made that very plain. It only has to let it sit for a day and bring it back on at the end of September and by then it will be too late because the original measure will be in place and quite a large number of pensioners will have lost part of their pension.

I stress here we are not talking about the millionaire pensioners that the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) seems to know about; we are talking about the 83 per cent of pensioners who hold $20,000 or less in shares. We are not talking about those pensioners who are at the upper end of the assets limit. Indeed, in this budget the government even further relaxed the assets test. For farm families I can understand that, but why on the one hand relax the assets test and on the other hand actually hit pensioners who have relatively small assets as they continue to accrue some assets and hedge against inflation?

What I believe the government has done is to send quite the wrong message about investment in Australian companies. It is actually discouraging people from maintaining an investment in Australia's future. By the way it has organised the assets test it is actually encouraging people to go off and invest in non-productive areas, be it antique clocks or jewellery, paintings on the walls or a holiday home, for example. It is doing this rather than encouraging pensioners to put their limited assets in an area that will actually help them minimise the pension because the more dividends they get—and they get far better dividends than they get out of a bank account—the less pension they need. I stress again, the government is sending quite the wrong message and the Democrats will be pursuing this issue, albeit through a variety of other means.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank the opposition and the Australian Democrats for indicating their support for the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. In respect of the amendments that are to be moved, one would have expected some disagreement, and that is occurring. I would say to Senator Lees that I do not think I know any millionaire pensioners. I have not met them yet, but they may be around and have thus far escaped my attention. The outer limits of our income and assets tests have been pushed a long way out in the last few years. So those who receive part pensions can now be on quite sizeable incomes by the standards of a lot of other families who do not necessarily have that level of government aid and support.

PARA.TAB: It has been important to see, when examining where those income and assets test levels have gone, that their integrity is protected at every point. So it is not a matter of the government seeking either to be punitive or to push investment in a particular direction; it is simply a matter of making sure that the pension is paid to those who actually need it. That is what income and assets tests have been about—making sure that the income support is paid to those who require it. We can do that only by fairly and equitably looking at income and assets tests across the board. We have to make sure that there are not areas where people can seek an advantage that is simply not available to others. We do not want everyone jumping in to find a way around the tests.

What we have achieved through this amended measure is to make sure that the treatment of shares is going to be the same across the board. I would have thought that was really the kind of policy objective that any sensible government ought to pursue. I note that Senator Patterson will be proposing the complete scrapping of the measure. That is disappointing because, for all the reasons I have just given, we are pursuing a sensible policy objective. Furthermore, the kind of hysteria about the sales of shares that this measure was supposed to have engendered is really based on a false premise. There is no evidence whatsoever that there has been any wholesale sell-off of shares. In fact, the evidence is quite to the contrary.

Some have sold—there is no doubt about that—but the idea that great numbers have sold simply is not true. It never was true. I said it when this legislation was last debated here. The evidence has never been collected because it cannot be. There is simply no evidence that pensioners engaged in a wholesale selling of their shares. All this measure does is make sure that those pensioners who have got cash to invest in shares or anything else are able to make the choice of investment knowing that, no matter how they seek to invest that money, whether in shares or other investments, they are going to be treated in the same way. I think that is the kind of policy objective that we ought to be pursuing.

It is true to say that some people have sold over the course of the last 12 months, but because there has been no wholesale sell-off I think much of what the government has wanted to do here has been correct. What happened, though—Senator Lees correctly pointed it out—was that there was a big community reaction, which she and the Democrats did raise in here, which the members of my own party went to the caucus economics committee last Monday night and made perfectly clear to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in, as I understand it, stark terms. As a result of that jolt, as I described it yesterday, the government finally decided to take some action.

The action having been taken to exempt all shares bought prior to 18 August 1992 suggests to me that what we have done now is absolutely fair. There cannot be any suggestion of any retrospective element. It is really when one gets into retrospectivity that one begins to cause some heartache and some pain. Now that even the suggestion of it has been removed, I believe that what we have before us today is a fair measure and one that will make sure that pensioners around Australia are able to approach their investments, knowing that we are not encouraging rorts and ways around the system and knowing that, if they invest in shares or other forms of investment, their income will be treated in the same way.

I would like to respond to Senator Lees's remarks about our income and assets tests and how they might be reviewed. Not only the controversy over this issue but the kinds of inquiries we get and the kinds of judgments we make when listening to the department and its many offices throughout the country ensure that these matters are, if not kept under constant review, often looked at. I am assured that in the course of the next few months the minister and his department will be having a good look at the issues that have been raised here to see if any further changes are required.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add'', but the Senate notes the Government's own admission that Aboriginal well-being is not improving and therefore calls for an independent review of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to determine the measures necessary to ensure an improvement in its performance in order to significantly lift the living standards of the indigenous population of Australia''.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) is the second of a series of three similar amending bills that the parliament is considering this year. All these amendments flow from the government's consideration of the review of ATSIC that the commissioners themselves completed in February this year just before the election. It was an urgent matter to have in place those improvements to ATSIC in time for the elections to take place in December this year. ATSIC has had its first term and its first period of operation. We now have had this review by the ATSIC commissioners themselves as to the best ways to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander decisions for programs to help the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am conscious, from discussion with the chair of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, a resident of my own state of South Australia, of the sincere, careful concern that ATSIC commissioners have for these reforms to the structure of the council, which is what we dealt with in the first amendment in our sitting back in May this year and now in this bill before us with four or five matters especially dealing with the election process for regional councils to be implemented in the election of December and with regard to some of the functions and responsibilities of advisory committees, deputy chairs of councils, and the like.

The third band of amendments, also flowing from the general advice of the ATSIC commissioners, is to see later this year a third bill, which will strengthen the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit to include powers to evaluate and audit regional councils, Aboriginal hostels, the CDC, land councils and ATSIC funded organisations, and make major changes to the arrangements for the Torres Strait, including the establishment of a Torres Strait regional authority. It is understood that the regional council arrangements as they relate to the Torres Strait are being deferred in anticipation of a regional authority in that area of northern Queensland being in place by the third wave of amending legislation later this year.

I think that the most significant changes are those that we have yet to face. I understand the government's wish to have more time to ensure that the appropriate amending bill is properly constructed and that it is precisely determined after consultation at each stage, that consultation to include the opposition's spokesman and representatives of the other parties in the Senate. The determination of that third stage of legislation must include consultation with the present ATSIC commissioners and Aboriginal communities generally.

The opposition welcomes these three stages of amendments to ATSIC and to the regional councils. We support the legislation that is before us today. Later in my speech I will move an amendment to the second reading which, I hope, will gain support from honourable senators in the chamber. I look to Senator Kernot and I look to Senator Margetts. That amendment is currently being distributed. I will speak precisely to that amendment in the latter part of my remarks.

I wish to note that the principal reason why the opposition welcomes these three amending pieces of legislation to ATSIC is that they largely implement what we advocated in our policy paper of November last year. I refer to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs statement, ATSIC—the way forward: a policy for the next coalition government, published after our party room's decision by Dr Michael Wooldridge, the then shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, on 5 November 1992. I seek leave to incorporate the first substantial page of that document in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS
Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, under a Coalition Government, will be based upon—

PARA.TAB: a partnership between the Australian Government and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, to address Aboriginal disadvantage.
the government having clearly defined objectives for achievement in Aboriginal Affairs, namely,
1.improvement in Aboriginal health;
2.provision of housing and infrastructure;
3.Aboriginal education;
4.Aboriginal economic development (including private sector employment);
5.the opportunity for those Aborigines who choose to maintain their culture to do so.

an understanding that, if Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are to move from dependence on welfare and government, to a position of self reliance, it is essential that they be given the opportunity to develop a sound economic base.
the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in the decisions that affect their lives and determine their local priorities.
an absolute requirement for—
1.a focus on tangible benefits on the ground, as a result of programs, rather than the present focus on timely distribution of funds and adequate acquittal process;
2.the decision making to be open and transparent;
3.organisations receiving government money to provide services in an efficient and equitable manner; and

SPEECH.PARA: 4.accountability on all levels of service delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I refer in particular to the last paragraph, which says that in the reform of ATSIC there should be:

SPEECH.PARA: .an absolute requirement for—

PARA.TAB: 1.a focus on tangible benefits on the ground, as a result of programs, rather than the present focus on timely distribution of funds and adequate acquittal process;

SPEECH.PARA: There has been too much concentration on just setting up the machinery, setting up the bureaucracy, and there has been insufficient concentration on actual achievements and on actual outcomes monitored against specified objectives. The statement continues:

PARA.TAB: 2.the decision making to be open and transparent;

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the third wave of amendments to ATSIC later this year will go a long way, I trust, to achieve openness and transparency. It further states:

PARA.TAB: 3.organisations receiving government money to provide services in an efficient and equitable manner;
4.accountability on all levels of service delivery.

SPEECH.PARA: In this document we went on to argue that there should be a reduction in the number of commissioners from 60 to about 30. What we have seen already in the May legislation is a reduction to 36, and we welcomed that. It largely implements opposition policy.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the regional councils we wanted to ensure that there was an ability for full-time executive action by the chairman of the regional councils; and that is being implemented. We want to see a decentralising of program management to the regions, and that is being provided for in this pattern of legislation. So it is not surprising that we are supporting the legislation which, happily, the government has written to accommodate us, and to accommodate, of course, the advice of the ATSIC council and its review.

I want to ask a precise question of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins. Is it envisaged that the third wave of ATSIC legislation will be introduced before 1 October? Otherwise, is it the government's intention that it will be introduced in order to lie on the table? That is, we will receive it perhaps late in November and be able to study it and then have the debate upon it early in the new year? As I understand it, the—

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted for the cut-off motion. How can you propose that?

—I understand that. What I am saying, Minister, is that the urgent matters that must be in place are in the bill we are now debating. But for the foreshadowed, substantial, further amendments I am asking if they will be introduced into parliament probably in late November so that they can then be debated and determined when we sit in March next year.
—It is necessary by December.

—I am wanting to hear the advice of the minister. With regard to any timing, we all need to know in the Senate chamber what the timing of the government is with regard to that matter. A second question I put to the minister relates to the implementation of wards. We have not the full detail of the precise number of wards and their definition in each region. By this legislation a maximum of five is to be required and I want to know what progress has been made in the definition of wards and their boundaries.

PARA.TAB: My third question refers to clause 23 of the present bill. It relates to the understandable tightening of the disclosure by regional councillors of any financial interest they may have in a matter that is being discussed. There is a requirement that they seek the agreement of the minister, in writing, for their participation in any matter in which they have a direct personal financial interest. This is going to cause a problem with regard to the operation of a quorum in regional meetings. If someone who has a direct financial interest is required to not attend a meeting there may be, for want of that attendance, an inadequate number attending—in fact, not a quorum—and an inability for a regional council to transact its business.

I have been in the bush as much as anybody has, and I think it would be difficult to get prior warning of all matters before a regional council in which an individual councillor may have a financial interest. It would not be practical to fax a quick letter to the minister or to get the minister's reply in time for a meeting. I envisage that there may well be a practical difficulty in the operation of this new arrangement for the disclosure of financial interests.

I refer to, and commend, a practice occurring for many years in this parliament. Whenever an individual participating in a decision has a direct personal financial interest he declares that interest openly and clearly. Not only does the individual declare that interest to his colleagues on the decision making body but he also declares it publicly. Having clearly identified his personal financial interest, it is then in the hands of the other members at the meeting to determine whether that individual ought to participate in the meeting or ought to leave the meeting.

I am concerned that there will be practical problems in the outworking of this new provision. I ask for the minister's reassurance that there will be some flexibility in making sure that regional councils do in fact work. The amendment that has been circulated in my name adds to the motion that the bill be read a second time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ", but the Senate notes the Government's own admission that Aboriginal wellbeing is not improving and therefore calls for an independent review of ATSIC to determine the measures necessary to ensure an improvement in its performance in order to significantly lift the living standards of the indigenous population of Australia".

We believe that there is such a serious failure of outcome in Aboriginal communities for the whole purpose of ATSIC—and for the whole purpose of public funding of Aboriginal programs—that there needs to be a review to ensure that we put in place a more confident set of programs that will improve the outcome for Aboriginal individuals and communities.

PARA.TAB: I now refer to the speech on this matter given by my colleague Michael MacKellar last Wednesday, on behalf of the opposition, in the House of Representatives. He referred to three particular issues: the high proportion of maternal deaths in childbirth amongst Aboriginal women; the extraordinary incidence of diabetes amongst Aboriginal people, and the very high proportion of early deaths from those who suffer diabetes in Aboriginal communities; and the work of the Menzies School of Health Research in Darwin with regard to the lack of child health care in Aboriginal communities. Whether we take these three examples or a whole range of other examples in health, housing and education—all of the indicators for the wellbeing of individuals, families and communities—we are distressed that the Aboriginal people of Australia are still, by a long way, worse off. The statistics still show a bleak picture for the Aboriginal people.

I note that it is now 26 years since the referendum that many of us participated in to change the constitution of Australia to allow the federal government to make laws for the Aboriginal people—laws that would develop programs. In those 26 years we have seen a certain range of improvements. Senator Kernot, who is serving on the commission for reconciliation, will have a good knowledge of some of those positive outcomes but there are too many static, negative outcomes and areas where we have not seen progress.

I believe that the $1,000 million that is provided each year to Aboriginal programs ought to be able to be reviewed by ATSIC. Through ATSIC's reports and through this parliament to the Australian public there should be some measurable improvements in these broad areas that affect the wellbeing of Aboriginal people in Australia. Those of us in the opposition are not satisfied that we have in place an evaluation process, a program of setting objectives and measuring outcomes against those objectives, to show how $1,000 million a year spent upon such programs is actually achieving the outcomes that we all wish.

Let me refer to my visit in June to the Pitjantjatjara communities in South Australia. Over my 15 years in the Senate I have been to these communities about 12 times, beginning in 1978. I am very sad to say that, in the broad, the situation of these remote Aboriginal communities has become steadily worse. I say it with enormous sadness. There is more and more money; there are more and more programs, more and more housing initiatives, CDEP initiatives, education initiatives—but the outcomes are worse.

Let me refer to Indulkana. Indulkana, at the moment, is a very sad example of what 15 years—or 26 years if we go right back to the referendum—of a large number of federal programs have provided for this community in my state of South Australia. Very few children go into secondary education in the whole of the community. The actual achievement level in the primary school is more at a ceiling of about level 5. The 10 years of bilingual education in English and Pitjantjatjara have now been abandoned.

If I look at the health outcomes: there are more health problems now through communicable diseases, respiratory diseases, eye diseases and so it goes on. Television has had an impact upon the community. Drink is still a community problem. We need a review and we need it to be constructive.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, Senator Teague, has said, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 is the second of three bills to be introduced this session which will pave the way for greater autonomy and a stronger voice for Aboriginal people through participatory administration of ATSIC. This bill is the next step in preparing the way for the elections for the board of ATSIC. These elections are scheduled to take place in December.

PARA.TAB: In the last session, we passed legislation to establish a 19-member full-time board with 30 regional councils throughout Australia. The bill we are considering today goes on to establish a ward system to feed into the regional councils. It establishes interim—and that is the important word—ward boundaries for the purposes of the forthcoming election. These boundaries, I believe, are to be reviewed before the full elections take place in 1996. An independent review panel is to be established in the third bill. It will consider submissions and then determine ward, region and zone boundaries. This panel is to operate in much the same way as the redistribution committees established by the Australian Electoral Act.

ATSIC has argued that there are a number of salient reasons why a ward system is appropriate at this point in time. The Democrats accept ATSIC's rationale, which is essentially that, with a reduced number of regions, some relatively small centres of population are expressing concern that it will be more difficult for them to be represented in the enlarged regions, particularly as there will be significantly fewer representatives; that within enlarged regions there is concern that larger population centres and larger interest groups will come to exercise a dominant influence on a council; and that a ward system will allow regional councillors to identify more closely with the people of their ward and to be more sensitive to their interests.

This bill also outlines procedures whereby budgetary and other administrative functions will be devolved to regional councils. It seeks to ensure economic and administrative accountability at all levels. I believe that the provisions of this bill will go a long way towards addressing Senator Panizza's concerns, as outlined in his notice of motion calling for a review of ATSIC. Under this bill there is to be a tightening of provisions of direct and indirect pecuniary interest. The bill establishes the terms and conditions for office holders, including provisions for dismissal for misbehaviour. There are also provisions to limit spending on administrative costs to under 15 per cent of the total budget of the councils. If this laudable effort is actually achieved, perhaps it will be a model for other bodies. We have been really hard in what we have expected of ATSIC from the very beginning and in what we have written into the bill when we set up ATSIC.

Our primary concern in examining this legislation has been the future of ATSIC. If Aboriginal people are ever to claim their rightful autonomy, ATSIC, which has been proposed and set up by this government, must be strong and not vulnerable to politically motivated, malevolent attacks from either the white or the indigenous communities. It seems to me that there is an orchestrated anti-ATSIC campaign going on at the moment, not in here but outside this chamber. I think that the comments by some indigenous people in Australia aimed at ATSIC, while perhaps expressing a sense of frustration, are particularly unhelpful at a time when ATSIC is reviewing the first three years of its operations.

There is bound to be a problem when one imposes a monolithic structure which says that ATSIC is the voice of all Aboriginal people. It never can be. We do not expect that in our society. Nevertheless, it is a representative body and it deserves our support until it can be significantly demonstrated that it deserves to lose that support. I think it is important that the elections scheduled for December happen as smoothly as possible and that this new system of administration be allowed some time to be established.

I listened to what Senator Teague had to say in support of his second reading amendment. I would argue, as I said to Senator Panizza, that this bill puts in place procedures for review. Let us give that a chance first. We cannot go on forever blaming ATSIC, a body which is just three and a bit years old, for everything that is demonstrably wrong with the living standards of indigenous Australians. Why do we not compare it, for example, with a white-fellow's body like the CAA? Can we say that that has been a roaring success in recent times in terms of following due process or delivering the best outcomes for the people who depend on it? I do not think we can. So let us not be unduly critical of something that is only three and a bit years old. Why expect ATSIC in three and a bit years to solve the problems of the legacy of a couple of hundred years? We are talking about injustices of 200 years and we are talking about a structure that has had a few years in which to address those injustices, and I think we are being unfair.

Senator Teague referred to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and I would like also to refer to it. We have got ATSIC, we have got the land councils, we have got the various legal services, we have got the Aboriginal community organisations and we have got the council for reconciliation. The good work that is being done there, I believe, must not be undermined by these orchestrated attacks on ATSIC.

The council has a rural subcommittee. That subcommittee has worked hard, through DEET, to bring indigenous and white pastoralists together in joint management situations. There has been a sharing of knowledge. It has been a very productive outcome for the pastoral industry. There is the mining subcommittee, which produced that marvellous report and which for the first time is bringing chief executive officers of the main mining companies in Australia face to face in the boardrooms with traditional Aboriginal landowners.

It is one thing to put in place the structures, as we are doing; that is important but what must reinforce and complement those structures is the dialogue. This dialogue is happening. There are proposals to set up a joint council of miners and Aboriginal people for future land management. There is incredibly new and important ground being broken here. I do not think it helps to start concentrating all the time on ATSIC and ATSIC's alleged failure to deliver, within a short period of time, solutions to a legacy of 200 years. We must stop this fixation. It is definitely not helpful. Progress is being made in this area. ATSIC is an important part of that progress. The Democrats support this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2). The major amendment provisions in this bill are to entitle members of regional council advisory committees to receive remuneration and allowances for their services. I will take them one by one so I do not have to go back over them.

PARA.TAB: The previous position was untenable because of the sort of remuneration that commissioners used to get. It certainly was not enough to make it a full-time job or even for an attempt to get completely to the bottom of things. The proposed situation will improve the commissioners' lot no end and proper remuneration will bring forward a lot of better applicants for those positions. I welcome that part of the bill.

The bill provides also for, in regional council elections, a maximum of five wards per region. I have in the past advocated the ward system for ATSIC regional councils. The reason I have done so is that during my long term in local government I saw the effectiveness of a ward system. Any local government councils in Western Australia that have gone backwards over the last few years have been the ones that had done away with their wards. In a no ward system in local government, no-one is responsible for anything. That is how it worked.

There were a few heretics in my local government council that wanted to do away with wards. First of all, it becomes loaded up with councillors from one particular area and everyone wants to be on board for the good things, the most popular things that happen to be going on, and less and less attention is paid to the hard decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is terrible, isn't it?

—Yes. I certainly welcome this move. The only way to go is to divide it up into wards, as Senator Kernot has said, to give representation to small communities, especially those in isolated areas. Most of these communities are in isolated and remote areas anyhow, but some are more remote than others. I commend the government for putting this provision into the bill. It is something that I have said should have been happening for a long time.

PARA.TAB: The next provision is the one relating to the declaration of pecuniary interests by regional councillors and members. I would go one step further than that and include anyone employed by a regional council. I have a motion before the Senate for an inquiry into the accountability of ATSIC. Senator Kernot is continually saying that there is a run on ATSIC around Australia, and she has referred to my motion at times, but the point is that my motion is about accountability. I reckon that, if there is to be accountability, people should declare their pecuniary interests. Honourable senators have to disclose their pecuniary interests, and I welcome that.

Senator Kernot is trying to interject. I remind her that I said that I was happy to have honourable senators' pecuniary interests disclosed, providing that they are meaningful and providing that they are signed. There is one honourable senator on the other side of the house who did not sign his. When I reminded him of it the other day, he still had not signed it.

Let us get back to the bill. I believe it is right that regional councillors and members should have to declare their pecuniary interests. I believe that anyone who is employed by those councils should also. I have seen time and again what happens with people employed by those councils. I am not talking about Aboriginals; I am talking about white people who are employed by them. Contracts go out to their friends or whoever, without even a tendering process or any of those sorts of formalities that are supposed to happen. So I believe that the provision should be extended to them.

There is another measure, which is to provide for the suspension from office of regional councillors and deputy chairpersons of regional councils. I do not know whether, in this democratic society, I really welcome that move. As Senator Kernot said, ATSIC is only two or three years old and it cannot, in two or three years, make up for what has happened in the last 200 years. I do not believe that in the last 200 years successive governments have neglected the Aboriginals totally. ATSIC took over from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I believe that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, whether under our government or Senator Collins's government, did do something for the welfare of Aboriginal people.

I believe that we could have the suspension provision for the next four or five years, but one day it has to get completely into the democratic system. In local government, a mayor or a shire president can be removed under certain circumstances. It is pretty hard to remove them. However, I believe that this provision should remain for only a short period. Let us get away from the concept that the opposition and others around Australia are solely out to undo ATSIC. The calls that have come to my office from around Australia regarding my proposed inquiry have been from Aboriginal people themselves. I want to see accountability.

Senator Kernot mentioned the bills that are to come later to strengthen the Office of Evaluation and Audit and to include powers to evaluate and audit regional councils, Aboriginal hostels, CDC, land councils and ATSIC funded organisations. First and foremost under the ATSIC funded organisations should be the Aboriginal Legal Service. I am not going to run right into what I said the other day, because that is on record. Especially in Western Australia, it is something that needs to be well looked at. That legislation will come forward. Senator Kernot told the Senate that it will.

The Auditor-General has said twice in the last few months that ATSIC should be inquired into because he has given qualified audit reports on it. But in relation to accountability, Senator Kernot, when this bill does come in it will not bring people to account for what has been done in the past. I know that we will have stronger provisions and I hope they will be carried out when they come in, but it will not catch up with the people that have ripped off the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in the last few years. We are talking about a budget of about $1.3 billion which, to put it in context, is two-thirds of the gold mined in Australia every year. We have Senator Kernot down there giggling her head off, obviously laughing at my suggestion there be more accountability. I am worried about what has happened in the past and what the royal commissions in Australia, especially in the Labor governed states of the last 10 years, have been doing about accountability regarding what has happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been complaining that we were not looking after processes.
—Senator Collins might even be interested to listen to this instead of talking to someone else down the other end of the chamber.
—I was talking to you.
—Okay. But the point is that that is what I am after: accountability and more accountability in the future. That is what I have said before.
—There is plenty of process.

—I ask Senator Burns whether he has apologised to Senator Troeth yet. When he does that I will recognise that he is in the chamber. Since I moved my motion the other day—and obviously Senator Collins thinks that is a joke—I have got three further public calls for accountability and inquiry into ATSIC, and I have them here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot can carry on as much as she likes. She knows as well as I do that the calls are out there; I have got three. Aboriginal funds miss the target. We have got a $1.3 billion budget and, as I said last week, I am not querying the budget, the amount of money that is going; I am querying where it is landing. An editorial, once again from the Sunday Times in Western Australia, calls for improvement of Aboriginal welfare and states that each week more evidence comes to light about the huge waste of public money earmarked to improve the welfare of Aborigines. As I say, I am not querying that. But it is not getting on the ground. Senator Margetts can laugh as much as she likes as well, but it is not getting there.

PARA.TAB: As I say, I have been in communities time and time again where the medical staff was overworked. In fact, I thought the doctor in one particular place was undernourished. He was probably working 25 1/2 hours a day. Yet there was not enough work being done on the ground because money was being wasted along the line. There is another one. Western Australia's Commissioner for Aboriginal Planning, Cedric Wyatt, said that funding often did not do the job for which it was meant. I urge Aboriginal people to do more checking and keep the bureaucrats honest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good suggestion. It will probably do better than a Senate committee.

—That is right. Here I am, bringing these things to Senator Collins's attention and I am having nothing but derision. I have, from a very distinguished member of the upper house in Western Australia, Ross Lightfoot, a demand for a royal commission. A royal commission is something that I do not want because I believe the resources will then just be wasted on that—on the royal commissioners, QCs and all that sort of thing. I am not a solicitor basher. I cannot afford to bash them any more; I acquired a daughter-in-law a few months ago who is a solicitor, so I had to stop. But here we are—there is MLC Ross Lightfoot—
—A conflict of interest.
—He has declared his interest.

—Yes, I have declared my interest. We have calls coming in all the time calling for accountability. On this side of the chamber, we are happy at most of what is in this bill but, as I said, it does not go far enough nor does the next bill coming through. Senator Kernot and the Greens, the way to fix the job properly is to support the motion I have in front of the chamber and Senator Teague's amendment which he moved this morning. If they are supported we will find out where the money goes in the future and the people that are misappropriating it. I am not saying it is the Aborigines; it is the white industry built up around it. If that amendment of Senator Teague's and the motion I have got in front are supported, we will find out what happened in the past and make sure it does not happen in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, the substantive thing to say is that the government welcomes the opposition's support for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. In saying that, I would like to address the specific questions that Senator Teague put when he addressed the Senate. Consistent with the earlier advice that I think both I and the Democrats got, that the third bill is currently being drafted and has been given essential for passage status this session, it is intended, all things being equal, to introduce the legislation into the house by 30 September.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the question Senator Teague asked about pecuniary interest provisions, the minister will make determinations in advance on those issues and those determinations will be disallowable instruments. In rare cases, quick decisions by the commission chairperson who is to have the power delegated by the minister are possible. The section of the bill that provides that power is section 23(3).

On the question that was raised on wards, Senator Teague noted the maximum number provided for but the actual situation is that the minister will make rules for wards once this legislation is passed and assented to. I might add it is very important that this legislation proceed through the Senate today in respect of the 60-day notice that is required for the elections to be held. It is proposed to have those elections in December as Senator Teague knows.

The minister will make those determinations based on advice from ATSIC and ATSIC's advice will be based on the consultation workshops that were held with regional council chairpersons in June this year. Interim boundaries only will be provided for the 1993 elections. The bill will propose an independent boundary review process for determining regional council zones' ward boundaries for the 1996 elections and beyond. I think that has actually canvassed the substantive questions that were raised.

I made a point before about the duplication of content of the second reading amendment that has been moved today. I think I saw Senator Panizza nodding in assent. It is fair enough for this amendment to have been moved in the House of Representatives where the honourable members are not debating the motion that Senator Panizza has moved which we currently are, but I think it is correct to say that the effect of the second reading amendment is precisely the same as Senator Panizza's motion. All I am saying in a desperate plea is that, having debated that issue thoroughly today, I hope it will perhaps curtail some of the debate on Senator Panizza's motion when it comes back to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is easy. You know what you have to do about it.

—Indeed, we do know what to do. The one point that I would like to make, and I think the debate today has clearly indicated it, is that the opposition is really on a hiding to nothing in the area of Aboriginal affairs, as it is in many other issues. Aboriginal people I know, and I do sympathise with them, find it very difficult at times to satisfy the often competing demands that are made by us and the critics generally. I think that has been profoundly demonstrated in debate here this morning.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague raised a point for which I have a significant amount of sympathy. He said that he felt that ATSIC had spent far too much time and energy concentrating on establishing its processes, rather than concentrating on the effectiveness of the delivery of its programs. Senator Panizza put the contrary view, which was that he felt it was all about accountability, accountability, accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Perhaps Senator Panizza and Senator Teague could work out a compromise position on this which Aboriginal people could properly respond to. I will make a few obvious points. Non-stop criticism of lack of accountability is consistently visited on Aboriginal organisations. A far higher degree of accountability is consistently expected of Aboriginal organisations than is expected of any other organisation in the electorate. That is obvious if one looks at the public record.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems which Aboriginal people have in this country, and I think they share it with women, is that more is expected of them. One of my favourite feminist slogans, which I really like because I think it is so accurate, is that it is not enough for a woman to be as good as a man—she has to be better. Fortunately, that is not very difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.
—I thought the honourable senator would! I think Aboriginal people are in the same boat.
—What about Aboriginal women?

—Yes, there is a common cause there. In my experience, it is never enough for Aboriginal organisations to perform as competently and accountably as equivalent organisations in the non-Aboriginal community. In order to be scrupulously passed as okay and given the stamp of approval, they have to consistently do much better than anyone else.

PARA.TAB: It would be interesting to look at the percentage of budget spent on administration by private enterprise and the government sector, but ATSIC spends a total of 14 per cent of its budget on administration in the delivery of its programs. That includes, I might add, the full democratic process which we, with bipartisan support, have established for ATSIC. So its elections and the establishment and support of its elected councils and council members are all included in that 14 per cent. So 86 per cent of the total budget of ATSIC is spent on program delivery.

ATSIC is a relatively young organisation which has, of necessity, spent a fair bit of time establishing its organisation and processes, otherwise it would have been kicked to death. Certainly, Senator Panizza indicated just a minute ago that he would be in there kicking it to death.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that at all.
—Indeed, the honourable senator did criticise ATSIC severely on the issue of accountability.
—Yes, and for what reason?

—I am glad the honourable senator agrees with that. ATSIC has now been criticised here this morning for spending too much time on the processes and accountability provisions that it is expected to deliver and not enough effective time on delivering the programs. In terms of the broad figures I have provided, that record stands up pretty well in comparison with equivalent organisations in maintaining the administrative vote at that level and delivering the lion's share of its budget provision in terms of actual program delivery.

PARA.TAB: I will not go through the host of complaints that Senator Panizza made.
