The reason why I do not think that the Senate's time would be profitably spent in doing that is that Senator Panizza complained about a domestic violence case in which a Queen's Counsel was paid to sit around the court for six hours a day over four days, and he visited that sin on ATSIC. I have been unable to find anybody in ATSIC who even knows about the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was defending the Aboriginal fellow.

—I heard everything the honourable senator said before, but that is a problem which I would confidently say, off the top of my head, could be rightly visited on the legal system. I am well aware that those things go on. I have been involved in those things with witnesses waiting to be called and so on. Courts do try not to inconvenience witnesses and not to have people who are on large salaries swanning around in corridors for inordinate lengths of time, but they do not always cope successfully.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Panizza is worried about people on high salaries swanning around in corridors, costing taxpayers a fortune, I suggest that he start on Senate estimates committees in his reform. I have to say, responsibly and with the greatest respect, that one of my early learning experiences in this place, in the old Parliament House—I have to concede that it has got a lot better since—was the extraordinary sight of rafts and rafts of highly paid bureaucrats spending hours and hours in the corridors waiting to be called before an estimates committee. I remember one group, when I was on my first estimates committee, finally being called but not asked a single question. If the honourable senator is worried about that, perhaps he could start on the estimates committee process of this parliament.

I am familiar with the kind of problem that is being raised in respect of our court system but I do not think it is fair to visit that problem on ATSIC, because it clearly is outside the commission's ambit of responsibility to control a court process. I give that as one example of why I do not think there is a lot of profit in spending too much time rebutting the entire list of targets for the shotgun attack of Senator Panizza.

One of the honourable senator's major targets was the CDEP program. ATSIC has to this point in time carried out an extensive analysis of three-quarters of the 200 CDEP programs, I think from memory, that are being administered across Australia. The commission is going for 100 per cent but so far it has done about 75 per cent. The result of that analysis, which has been done in direct cooperation with the relevant government department, has disclosed only about one per cent incidence of problems in that scheme. What it has also disclosed is a far greater number of people eligible as recipients of social security benefits in those communities who are currently not accessing those benefits.

I am not decrying for a minute the necessity to carry out these accountability provisions. ATSIC is certainly well aware of it and has got a major program of non-stop accountability. I suppose it is a difficulty if the commission has these processes and then is criticised for spending too much time on process and not enough on worrying about the delivery of the programs. Nevertheless, what I have stated has been the result of what I consider to be the most serious criticism that Senator Panizza has raised in earlier debate in this house.

I might add that I was intrigued this morning—I will follow it up this afternoon—to hear Senator Panizza say that there had been two calls by the Auditor-General for inquiries into ATSIC. I am not aware of either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I said that he qualified the reports twice.
—I will check the Hansard record. I understood Senator Panizza to say that the Auditor-General had called for two inquiries into ATSIC. I am not aware of either.
—Check Hansard.

—I will. All I am saying in trying to respond to the points raised in the debate today is that I personally am not aware of those calls. What I am aware of is the concerns that are raised about the CDEP programs, which I am sure will be satisfied when the full survey of all of the programs has been completed by ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line of all this is that I do not think it has been demonstrated during this debate, in anything that has been put before the Senate, that one can at this point justify setting up another reference to a Senate committee for a major investigation of ATSIC, when by any measure it has set up comprehensive processes. This bill, indeed, is further evidence of the continuing progression of ATSIC's own initiatives in providing for greater accountability. I do not think that on any measure one could justify setting up at this stage a reference to a Senate committee.

I make it clear that I am not saying that an examination of the effectiveness of ATSIC is not going to be the thing to do at some future time, after the significant changes that we are now processing in this three-stage process—all of which are based on initiatives that have come from ATSIC itself—have been progressed, and after the organisation has had a chance to settle down, when the legislative base has been established.

I make that point because it would be very helpful—for Aboriginal people on the ground—for that examination to be carried out at some future date by a Senate committee or a joint committee or a whatever committee, and for it to be carried out in a positive light, rather than in a negative light. If criticisms are to be made, that is okay. However, the parliamentary committee needs to approach this in an atmosphere of attempting to assist the organisation to provide a better delivery, rather than approaching it with a negative view.

I think I have addressed the major questions that have been raised today by Senator Teague and by Senator Panizza. On behalf of the government, I acknowledge the support given by honourable senators to the legislation, and thank them for that support. For the reasons that I have just given, we think that the second reading amendment is premature at this stage. It does not have sufficient grounds to be supported and the government will be opposing the second reading amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have learnt from experience here that Hansard does not record tone of voice, to my peril on occasions. I want to take the opportunity to clarify some of the motives that Senator Panizza imputed to my smiles and laughs, because I think it needs to be done. He imputed that I was laughing because the whole matter of ATSIC, including the accountability of ATSIC, was a joke. I just want to get it on the record that I do not think it is a joke. I do not think his motion is a joke. I think he is motivated by concern. We feel that the structures and the processes are being put in place to address some of his concerns—albeit not retrospectively, as he wishes it to be. Senator Panizza could not hear what I was saying, and I cannot let the record stand that I thought what he was saying, in terms of accountability, was a joke: it is not.

—I rise very briefly to acknowledge the answers to my three questions from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). I also acknowledge Senator Kernot's remark during the second reading debate that she was not imputing to the opposition any wish to get at ATSIC. She was making comments about the community at large. I want to make the clear affirmation, on behalf on the opposition, that we were not trying, by any of our remarks, to make life more difficult or more onerous for ATSIC. We want the reforms to the ATSIC legislation, and through those other reviews that we have called for, to make the whole of ATSIC's processes and outcomes more transparent, more open and more constructive.

PARA.TAB: In the light of the failure of the second reading amendment that I moved, I conclude by referring to the estimates process of the parliament and to the program performance statements that are a part of that estimates process. I believe that we in this chamber will be looking carefully for ATSIC to include explicit objectives in its programs. We want ATSIC to monitor its own performance. If there are ways in which we can assist ATSIC to make the evaluation of its programs more transparent, and to demonstrate the achievement of the outcomes that we are all pressing towards, we will all be better served when we look at the ATSIC estimates each six months at the Senate committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, very briefly, to address the remarks of Senator Kernot. Obviously, Senator Kernot has made an explanation of why she was giggling and laughing, but it is best if I explain to the people of Australia the actions of the Democrats, the Greens and the government, including Senator Collins, Senator Schacht and Senator Sherry and anyone else sitting over on the other side of the chamber. I will go easy on the new one. The message they gave as to what they think of accountability in Australia was in where they sat during the division. The Democrats were sitting with the government to attempt to deny accountability. The Greens from Western Australia were sitting on the same side, denying accountability. I refer to accountability for the $1.7 million of CDEP money in the Strelley leases near Port Hedland in Western Australia that Senator Collins said has been bought to account and the $120,000 that went to one—
—Did you have to respond, Senator Kernot?

—I ask Senator Collins to listen to this. I refer also to the $120,000 that was taken off one community, on a station not far out of Fitzroy Crossing, 100 kilometres away by bitumen road, just for taking goods out there for one year, including a spare fanbelt for a Landcruiser and ice-cream when they ran out of it. That sort of money is being creamed off the Aboriginals by the white Aboriginal industry. By their actions those honourable senators have denied accountability. Senator Collins said earlier—and I give him credence for it—that there will be more accountability in time to come. But they are letting abuses of the past get off scot-free. That is why I need to tell the people of Australia where the Democrats and the Greens sat when there was a vote on accountability. Of course, all the government senators sat right there with them.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS (PRODUCERS OF URANIUM ORE CONCENTRATES) CHARGE BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 September 1993, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Senate, I suggest that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Amendment Bill 1993 be debated cognately with the Nuclear Safeguards (Producers of Uranium Ore Concentrates) Charge Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Nuclear Safeguards (Producers of Uranium Ore Concentrates) Charge Bill 1993 are two bills that the coalition does not oppose. These two bills seek to impose a charge on commercial uranium producers to recover some costs incurred by the Australian Safeguards Office in conducting nuclear safeguards and physical protection programs which arise as a result of commercial activities. They are merely cost recovery bills, and they have the support of the coalition. Not only for these two bills but for many other bills that the government puts forward, it is the coalition's policy that, where possible and where community obligations are not prominent, cost recovery has the support of the coalition.

PARA.TAB: The charges are set at the maximum of $500,000 per year per company and two companies are going to be affected—the Ranger uranium company in the Northern Territory and the Olympic Dam company. The cost I believe will be something around $340,000 per annum or 20c per kilogram of uranium produced, which is about $700,000 a year.

I do not see a need to go into a long debate about this—the opposition has been accused of obstructing the Senate and this is one set of bills that we have no objection to. I will just raise one point that I think bears noting. When Michael Lee, the representative of the government, was responding to the bills in the other place, he said that there is no need to discard the third uranium mine policy because it is quite feasible for Ranger to increase production to meet any demand. That is not the case in point. Ranger's mine has just about reached the point where it is unable to increase production. The company is looking for the government to open up the old Jabiluka mine, the North Ranger mine, but the government has said that it will not allow it.

While in a lot of areas the government may move to dry economics and economic rationalism, it is still the captive of the Left when it comes to the crazy uranium mining policy that it has. When the government is facing a million unemployed and a massive balance of trade problem, one way that we could create more jobs and reduce our overseas debt would be for the government to take a responsible attitude on the uranium policy. Even the members of the Right and the Centre Left would agree—I have heard a number of them saying it, I think even quite openly, and certainly former Senator Walsh used to say it frequently—that the government's policy just does not make sense.

I would just like to make that point and say that it is almost an act of stupidity to continue down the line of the uranium mining policy that the government has. I think it is well known that our side of politics would not go down the same track. In the interest of shortening use of the time that we are always being blamed for wasting and in the interest of getting more legislation through the Senate, I make only those few observations on these two bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the position of the Democrats in relation to uranium mining and export is well known. It was a foundation policy of the Australian Democrats in 1977 to oppose uranium mining and export. Indeed, although I was not a foundation member of the Democrats, I was probably the person in Australia who formulated that policy, as long ago as 1972. As a person who formed the Conservation Council of South Australia I formulated that as one of the council's initial policies. In 1973, when I was elected to the council of the Australian Conservation Foundation, I put it before the ACF; it was the first written policy of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Going back well before the formation of the Democrats, I had already adopted a strong position of opposing uranium mining and export from Australia.

PARA.TAB: I had taken that position after having been quite an enthusiastic supporter of nuclear power from the 1950s onwards. As a student of science, and later as a research scientist, it seemed to me that the argument that nuclear power would be so cheap that it would not even need to be metered was quite persuasive. However, by the late 1960s, it was becoming evident to me from reading the scientific literature that there was a great deal wrong with the safety of the whole nuclear power cycle.

When I looked at the inevitable links between the civilian nuclear power cycle and the use of nuclear facilities for the preparation of weapons, the whole situation became quite worrisome. Thus, in 1972, I adopted the position of opposing uranium mining. Nothing that I, or the Australian Democrats, have seen since has persuaded me that that position is not the correct one.

On the contrary, when I review the accidents which have occurred, the diversion of nuclear material into weapons, the total inadequacy of international safeguards—either at the multilateral level through the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the facilities of the International Atomic Energy Agency, or in relation to Australia's bilateral arrangements—I perceive that they are totally inadequate. They are pieces of paper which in no way can guarantee safeguards.

So the Australian Democrats support these two bills which seek to impose a charge on those who export uranium from Australia, under both the non-proliferation treaty arrangements and the bilateral arrangements which Australia has with a number of countries. These bills seek to recover the costs of the supervision of those safeguard arrangements. We have no objection to that as a matter of principle, because if Australia exports uranium, quite clearly those who lay the cost on the community of supervising those safeguards should pay that cost. That cost should not be borne by the community. I draw that clear distinction between the Australian Democrat's fundamental objection to uranium mining and export and our support for this legislation in relation simply to the polluter-pays principle, or the user-pays principle, which means that those who commit us to those international safeguard obligations, by reason of mining and exporting uranium, should pay the cost of those safeguards.

I would like to say a few words about the inadequacy of safeguards. The most extreme example of civilian nuclear non-safety was the Chernobyl reactor disaster. I invite members of the Senate to look at an article in a June issue of the journal of the International Atomic Energy Agency which was written several years before the Chernobyl disaster.

That article was written by Dr Semenov, who at that stage was the Director of Nuclear Safety in the International Atomic Energy Agency. Dr Semenov had the oversight of the safety of all nuclear power stations in the whole world. He says in that article that he was actually one of the engineers who designed the RBMK 1000 reactor, which was the type of reactor at Chernobyl.

In that article, Dr Semenov points out the essential safety of the Chernobyl reactor, claiming that there was no way at all that the Chernobyl reactor could have the sort of accident which we now know it subsequently had. I stress that it was the Director of Nuclear Safety at the International Atomic Energy Agency who made these claims several years before that Chernobyl reactor blew up—with the disastrous consequences that we all know about.

Many people have claimed that the Chernobyl reactor fire—the losing of the top of the safety shield around that reactor—resulted in some tens of deaths. What the people who make those sorts of claims ignore is the fact that it spread vast amounts of radiation around the whole of Europe as far as Ireland, as far as southern England, and right through southern Europe as far as Turkey. In the long term, the number of cancers which could be equated with that radiation exposure may range up to a million, and they are additional cancers which would not otherwise have occurred in that European population.

I would just like to turn to a couple of points that Senator Boswell made. Senator Boswell talked about the advantages of opening other mines. I would point out that for many years Australia maintained a floor price for uranium. I guess it maintained a floor price because it wanted a profitable industry and it reckoned that the $US30 per pound floor price was one which would guarantee that the industry was profitable. We all know that not so long back the government had to reduce the floor price and, if we take the figure in the minister's second reading speech, the value of 20c per kilogram which is quoted there works out at about $17 per pound for the current price of uranium.

I simply pose for the government and the opposition, but particularly the opposition, the stupidity of opening up other mines so we are then in the position of having mines which are competing with existing mines which have only just recently, through a slight increase in price, become profitable again. Having those mines compete, we would possibly export somewhat more uranium but certainly we would be exporting it at a lower price. That links very much with the question of safeguards. If we put ourselves in a situation in which, for economic reasons, we need to push the sale of uranium, there is a strong temptation to undermine the bilateral safeguard arrangements into which we might enter.

I think the coalmining industry is a nice example of this. We have recently had a strike in which the coalminers were very concerned that negotiations had led to a lower unit price for coal exports. As long as coalmines in Australia compete with one another for exports it is very likely that the unit price will fall lower and lower, and to make any profit at all one will have to export larger and larger tonnages. It means that we exploit these non-renewable resources even faster and Australia finishes up sooner rather than later as a mined-out quarry with no resources left whatsoever, either for its own use or for export.

Senator Boswell also mentioned the question of employment, claiming that opening new uranium mines would lead to more employment. I think it needs to be restated yet again—unfortunately, yet again—that mining is now a very capital intensive activity. No matter how much more mining we were to open up, mining would not in itself lead to very much more employment. Mining is not the way to go if one wants employment. The costs per job in the mining industry come at a very high price. The opening of further uranium mines certainly would not lead to a large increase in employment. If the increased exports led to an excess of uranium on the international market and a fall in the price, it may well be that opening another mine would lead to no employment whatsoever and an undermining of the employment in the existing two mines.

There are another two issues that I would like briefly to raise. One is that the whole notion of safeguards, the very use of the word `safeguards' in relation to these multinational and bi-national agreements, is really a euphemism. It leads people to believe that there is such a thing as a safeguard. I come back to the point that I made earlier that, whatever agreements we enter into, either through the NPT or as nation-to-nation arrangements, they are simply bits of paper. Once the uranium leaves our shores there is no effective control that we can have over it, whatsoever. I simply witness the situation where the French supplied a nuclear reactor to Iraq, and other countries supplied uranium. Once that regime decided that it was not going to conform with any inspections, we all know the difficulty that occasioned. We cannot control the use of uranium or anything derived from uranium, such as plutonium, once it leaves our shores. So `safeguards' really is a euphemism for bits of paper which may, for a time, give some guarantee of protection but certainly can give no absolute protection, whatsoever.

My final point, in relation to entering into the export of a dangerous material such as uranium, is the way in which it can be used, not only for civilian power development, but it can also be diverted into weapons development. Of course, Australia participated very much in this activity in the 1950s. It was Australian uranium that came back and was used in the British bombs which were exploded at Maralinga. That has polluted a vast area of South Australia and there is continuing controversy as to the costs and the efficacy of clean-up. The very fact that one exports this material which is so dangerous, and so linked with the potential for nuclear war, brings one's international relationships into an area that, in our view, it is not necessary to enter. If, for argument's sake, the money that we are spending on uranium mining and export was spent instead on things such as alternative energy sources, which are essentially renewable and are non-polluting, then one would not even need to enter into these safeguards agreements. They inevitably produce a certain amount of tension between nations—tensions that we can well do without.

At this very time, as honourable senators will have heard, we have a marvellous opportunity in relation to alternative fuels for transport—something that I have spoken about several times in recent days. We have the world's leading technology in many aspects of the use of solar energy for heat and for direct generation of electricity through photovoltaic devices. We would strongly urge that the government continuously review the benefit and the disbenefits associated with uranium mining and export, and that it should seriously consider getting out of uranium mining altogether and getting into these renewable and safer sources of energy which have enormously more value in terms of export potential as well.

Having said all that, I simply come back to the point that these bills are user-pays type bills. If we are going to export uranium, then those who mine the uranium and involve us in these exports should pay the full costs of safeguards, such as they are. Therefore, we will be supporting the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of brevity I will try to finish in the next five minutes. Firstly, in response to Senator Boswell, I thank him for taking into account our time constraints on this piece of legislation. One matter that I do want to rebut is his assertion that the Labor Party policy is a captive of the Left on this matter. That is certainly not correct. The party has a well-regarded, democratic, representative structure and a national conference which we attend every couple of years. That is the very open and democratic policy forum for these sorts of debates. Our policy is well known as a consequence of a policy adopted about three or four years ago.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter raised a range of issues and, frankly, that did not surprise me, given the Democrats' position on the uranium industry. I do not intend to go into those issues today. The purpose of the two bills before us is to enable us to recover the costs of certain nuclear safeguards and related activities of the Australian Safeguards Office from Australian uranium producers. I welcome the support of both the opposition and the Australian Democrats for the principles and the details in this legislation.

The charge will be set by regulation each year on the basis of the approved program and the budget of the Australian Safeguards Office, following consultation with the uranium companies. Since the charge is not due to be paid until 1 December each year, there will be plenty of time for full consultation before it is collected. The government's international obligations on safeguards—legally binding under treaty-level agreements—will ensure that there will be no compromise on safeguards through the implementation of the cost recovery arrangements.

There is no reason that the uranium mining companies should not pay a reasonable share of the costs of nuclear safeguards that are applied in connection with their operations and exports. Those who benefit from a service or activity should pay for it on the basis of full recovery of attributable costs, provided that national interests or community service obligation components are funded wholly by the government. The specific amounts to be recovered are reasonable and defensible. There is adequate consultation with those being required to pay. For these reasons, and the reasons that I outlined earlier in this debate, I would urge all honourable senators to support the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS (PRODUCERS OF URANIUM ORE CONCENTRATES) CHARGE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that struggling truckies will pay an average of $6,000 a year more in tax as a result of this budget; that increases in sales tax will put up the price of a semitrailer by $2,400; that Australian National, running through South Australia, will have an extra $4.25 million to pay which, of course, will be passed on; that V/Line in Victoria will pay an extra $2 1/2 million; and that State Rail in New South Wales will pay a massive extra $9 million? How does the minister expect battling Australian businesses to survive under this impossible tax load? Why does the government not take the advice of 74 per cent of the Australian people and go back and redraft the budget?

—It is well known that there are some implications of the budget in the areas that have been mentioned by Senator Hill. I am not in a position to comment any further on that particular matter. I will see what the Treasurer or my leader wants to say in reply to that question.

—Mr Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. The government has already demonstrated that it has been prepared to go back and redraft part of the budget. Why will it not now go back and relieve the transport industry of this impossible burden, which flows through to so much of Australian business?

—I am reminded by Senator Collins that this question, as I thought, has been answered in terms of the actual CPI impact. If Senator Collins can finish reminding me what the actual numerical impact of it was, I may be able to tell the Senate.
—Half a per cent.

—Half a per cent is the impact at its maximum, as has been estimated by the government at the moment. I cannot be expected to carry around all these figures in my head on every single aspect of the budget in this respect. The question has already been asked and it has already been answered. That is the response of the government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to recent publicity concerning the forthcoming trade mission to Asia being led by the Minister for Communications, Mr David Beddall. It stems from my interest in communications and particularly the question of telecommunications manufacturing. Can the minister inform the Senate of developments in the Australian telecommunications manufacturing and export markets which the trade mission will aim to promote?

—As I informed the Senate only a few days ago, Australian electronics firms are carving themselves a very effective place in the market internationally with their capacity to produce world-class electronics equipment and telecommunications equipment. I mentioned a number of the companies that have successfully exploited market opportunities for the provision of technology such as microwave landing systems, in which I think, arguably, Australia is leading the world at the moment.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Beahan has indicated, the Minister for Communications leaves tomorrow to lead a trade mission to Asia. The trade mission is being conducted under the auspices of the telecommunications export task force, which was created by the federal government as part of the government's policy underpinning the reform of the Australian telecommunications industry. The trade mission is a clear example of the continuing growth of the Australian telecommunications industry and the government's commitment to raising the profile of this industry in our region.

In relation to growth in the industry, the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association recently reported that exports of Australian produced telecommunications equipment increased in 1992 by over 25 per cent to $360 million. Exports in 1993 will exceed $500 million, and are on target for $1 billion by 1997. Exports in telecommunications equipment have quadrupled since 1988 and reflect the competitiveness of the industry and the results achievable under the government's telecommunications industry policy arrangements.

Major exports include customer premises equipment; cable, including submarine cable; network equipment; mobile telephones; and data communications equipment. Almost 50 per cent of exports go to the Asian region where the major markets are China, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia and Thailand. There are numerous projects in which Australian telecommunication manufacturers are involved. Examples of these projects include the supply by AWA Australia of microwave transmission equipment and multiplexers for Vietnam's rural communication networks; a $70 million contract, won by the Olex Cable division of Pacific Dunlop, involving the supply of 3,150 kilometres of optical fibre cable and transmission equipment that will link a number of cities in north-west China; and a contract for Alcatel Australia, which I mentioned the other day, to supply 12 digital telephone exchanges to China valued at approximately $75 million and considered to be one of the biggest export deals involving exchanges made by an Australian company.

In addition, since 1986 Telstra has co-operated with the Director-General of Post and Telecommunications of Vietnam in the development of that nation's telecommunications infrastructure. Under a 10-year business cooperation contract, Telstra's partnership with the DGPT has created satellite earth stations, international and domestic exchanges, optical fibre cabling networks and has supplied a large range of equipment and components, training and management services. A team of over 60 Australian companies has been involved in this project. It is pleasing that the region is increasingly looking to Australia as a supplier of high quality telecommunications equipment and services. I have no doubt that the trade mission led by Minister Beddall will increase that trend.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. In light of the evidence given to Estimates Committee D by the Department of Finance that a reasonable commercial rent payable to the Australian Labor Party for space in its Centenary House is for an annual rental increase of only one per cent, not nine per cent as provided for in the agreement for lease negotiated by the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services; and further in the light of the Department of Finance's evidence that it will provide money to the tenant, the Auditor-General, to cover only one per cent and not nine per cent; and the evidence given by the Australian National Audit Office that by 1996 it will not have enough money to pay the rent and do its job, will the government—which of course is the Australian Labor Party—and the minister responsible to whom I direct this question, find some decency and renegotiate the lease, which I understand has not yet been signed, to meet the standard of the Department of Finance?

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, your time has expired but, as the President himself has observed, one does not need the help of government senators to establish that.

—It is a great pity that Senator Bishop does not have any new issues to run her leadership campaign on and so has to dredge up last year's issues. Everybody here would—or should—remember that this matter was exhaustively investigated and discussed at great length in the Senate and in the Senate estimates hearings last year. We tabled mountains of documents and people went through them in the fond hope they would find a scandal and, to their great chagrin, they found none. The result was very clear. There was no malpractice then because the documents were presented and those opposite had every opportunity to pursue them and did not. I am not going to go over all the things that were tabled then.
—Why don't you answer the question?

—I thank Senator Vanstone very much for her help; I will be quite happy to deal with the question of the Department of Finance and the audit office and their disagreement in a moment. But I want to give a bit of background which is directly relevant to the question. These are matters that have been discussed in the Senate before and we are entitled to put on the record the facts that have been discussed. In his 1991-92 annual report, the Auditor-General advised the Senate that of the 14 proposals submitted to the audit office for new accommodation, Centenary House was considered by audit to be the only suitable proposal. It did not think the Liberal Party's proposal was suitable.
—Hang on! That was not a Liberal Party proposal; get it right.

—The Liberal Party made a proposal and it was rejected. I know Senator Hill is upset about that but it is still true. The terms of the lease, the rent and the escalation were based at all times on the advice of the independent Australian Valuation Office. The integrity of the Australian Valuation Office has never been questioned on any occasion that I am aware of. Nobody has questioned the professionalism or integrity of the AVO, nor has anybody questioned the integrity of Baillieu Knight Frank, which conducted the independent assessment of the lease for the audit office and which said that the base rent was commercially realistic.
—Ha, ha!

—Baillieu Knight Frank and the Valuation Office did that. The level of escalation was based on AVO recommendations and Baillieu Knight Frank said, `Having regard to the factors which impact on rental growth, the escalation rates, while considered towards the maximum, are not unreasonable'. Baillieu Knight Frank and the AVO have both said that these are reasonable proposals.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that there is a disagreement between the Department of Finance and the audit office. I represent Finance and the audit office here, as well as the Australian Property Group. But I have not as yet heard what the objective evidence is which the Department of Finance is using to indicate that the Australian Valuation Office and Baillieu Knight Frank are wrong and the Department of Finance is right. But it is a proper matter for the Department of Finance to discuss with the audit office and I assume it will and will continue to do so. The Australian Property Group in DAAS has indicated to the audit office that it remains available to assist it in its discussions with the Department of Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I see from the Australian Securities Commission records that at the time of the negotiations and the signing of the agreement for lease between the Commonwealth and John Curtin House Ltd—the ALP is the shareholder and the beneficiary of the lease—three sitting senators, namely, Senators Beahan, Faulkner and Loosley were directors of the company. The minister was previously the principal executive officer. In the light of these facts, how can the minister maintain that this is a genuine commercial lease, negotiated at arms length and untainted by undue influence? How can he possibly justify signing the lease, which is due to commence on 23 September next, except to meet the cashflow requirements of the Australian Labor Party?

—I have only one fact to add to those which I have already given. My advice, as I left my office to come here, is that the average escalation of rent in McEwen House up the road in the period it has been occupied by the National Party has been 9.35 per cent.

—My question to the Minister for Family Services refers to the child-care promises made to Australian families in the Prime Minister's `Investing the Nation' speech and his speech at the launch of the National Agenda for Women in the lead-up to the federal election. Can the minister inform the Senate to what extent the recent budget child-care initiatives meet those commitments and what steps the government has taken to implement those measures?

—The government does recognise very much the importance to families of affordable and accessible child care so that they can participate actively in the work force and the community. The important child-care initiatives announced by the Prime Minister during the election campaign are designed to build on the government's child-care strategy. First, the government has delivered on places: over its life, the government has increased the number of child-care places from 46,000 to over 200,000 currently and it has increased expenditure from $65 million to about $640 million this financial year.

PARA.TAB: The government is moving to implement its election promises, particularly in the area of child care. The government has made a commitment to fully meet the demand for work related child care by the year 2001, and has an interim target of 300,000 child care places by the end of 1996-97.

This budget provides funding for an estimated 29,000 additional places in 1993-94. The government will do this by continuing its national child-care strategy and by entering into partnerships with local government, community groups and employers to increase the supply of child care. In case the opposition is interested, New South Wales and Victoria have been very tardy in negotiating with government to establish and continue the national child-care strategy.

The government is also encouraging employers to participate in providing child care by extending the fringe benefits tax exemption not only to cover long day care places that are already covered but also family day care, after school hours care and vacation care from 1 July this year.

The government is also concerned about the message that has been given to us by users of child care about how best to provide for parents with sick children. This is a pilot project that we established late last year. It has provided evidence to government that will enable us to find the best way of delivering provisions for parents with sick children. This is a very complex measure. Of course, honourable senators would appreciate that the variety of need depends very much on the sort of child care that parents use and whether or not an alternative use of child care might be best for children who are sick.

Also in this area, the National Health and Medical Research Council is investigating the criteria for when children should be required to be away from child care because they may have a contagious or infectious disease and when children who are sick may return to a child-care centre but be cared for apart from the other children. These are very complex matters. The government intends to continue to talk very extensively with child care providers and parent users.

The government also announced its 30 per cent cash rebate for the cost of work related child care, which will be implemented on 1 January 1994. The government is also introducing sales tax exemption for the goods provided in the child care area in long day care, outside school hours care, vacational care and family day care. We are also continuing the important emphasis on quality child care. That is why I have established the National Child Care Accreditation Council, headed by Quentin Bryce, AO, to implement that system. We are also concerned to assist mothers at home by extending long day care fee relief—now called child assistance—to occasional care. We have also allocated money to assist the establishment of over 3,000 play groups. So, Mr Deputy President, you can see that in this area the promises made are the promises kept.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the minister aware of the serious concerns being raised about the safety and efficacy of the proposed changes to the airspace rules for Australian airspace? The CAA has announced that these changes will begin on 11 November 1993. When is the government intending to introduce the regulatory changes which implement these new rules? Will the Senate be given sufficient time to discuss these changes because, as I understand it, we are talking about serious air safety matters for a large number of commuter passengers at places like Cooma and Uluru? We are all a bit worried that the government will bypass parliamentary scrutiny on this issue.

—Frankly, what would be of much more concern to me than any expert opinion the Senate could bring to bear on the new airspace management would be if the CAA made any attempt to bypass the true professionals in this area, and that is the pilots who fly aircraft. I am well aware of these criticisms, because I worked very closely with Dick Smith—who is making these criticisms—when he was chairman of the CAA, and I know what Dick's views are.

PARA.TAB: I have to tell Senator Kernot, with the greatest respect, that as much as I respect Dick Smith's views—and I do—I have a great deal of difficulty, closely concerned with this issue as I am as the minister, when I know that every peak body in Australia, which represents 99 per cent of all the pilots in Australia from senior 747 captains to hang-glider pilots, are so concerned about Dick Smith's opposition that they have written to me and expressed their strongest support for the changes to the CAA.

I am happy to provide Senator Kernot with a copy of all of the correspondence. It has already been canvassed at length in Senate committees. I chaired a forum of all of the peak industry aviation bodies here at Parliament House only last week. This matter was actively discussed then. It is a shame that Senator Kernot could not have been there to have heard some of the things said.

I have letters from the peak bodies that represent 80 per cent of the private pilots in Australia that fly light aircraft, that say categorically—these people are no supporters of the government; we have had plenty of kicks from the same organisations over the years—`on this issue Dick Smith is wrong'. I also have letters from the organisations which represent the major RPT airlines in Australia.

I wish Senator Kernot or someone from the Democrats would avail themselves of the invitation that has been issued of getting detailed briefings from the CAA on this complex issue—as the opposition and David Jull have—then she would then understand how complex the issue is. She would then also understand that over the last 18 months the CAA has had face to face discussions with 2000 flight instructors and 3,500 individual pilots already. They have been the most extensive discussions with the people who really matter—that is, the people who fly aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an absolute and utter disaster.

—I am well aware of Senator MacGibbon's idiosyncratic views on matters relating to aviation. He never declares his own personal interest in these matters. All I can say is that I am taking a close interest in the issue. I have had extensive consultations with the CAA and with industry. I am happy to provide Senator Kernot with copies of the correspondence I have received from all of the peak bodies in Australia that represent the majority of Australian pilots and airline companies, from the 747 captains to the people who fly hang-gliders. I wish that the Democrats would avail themselves of the opportunity to be briefed by the Civil Aviation Authority on this issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Could the minister inform the Senate what options are open to doctors to recover fees which are owing to them? Can the minister advise the Senate whether it is usual for a doctor to threaten access to future treatment for the non-payment of a bill? Is the minister aware of a recent example of such a threat raised in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Gilmore?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, doctors, like all business persons, are entitled to use the normal processes available for the recovery of debts. Those processes extend from the writing of reminder letters to people to pay up, all the way through to the use of the sheriff in the courts. Many doctors have availed themselves of those processes over the years. However, it is not normal, in fact it is highly unusual, for a doctor to threaten to jeopardise access to future treatment for non-payment of a bill. The government would be extremely concerned if a patient's ability to pay for those services was ever to affect the provision of those services in the future.

PARA.TAB: Now the specific case referred to here was mentioned by the honourable member for Gilmore in the House of Representatives and then referred to in the Senate by Senator Baume—whom I note has now joined us. I have great concern about this issue. Unlike my colleague in the House of Representatives or Senator Baume, I will not be referring to the names of those involved. I do not believe that helps any of us. It should be noted that the doctor concerned, in his letter to the patient, said:

ANSWER.PARA: It should be noted that all four anaesthetists rendering services in this area have a computer linked system. All non-payments are obvious and noted by all doctors concerned. Therefore, in order not to jeopardise receiving future treatment, please pay your account promptly.
I think any citizen who was in a regional area where those four anaesthetists were the only game in town and who received that kind of letter would be entitled to worry—and worry this person did!

TALK.START.PARA: —It might encourage him to pay his bill.

—I hope Senator Panizza's interjection is on record. The encouragement for people to pay bills is quite reasonable. I have no objection to that whatsoever. I referred at the beginning of my answer to the access that doctors have to the normal processes open to every business person to chase up those who owe them money, including access to the sheriff and the courts.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Baume referred to this matter in the Senate, he responded on the basis that there was no suggestion that emergency treatment would be denied. He stated in his contribution:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no suggestion that in an emergency no service would be provided.
He suggested that the member did not understand the difference between emergency and discretionary services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you heard of discretionary surgery?
—The letter sent out by the doctor reads:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . in order not to jeopardise receiving future treatment . . .

There is no difference made by the doctor. Any ordinary citizen who received that kind of letter would immediately say to himself, `If I get into strife, I'm in big trouble here. The anaesthetists aren't going to look after me'. That is what I find disturbing—not just a little disturbing, but very disturbing indeed. The medical profession does not normally behave like this. It is not customary. There are thousands and thousands of doctors who would never dream of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —All he had to do was pick up the Medicare cheque.

—When this doctor did it, he was very wrong indeed, Senator Baume. It is to be hoped that the doctor and other doctors who hear of this incident just remember that at the end of the day one does not threaten to kill; one just threatens to go to court.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In answer to a question from Senator Parer yesterday, the minister said that the shipping industry's fuel oil excise is now under consideration. How can this be when the budget passed through the other place last night? Does this mean the government is planning to further amend its already discredited budget of betrayal to lessen the devastating effect that the increase in fuel excise will have on our shipping, road and rail transport industries?

—There is nothing I wish to add to what I said about this yesterday, except to point out that it is not the shipping industry's fuel oil excise. Fuel oil is also extensively used for the generation of power in isolated communities, particularly in mining establishments. One of the most notable that I am aware of, which is in my backyard, is the Nabalco operation at Gove, which uses fuel oil for that purpose. So it is not simply the shipping industry that uses fuel.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Why is it that special consideration is being given to fuel oil excise, but no special consideration is being given to the extra fuel excise that will be paid in terms of our road and rail transport, which will have such a profound effect on people who live outside metropolitan areas in particular and which will add to costs, resulting in the burden being borne by ordinary Australians?

—In answer to that question, I suggest that Senator Ferguson should have regard to the current base rate of excise being charged on those different categories of fuel. There is quite a gap between the two.

—Order! In an earlier question, during an interjection, a senator described another senator as dishonest. In my view it is an unattractive description and it is unparliamentary. If I hear the word being used in future, I will call on the senator to withdraw it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of recent reports in the Australian Financial Review, the Canberra Times and other newspapers indicating industry concerns about the government's budget decision not to go ahead with private sector financing for the Commonwealth self-drive vehicle fleet? What is the background of this decision and the reasons for it?

—To assess this issue, one needs to look a bit at the context. It falls within the context of the overall process of commercialisation the government started in 1987. Since that time, about $700 million in potential revenue previously controlled by what are now Department of the Arts and Administrative Services operations has been opened up to competition. These issues of commercialisation and competition are very complex. They cannot be resolved simply by sloganeering and assertion, which we tend to get all too often.

PARA.TAB: The government's obligation is to base decisions in these matters on a proper assessment of the public interest, taking into account the benefit to the public as taxpayers. In the case of Dasfleet, the government has decided that this business should continue as the sole provider of leased self-drive vehicles to Commonwealth departments and agencies. We simultaneously decided that the maintenance and servicing of the leased vehicles should be opened up to private sector competition.

This decision was made following a substantial analysis of the options available to the government in this matter. The analysis was first of all undertaken by the Department of Finance in consultation with the Department of Administrative Services but it also involved considerable assistance from expert advisers from the private sector. This analysis showed quite clearly that the current acquisition and leasing arrangements are the most cost-effective.

In the face of that evidence, not to have gone in the direction that we did—that is, not to have maintained the current acquisition and leasing arrangements—would have been a triumph for ideology over analysis. I know that there are those who believe that we should, in any event and irrespective of the facts, proceed to hand things over to the private sector, but in this instance the potential cost to the Commonwealth—in other words, the Australian taxpayer—of changing the existing arrangements was assessed at up to $100 million over 10 years.

So, quite clearly, the responsible decision in this instance was to retain vehicle purchase and disposal through Dasfleet to enable the Commonwealth to maintain the benefits and savings available from its aggregate purchasing power. But something obviously needs to be done to constrain the potential for a monopoly supplier to abuse its position. In the first instance, we will be setting up a committee of the customers to monitor regularly the prices charged and to compare them with private sector charges. There will be a major review conducted under the auspices of that committee in two years time.

The Australian Financial Review referred to the fact that some private financing groups have done deals with state governments in this area. The Financial Review got it absolutely right when it said that those bodies—state governments, statutory instrumentalities and local government—have relied on tax effective financing; that is, they have been transferring the cost to the Commonwealth taxpayer, thus saving money for the state. As the Financial Review pointed out, while savings from this source have obvious appeal to the states, they have none for the Commonwealth. All we would be doing is making fleet leasing savings in one hand which we paid through forgone tax revenue in the other. We decided not to go in that direction. We decided to pursue the course which independent advice indicated was the most tax effective for the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister will be aware that there has been widespread community concern about the various promises and statements made by the Prime Minister during the election period. Is it not a fact that during the 1993 election campaign Mr Keating said on 3 March, `Australians deserve the right to organise themselves as they wish'? How does the minister reconcile this statement of the Prime Minister in the light of the government's cave-in to the ACTU in forcing workers to join unions if they want enterprise based deals? Further, why does the government allow the ACTU to dictate its industrial relations policy?

—That was as cogent and analytical a question as I would have expected in the circumstances. The circumstances are simply that Mr Brereton, the Minister for Industrial Relations, and the Prime Minister, in speeches recently and in answers to questions in the House of Representatives, have made very clear the policy position of the Commonwealth, which I also outlined to the Senate yesterday. The answers were obviously very accurate because they coincided quite closely. If people want to know what the policy position is, I simply refer them to those answers provided by Mr Brereton yesterday and those which I provided, which were consistent.

PARA.TAB: I said yesterday, and I reiterate, that our position remains simply that we have objectives which we want to achieve in terms of flexibility in the workplace. We will achieve them and we are prepared to enter into discussions with any responsible participant about the most appropriate method for achieving those objectives. The fact that there might be a review of the process of achieving fixed objectives should not be a cause of concern to anybody. It is the move towards allowing individual groups of workers within workplaces, if they so choose, to form enterprise unions. It is something which we would have thought the opposition would have welcomed. If they do not so choose, they will not be forced to do so and the existing arrangements, which have existed under federal laws since federation and which allow those workers to conduct negotiations with their employers, will continue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that Senator McMullan did not tackle the issue of whether Mr Keating's word had been kept or not. I will not press him on that because clearly it causes him some embarrassment. I draw the minister's attention to a related issue. The Business Council of Australia said today:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Kelty position on non-union bargaining meant the reforms would be worse than the present system and a deterrent to future investment.
That comes from an article in the newspaper today headed `Democrats flag support for Kelty proposals'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report but it sounds profoundly wrong to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates to the recent release of statistics for passenger traffic in Australian domestic aviation and to a recent National Reporter article headlined `Growth zooming in the north'. In the light of these statistics and the contents of the article, can the minister advise the Senate of the domestic aviation results achieved in Queensland and Northern Territory destinations?

—I am pleased to inform the Senate that the level of domestic airline activity in Australia has increased to new record levels for the year ending 30 June 1993. Almost 18.6 million passengers were carried for the year—
—Does that include Compass?

—There is some good news in here for Townsville, and I know that Senator Macdonald cannot stand hearing that because he has opposed everything we have ever tried to do for Townsville, including the $20 million we put into the harbour. Leaving that aside, the annual rate of growth was small compared with the previous record high of June 1992 base. Nevertheless, in the light of difficult economic conditions both in Australia and overseas, any growth is an outstanding result.

PARA.TAB: A very encouraging indicator was the result for the June quarter this year which was the highest ever recorded. Over 4.5 million passengers flew in the June quarter 1993—an increase of eight per cent on the previous June quarter. The stimulus provided by the government's aviation reforms to Australian tourism has been a major achievement of Australian transport and economic policy and that has been acknowledged by the industry.

Coming from northern Australia, I noted that one of the outstanding features of the results for the year ending 30 June 1993 was the passenger growth rates achieved in a number of major holiday destinations. These results included the following increases in passenger numbers: Maroochydore up 37 per cent; Yulara up 29 per cent; Townsville up 18 per cent—obviously they have not found out that Senator Macdonald lives there yet; Proserpine up 17 per cent; Mackay up 14 per cent; and Alice Springs up 11 per cent. I would have thought that was welcome news from anybody who purported at least to represent Queensland. These results, as the article in the National Reporter indicated, certainly demonstrate the health of tourism, both domestically and overseas, in the Northern Territory and Queensland.

The government has substantially reaffirmed its commitment to the tourism industry through additional funding in the budget of $80 million over the next four years. I was particularly pleased to note that an allocation of $23 million will be provided to stimulate tourism development in regional Australia although I am sure that, consistent with his previous record, Senator Ian Macdonald will lobby to ensure that none of that federal government money goes to Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the requirements of the occupational superannuation regulations, for which the Treasurer has responsibility, which specifically prevent members of superannuation funds using their entitlement to superannuation as security for pre-retirement loans and which also prevent trustees allowing any consequential liens to be effected. I also refer him to taxation law on this matter. Is the minister aware of the Prime Minister's recent statement in Tasmania, of which I have the transcript, that he had hocked his superannuation to pay for his $430,000 half ownership of a $30 million piggery group that has entered into a $80 million joint venture with a Danish multinational? Will the minister ask the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to examine whether there has been any breach of the superannuation regulations or misuse of the Commonwealth parliamentary superannuation fund in this case? Will the minister table any such evidence of breach or misuse?

—Senator Baume has not improved, has he? We went scurrying along this gutter for a couple of years before the last election with no good cause. All that has happened is that the Prime Minister is still the Prime Minister and Senator Baume is on the back bench, so I just point out to him that this has not been the world's most successful campaign. I suspect from the sound of the quote that he has taken it monstrously out of context and misinterpreted it, but I will see whether the Prime Minister wishes to add anything and if he does, I will report it to the Senate.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. If the minister does not take the Prime Minister's word for it, does he believe Mr Laurie Oakes's backgrounded justification of the Prime Minister's investment that `in essence, Keating has punted his parliamentary superannuation' on the piggery venture? Will the minister give his personal assurance to the Senate that there have been no breaches of the superannuation regulations in this case, particularly by the Commonwealth Bank for which the Treasurer has responsibility? Or is the bank giving privileged treatment to the Prime Minister, as a pig farmer, that is not available to the Australian farmers against whom it is now foreclosing by lending $430,000 to the Prime Minister against his superannuation entitlement without requiring security?
—I regard the Commonwealth Bank as a very reputable institution whose reputation does not deserve that sort of attack, but I will give it a chance to respond.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It concerns the fact that Australia is about to finalise the nuclear science and technology agreement with Indonesia at a time when a decision to construct a new research reactor has been put on hold for five years. If Australia no longer had an operating research reactor, would there be any part of any of the nuclear cooperation agreements already signed or currently being negotiated either in general or with Indonesia in particular which could not be met? Will the minister give the date on which the nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement with Indonesia will be signed? Finally, where will the signing take place?

—The question is a manifestly hypothetical one, not least because it is the case that Australia continues to operate two research reactors at Lucas Heights—one medium sized one, the HIFAR, and another very much smaller one—and will do so for some years to come, irrespective of the question of whether or not the HIFAR reactor is replaced. But having said that, let me respond to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: The first part is based on a false premise about the extent of the obligations that Australia would assume under the agreement with Indonesia, or indeed any similar agreement that might be contemplated. The nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement under discussion with Indonesia is, like most inter-governmental science and technology cooperation agreements, a framework agreement. While setting out the types of areas of intended cooperation, such agreements do not oblige either party to participate in particular projects. That is a matter for subsequent decision on a case by case basis.

I have told the Senate on a number of occasions that the agreement in question here is intended to enhance cooperation between Indonesia and Australia in areas such as nuclear medicine, radiation protection, nuclear-related safety information and applications of radioisotopes. Clearly if we did no longer operate any research reactors, the scope for us to engage in nuclear science and technology cooperation with other countries would be significantly diminished. However, I would expect that Australia will remain involved in peaceful uses of nuclear energy into the future, irrespective of whether there is a replacement for HIFAR through, for example, the medical, agricultural and industrial uses of radioisotopes. Similarly, we will be involved in the handling and accounting for nuclear materials for the foreseeable future, again irrespective of the decision on HIFAR.

As to the latter parts of the honourable senator's question, no date or place for the signature of the agreement has yet been set. As I told the Senate estimates committee on 31 August, the Indonesian Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Habibie, prefers that the agreement be signed in the context of a broader complementary science and technology agreement. Discussions on that are in progress and when precisely all the pieces will come together remains at this stage rather unclear.

Let me just take this opportunity to respond to some other related questions that people have been raising in the press recently, in particular about this being a secret agreement with Indonesia. Information in general terms about the nuclear science and technology agreement has been on the public record now for over 18 months. It is not normal practice for draft documents relating to government to government discussion on an agreement under negotiation to be made available publicly. It is simply not appropriate to do so—not because there is any particular sensitivity about it, but just because of the normal bilateral treaty practice. There is no particular further negotiation going on, in fact, about the text of the nuclear agreement. The difficulty is, as I have just described, that it is being discussed in the context of a possibly broader umbrella science and technology agreement, and how the whole document or related set of documents comes together is yet to be finally determined.

When the agreement is eventually signed, as we hope it will be before too long, it will of course be made public on signature, as these things always are, and tabled in parliament in accordance with normal treaty practice.

I would just say finally that I have seen a Greenpeace press release in the last day or so alleging that administrative arrangements for the agreement will not be made public. That is completely off the beam, as Greenpeace press statements so often are. The nuclear science and technology agreement has no administrative arrangements either as part of it or proposed to be part of it. Such arrangements are normal under Australia's nuclear transfer agreements for the export of uranium. But, as I have said on innumerable occasions now, the proposed agreement here does not provide for commercial transfers of uranium. That would be something to be negotiated at some future time, if the case ever arose.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. When the government came to power in 1983, over $6.50 out of every $10 raised through fuel tax was spent on Commonwealth road funding. The budget papers now reveal that by 1994-95 this will have fallen to $1 out of every $10 raised. Does this signify that the government feels all road problems are solved or merely that it sees the petrol bowsers as a branch of the tax office?

—No, it does not. In fact, as I am sure the honourable senator will be well aware, this hypothecation argument in respect of excise and road funding is a fiction, has always been a fiction and will continue to be a fiction, as the history books have shown since federation. Fuel excise is a revenue measure, just like any other revenue measure for government. It is spent not just on roads but on hospitals, health care systems, schools and everything else that the government expends road funding on.

PARA.TAB: Following the 1991 Premiers Conference, a substantial decision was taken by agreement with all of the state premiers that a brand new arrangement would be set into place in terms of road funding around Australia. It was, in that sense, as many of these things are, an historic decision. It was decided to have an absolute demarcation between the responsibilities of the Commonwealth government and state and local governments in terms of road funding. The Commonwealth government accepted the responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the national highway system, as designated from time to time. All 18,500 kilometres of it would be the Commonwealth's responsibility. The Commonwealth also agreed to untie substantial federal funds that were formerly directed specifically to road projects and to pay those funds to the states as untied grants so that the states, at the discretion of the state cabinets, could determine how that money would be spent.

The Prime Minister wrote to all of the state premiers and territory chief ministers last year—I think it was in July—clearly laying out the responsibilities, as agreed, and the amounts of money that we were committing ourselves to. We have committed ourselves to in excess of $1 billion of federal government funding for roads—I think the figure is $1.170 billion a year—for the next three years. Of that, roughly $820 million per year will be allocated by the federal government specifically to the national highway system. The rest of that money will be allocated in terms of untied grants for states.

Much has been made in recent times—and it has been highly inaccurate—of the black spots program, for example, which the federal government initiated through the initiatives of the former Minister for Land Transport, Bob Brown, to his great credit. That program was identified as a one-off program that was always due to expire at the end of June this year. It was a three-year program, planned over three years, and always planned to end in June this year.

The figures that have just been given by Senator Macdonald—the kind face, the human face, of the Macdonald family in the Senate chamber—have been used to draw these unreal comparisons against previous base rates of road funding. I will not be deterred if at some future time the Commonwealth can successfully negotiate a further one-off package. But as I have clearly indicated, in historical terms the Commonwealth's commitment to the funding of the Australian road system has been maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the minister to a report released last week by the Bureau of Industry Economics evaluating the government's 150 per cent tax concession for research and development. Can the minister inform the Senate of the benefits of this program? Is there any basis for the criticism which has been raised by the coalition spokesperson for science and technology, Dr Kemp?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the report released last week by the Bureau of Industry Economics entitled R&D, innovation and competitiveness. That report made a number of supportive comments, in particular about the government's decision in 1985 to introduce a 150 per cent tax concession for R&D. The report concluded that `the government's tax concession for R&D benefits both the individual company that invests in R&D and the nation'. It is clear that the opposition spokesperson on science, Dr Kemp, had not read the report, and particularly had not read that recommendation. Of course, one is not surprised by Dr Kemp's views about science and government assistance and support for R&D, because he comes from the far right wing—the ideological zealot of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —His namesake is up here also bleating along the same lines. So one is not surprised that Dr Kemp takes this view opposing government assistance and government support to R&D.

PARA.TAB: At the time of the last election, the then shadow minister for science, Peter McGauran, made it quite clear that the 150 per cent tax concession would be maintained. I know that, since then, there has been an absolute policy vacuum on the other side. The opposition has no science policy and no industry policy. Dr Kemp just goes around criticising, waiting for reports like this to be tabled and then uses it as a basis to claim the government is not assisting.

I point out to the Senate and to Dr Kemp—because he should have read this in the report—that the tax concession at the moment of 150 per cent for R&D is encouraging companies to spend around $200 million extra on R&D in Australia. Since 1985, that tax concession has meant that there has been $2.2 billion assistance in R&D expenditure in this country. I also draw the attention of Dr Kemp to remarks made by Ian Lowe, a science writer in New Scientist, who said recently in an article:

ANSWER.PARA: is now 1.35 per cent of total economic activity as measured by the gross domestic product. This is the highest figure ever.

It is the highest figure ever achieved in Australia in terms of the amount of money spent in total on R&D. I believe that reflects the success of the government's policies since 1983. It is amazing that the right wing idealogue, the patron of the H.R. Nicholls Society—totally opposed to any government assistance in industry—is running around criticising such a successful program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Did the minister receive formal advice from his own department, the department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, recommending that he not proceed with his ill-conceived plan to merge the CSIRO's marine science division and AIMS on the basis that such a plan would damage Australia's national research effort? Did the minister or the government receive additional representations from Australia's scientific community, the ACTU and the business sector, calling for the planned merger to be abandoned? In light of such overwhelming professional advice and community concern, why did the minister proceed with his plan to destroy the CSIRO's marine science division? Does the minister consider that his actions have jeopardised the government's relations with the scientific community—
—Order! Senator Calvert, your time has expired.
—Well, bad luck!

—Bad luck, Paul. I think I got the gist of Senator Calvert's question, even though he could not fit it in in a minute. I have been waiting for three weeks for Senator Calvert to ask the question, in view of the statements he has been making in Tasmania. I think it reflects the very low priority science has with the opposition that it took Senator Calvert three weeks to get the call from amongst those opposite on a science issue.

PARA.TAB: First of all, Senator Calvert's question referred to my ignoring advice from my department. I think he was referring to a sensational news report on the front page of the Weekend Australian around mid-July claiming that I had ignored advice from my Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. That story was absolutely a beat up. It had got the so-called leaked document absolutely confused.
