The recommendation to me from the department was on an options paper that had been circulated from the Department of Finance that, not only should those two divisions of CSIRO and AIMS be merged, but also the Bureau of Meteorology, the Australian Geological Survey Organisation and a couple of other bodies should all be put into one body. The department recommended that that would be a very unwise combination. I agreed with that. In the same minute, it also said that a more interesting proposal to look at which would have some merit would be the merger that was subsequently discussed and arranged and put out by the government.

However, I said in that minute that that particular combination interested me and that I would discuss it further with the department, and that is what I did. That story was a complete beat-up and factually wrong. When I discussed it with a journalist a few days later, I pointed out to him that any article in which I am described as a long-term veteran of the Labor Party Left in South Australia is obviously a long way out of the gum tree as far as accuracy is concerned. So it was all downhill after that.

In the proposals put forward to cabinet as part of the budget process I recommended that there be an independent inquiry on the marine issue by Professor McKinnon. In 1989 Professor McKinnon produced a report called Oceans of wealth, which has been the best definitive study in the last 15 to 20 years of where we should be going to promote marine and fisheries research in this country. Most of his recommendations and comments are still valid today, if not more valid in view of the fact that Australia is about to declare the exclusive economic zone around our coast, which will be a major resource.

We await Professor McKinnon's report, which will come down about the end of October. All the interested scientific bodies have the right to put their proposals and views to Professor McKinnon. In view of his previous report, I look forward to this report because he is a man of considerable integrity, openness and balanced judgment, as previous reports show. At that stage I look forward to debating Senator Calvert. I only hope in the future that some of the statements he puts out bear a better relation to the facts than some of the scaremongering statements he put out in Tasmania in July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. If the story and the issue were such a beat-up, why were so many members of the scientific community in Australia so upset with the minister? Why was it that his colleague from Tasmania Senator Coates criticised him for his actions in Tasmania? When is he going to discontinue his vendetta against the CSIRO?

—As Senator Collins would say, that question is really like being beaten with a feather. I have made it quite clear from the very beginning that I strongly support CSIRO as a broad based, multi-disciplinary scientific research institution in Australia. I have said that through all of that debate and will continue to do so.

PARA.TAB: I have pointed out that I believe that there is a special case to be made for marine and fisheries research in this country at the Commonwealth level because we have two different statutory authorities dealing with basically the same area, with a now increasing overlap: one is CSIRO and the other is AIMS, and both are excellent bodies. I believe there is a case to see whether we can get a higher focus and a better outcome for marine and fisheries research. I think Tasmania would do very well out of it as well as the rest of Australia. In fact, Senator Calvert would be surprised to know that a lot of people have made comments in favour of a restructuring and a higher focus on marine and fisheries research.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Ian Macdonald asked a question on 6 September relating to the superannuation guarantee charge and how it applied to local government. The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, Mr Howe, has provided me with the following answer.

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of the superannuation guarantee levy, councillors were defined as employees of a council. As explained in the second reading speech for the April 1992 amendments, the word `payment' was replaced with `remuneration' to make it clear that only payments for work done by councillors will be salary or wages. Reimbursements for expenditure incurred, whether paid in advance or after the incurring of the expenditure, are not included. Therefore, it is only those councillors receiving remuneration for work done, not a reimbursement, for a council which is in excess of $450 in any month, who are subject to the levy. This is not inconsistent with the former minister's letter.

The minister responsible for local government issues is aware of the need to clarify some aspects of the legislation in terms of the impact on local government and has written to the Treasurer seeking that clarification.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 September, Senator Panizza asked Senator Richardson, as the minister representing me, what action I intended to take to ensure that Australian Vietnam veterans are compensated on the same basis as American Vietnam veterans, following a report from the US Institute of Medicine—it is part of the National Academy of Science—which completed a comprehensive literature review of some 230 epidemiological studies of the possible health effects of exposure to herbicides. The institute has released a detailed report of the review, which concludes that there is sufficient statistical evidence to suggest an association between herbicide exposure and certain health problems.

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that repatriation legislation in Australia is significantly different from that covering veterans in the United States. The Americans deal with classes of cases. In Australia, the legislation requires that each application for a disability pension be considered on its merits, depending on the individual circumstances of the veteran. The decision as to whether to grant a pension is made by the repatriation commission through its delegates.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs was aware of the impending publication of the United States report and received a pre-publication copy soon after its release. The report itself extends to some 1,000 pages. I have been advised that the research found that there is sufficient statistical evidence to suggest an association between herbicide exposure and five conditions: non-Hodgkin's lymphoma; Hodgkin's disease; soft tissue sarcoma; chloracne; and porphyria cutanea tarda, or PCT.

The repatriation commission has accepted claims from Vietnam veterans for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and soft tissue sarcoma for some time, following earlier research results. Only one claim for chloracne has been recorded so far, and it was accepted. Claims for Hodgkin's disease and PCT have also been accepted previously, although not necessarily because of an association with herbicides.

Since the release of the recent US report, the repatriation commission has taken action by issuing statements of principle and establishing an independent expert medical committee to examine the report. Interim statements of principle on Hodgkin's disease, soft tissue sarcoma, chloracne and PCT have been developed and distributed to the peak ex-service bodies and to repatriation commission delegates. The statements of principle state that claims for disability pension for these diseases will be accepted if the disease is medically diagnosed and the veteran served for 28 or more days in Vietnam. A statement of principle covering non-Hodgkin's lymphoma was already in existence because of previous scientific findings.

Veterans who have previously had claims for these conditions rejected are being contacted and invited to reapply. I remind honourable senators that veterans who suffer from cancer, regardless of whether the cancer was caused by war service, are entitled to have all their medical and hospital costs for cancer paid by the Repatriation Commission.

Professor Robert Maclennan of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research has agreed to chair an independent expert medical committee to examine the report and advise the repatriation commission about other areas in the report which are relevant to Australian Vietnam veterans. The ex-service community is being consulted about the membership of this committee. I assure the Senate that the government will continue to monitor relevant research, both here and overseas, into the health of Vietnam veterans and any possible effects of exposure to herbicide or other chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time on national radio Senator Collins, in his typical coward's fashion, made some disparaging references to me and my representation of Townsville, which is the area I come from. No-one ever takes very much notice of Senator Collins or any member of government because of their deceptions before the election.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is not a personal explanation that Senator Macdonald is giving. I ask you to bring him to order and make him come to the point of his personal explanation.

—I am still waiting to hear the extent of the explanation which is to be offered by Senator Macdonald. Having said that, I observe that the expression `coward' is not one that is viewed favourably by the chair. Would you be ever so kind and withdraw it?
—Certainly, I will withdraw that. Mr Deputy President, I am absolutely positive that the ruling would be correct coming from you, so I will withdraw it unequivocally.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins makes these accusations in a place where he knows that he can never be called upon to be accountable. It is for this reason that I seek to make a personal explanation. Very few people take any notice of what Senator Collins says. I make this personal explanation for the benefit of those few narrow-minded people with a warped mental process who might take notice of Senator Collins.

To suggest that I do not represent the area I come from, North Queensland, is patently false. I will start my personal explanation by declaring an interest. I have a personal financial interest—only very small I might say—in some tourist activities in Townsville. I make that qualification before I start. It really shows the stupidity of Senator Collins's allegations because anything that benefits Townsville benefits me personally. Even I am not silly enough to oppose that!

I have lived in North Queensland for most of my life. My whole life has been devoted to advancing the causes of the areas I come from and North Queensland, in particular. To be insulted by a Johnny-come-lately, a carpetbagger, or a blow-in from the north such as Senator Collins really is a little bit rich.

I have spent an enormous amount of my adult life in groups like the Apex Club of Australia advancing the causes of the north. I have been involved in chambers of commerce in my home town of Ayr, and more recently in the towns of Home Hill, Townsville, Cairns and Mount Isa. I have been involved in the Burdekin Shire Council, the North Queensland Local Government Association, the North Queensland Games Foundation and many other organisations of a North Queensland character that all exist to advance the cause of the north. In the three years that I have been in parliament my whole time has been devoted to advancing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With the best will in the world—and we are a very tolerant and patient mob on this side of the chamber—this is not really a personal explanation, and every senator in the chamber knows it. Senator Macdonald has had his little trip around the oval about his local obligations or whatever they might be in Townsville and how much he has given to the local community. We all understand this. This is not a personal explanation; it is an abuse of Senate's procedures and I ask you to call him to order and sit him down.

—On the point of order: it was suggested that I did not represent the interests of the area I come from. I am simply indicating how that is not correct and I am seeking the opportunity of putting on the record, after being blasphemed by Senator Collins, just how that is wrong.

—Senator Macdonald, as I understand it, your exception is that Senator Collins implied that you were having but a flirtatious excursion into the north of Queensland and were therefore not representing your electorate properly. I think you have probably, to the satisfaction of most on your side, satisfied the constituents that that is not the case. Would you be kind enough to finish in the next 30 seconds?

—I just want to mention that, had we won the election, we would have had a new university in Cairns; we would have had better trade with Asia; we would have had a new look at Torres Strait government; we would have had better transport in the Cape; we would have had a better deal for the sugar farmers; we would have had a substantial boost to tourism; JCU would have expanded; Magnetic Keys would have got going; we would have dredged Karumba—
—Senator Ian Macdonald, you really are trespassing well past a personal explanation.

—I will sit down, but I want to make the point that all of those issues have had attention drawn to them because of my representation of the north—the kind of representation which Senator Reynolds, Mr Lindsay and Mr Dodds from the Labor Party have never been able to bring to this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day relating to rental of premises by ANAO.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that Senator McMullan did not remain in the chamber, because it was quite apparent that the things that passed for answers were totally unsatisfactory and did not answer the main point. The proposed lease for that building is meant to commence on 23 September—that is, this month—which is three weeks away. Yet the lease has not yet been signed. That lease needs to be renegotiated to be in accordance with the standards of the Department of Finance. The Department of Finance says that a one per cent increment in the rental is reasonable. The Labor Party is holding the Commonwealth to ransom for nine per cent. The difference is $34 million over 15 years.

PARA.TAB: Several points need to be made. Senator McMullan pretended to find evidence that it was a commercial lease. He brought out the Baillieu Knight Frank report, which was released after the event. That report, which is far from supportive of his proposition, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The overall lease framework is at variance to the general practice of the Commonwealth, in that the Commonwealth generally enters into leases that reflect gross market rents reviewable every two years with the Commonwealth being responsible for increases in statutory outgoings only in addition to normal tenant responsibilities.
It further says that it is presumed to be a binding rental and therefore, with respect to the ANAO options, the report states:
We recommend that relevant advice be sought from the legal profession.

That is hardly a backup for the minister's assertion that it is a commercial lease. As I pointed out, at the time of negotiating this agreement for lease and at the time of signing the agreement for lease, three senators in this chamber were on the board of the company which benefits from the lease. The shareholders are the Australian Labor Party, as set out in the return to the Australian Securities Commission, filed by John Curtin House Ltd, where it says that the Labor Party provides the members of the company. It further says that John Curtin House Ltd has guaranteed, in an unending way, the ALP election fund campaign account and the ALP national secretariat operating account. That is in its 1991 accounts.

PARA.TAB: In its 1992 accounts it omits to mention the ALP election fund, but it does mention the ALP national secretariat operating account, which can fund the campaign fund. So in its own documents it is telling us that the money that is paid by way of the Commonwealth for rent for this building is being used to pay for the Labor Party's election expenses.

It also shows us in the annual accounts that the Labor Party has entered into a mortgage with the Macquarie Bank. The mortgage was entered into on exactly the same day as the agreement for lease was entered into. The size of the mortgage is $50 million. As at 31 December 1992, the Labor Party had already drawn down $14 million against the $50 million. We will see when the accounts are lodged on 31 December 1993 how much of the money was brought down for the building which ranges in value between $17 million and $22 million, and how much was brought down for the guarantee on the Labor Party's campaign fund.

The point is that this lease has yet to be signed. It is quite clear that this is not a commercial lease. It is tainted by the fact that sitting members of the Labor Party in this Senate are on the board of the company that benefits from this lease. It is a funnel for money from the Commonwealth to the Australian Labor Party. We are talking about $34 million—the Department of Finance has said that over the course of the lease it will provide $45 million, but the Labor Party will receive $80 million. In other words, the Department of Finance says, `This is a shonky lease'. How can Senator McMullan justify getting the Australian Government Solicitor to sign this lease for and on behalf of the Commonwealth when it is clearly not at arm's length and not a commercial lease, and is designed simply to be a funnel for money to the Australian Labor Party to fund its campaigns? The Labor Party now has access to millions of dollars which do not need disclosure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague Senator Bishop in her motion to take note of the answer to a question relating to ANAO evidence on rental of premises. Last Thursday, in the estimates committee hearing when this matter was being discussed, evidence was tendered from the Attorney-General's Department that it received advice from the Australian Property Group. That document read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . APG negotiated the lease clause by clause and achieved amendments which brought the document in line with all significant terms and conditions of the Commonwealth's Standard Expenditure Lease.

I question whether in fact that is so. There are two very unusual features with regard to this lease which, as my colleague points out, has not been signed yet: first of all, the length of the lease; and, secondly, the escalation clause.

PARA.TAB: With regard to length, the advice I have received from the commercial area here in the city is that the Australian Property Group has normally signed leases with a length of 10 years. They sometimes have an option to go another five, but the critical point is that the normal arrangement is 10 years. It is my understanding that one would have to go back a very long way before one would find a 15-year lease, but in this case we have a 15-year lease rather than 10.

In addition, we have the escalation clause. This agreement was negotiated—the original agreement was signed in April last year—at a time when the Australian property market had already crashed substantially throughout the nation. The winds of that change had even reached this city, and its property market was turning down. In spite of that, we have a clause in the agreement for nine per cent per annum for the 15-year period. As my colleague pointed out, that is against what the Department of Finance advised would have been fair and proper—one per cent—or what the commercial world would have said, which is that it should have been reviewed every two or three years. Marrying those two things together—the 15 years and the nine per cent escalation per annum—we have this extraordinary combination which gives the owner of the property the chance to make substantial gain—

TALK.START.PARA: —And who is the owner?

—Who is the owner? The Labor Party, and it stands to make an extraordinary gain relative to what is a fair and proper commercial arrangement here in this city. I would have thought that the government would have been particularly careful in dealing with this building and with tenants, particularly in view of the fact, as I understand it, that the person who used to be the head of the Australian Property Group moved over to become manager of Lend Lease operations here in this city—
—Which built the building.

—Which built the building. I support my colleague and I believe that the government should renegotiate this lease and put it on a fair and commercial basis for the taxpayers of Australia before the matter is signed.

—Senator McMullan, in answering Senator Bishop's question, said that previous investigations had found no scandal and no malpractice. Let me state that with the passage of time the leasing of Centenary House, owned by the Labor Party, is fast acquiring a stench of intrigue and corruption. On 7 November 1991, nearly two years ago, at a hearing into the ill-fated Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, the then secretary of the ALP, Mr Bob Hogg, was asked whether there were any arrangements for pre-renting of the projected building—that is, Centenary House—and the answer he gave was no. Yet, on 1 November 1991, six days before, Mr Robert Ireland of the Australian Property Group wrote to the Australian Valuation Office stating that the audit office had expressed an interest in relocating to the ALP headquarters building.
—That is not a contract.

—Senator Schacht should just listen. Not until six months later did the audit office know that the building being looked at was owned by the ALP. It thought it was owned by Lend Lease; it was called the Lend Lease site. In that letter from Mr Ireland, all the details of the lease were provided.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Property Group pointed out that the agreement represented `a major departure from the conventional gross lease arrangement', and all details were provided on 1 November 1991. Yet Mr Hogg, the then secretary of the Australian Labor Party, said `no' when asked whether any pre-renting arrangements had been entered into.

On 15 January 1992 I issued a press release exposing this outrageous deal and offered to supply documents supporting my claim. It is fascinating; this is where the stench starts to come in and questions have to be asked. The sorts of questions that have to be asked are: Why did the person in the Australian Property Group who negotiated the agreement take voluntary redundancy within a short period? Why did he ring my office and pretend that he was a private citizen and seek further details on the information that I had? Why did he do that? Is it a fact that the person who negotiated for Lend Lease was previously a director of the Australian Property Group and entered into that detailed negotiation? Is it a fact that the major person in the Australian Valuation Office who had to verify this is a member of the Labor Club and allegedly a member of the Australian Labor Party?

The minister, in his response, quotes Baillieu Knight Frank. Its report stated that the evaluation of the escalations was not unreasonable based on the past eight or nine years escalation that had occurred in the ACT at a time which tracked the very high inflation rate that was brought upon this country by the Labor Party before the recession we had to have.

Let me say very quickly, because Senator Schacht is trying to stop me from speaking, which is understandable, that Senator McMullan also mentioned—he did this to bring a red herring into the debate—that McEwen House, which has been rented for donkey's years to some government department, has had average escalations of around nine per cent. Let me put on the record that the current rental at McEwen House, which I have just checked, is $50 per square metre below the market rate. One of the major complaints we have about this lease agreement is that it is not in accordance with the market and it is not in accordance with the standard practice for government departments leasing buildings from the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues on the motion to take note of the answer from Senator McMullan. What we have here is a major scandal—nothing more, nothing less—involving taxpayers' funds and in which the government and its officers have been directly involved.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the facts which have come out today. It is clear, as Senator McMullan said, that this has been debated before, but the Senate estimates committee on 2 September, I suggest to the Senate, brought forth a major new fact; that is, the Department of Finance was exceedingly unhappy with the terms of this lease, a lease which had been negotiated by the Department of Administrative Services. What is new about this debate is that now we have a major government department bringing to the attention of the public that it has very real concerns about this particular contract. Senator Bishop, Senator Parer and a number of my colleagues on this side have been quite right in pointing out these concerns.

The facts are these: when this contract is signed it will give a capital profit to the Labor Party of $15 million of taxpayers' money without any real basis for it except that an excessively generous contract has been signed. Above that, over 15 years the Labor Party will collect from the taxpayer some $80 million in rent. What is the profit on that? We would suspect it would be tens of millions of dollars plus a capital profit of $15 million. I put it to the Senate that this is a major scandal.

The other fact which has been made clear today, and which Senator Bishop has brought to the attention of the chamber, is that this lease has not yet been signed. The actual contract remains for the signatures to be put onto it. I wonder which officers will, in the light of the evidence that has come forth today, be prepared to put their names on such a document.

I believe there is only one way to deal with this matter; that is, for Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, who allegedly sets the standards of his government, to indicate that in the light of the evidence that has been brought forth by the Department of Finance this contract will be renegotiated and that a fairer rent, a rent far more in line with market rates, will be struck and accepted by the Labor Party. I believe that is what Mr Keating now has to do. I would urge my colleagues, the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to think very seriously about whether this is not a matter which must be referred to a Senate standing committee for a full and proper investigation.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that this can be avoided by the Prime Minister—in the light of the evidence which has been brought forth at the Senate estimates committee—indicating that, in view of the views of the Department of Finance, the government will allow this contract to be renegotiated. I believe that that is the only way that this scandal which is gathering pace and gathering increasing public interest will be laid to rest. If that is not done, it is a matter for this Senate to take action so that this Labor Party will not, once again, rip off the taxpayers of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This lease is a shonky lease organised by a shonky government. It goes to the whole heart of democracy in Australia where a political party that happens to be the government of the nation can manipulate the public purse in such a way that it funds itself for political purposes for the next many decades.

PARA.TAB: As my colleagues have pointed out, it is very seldom that one gets a lease which has an escalation clause of nine per cent when inflation is running at one per cent or even three per cent, as is envisaged in this year's budget papers. It is normal for a lease to have an escalation clause in line with the CPI; it is not normal to have a lease which has an escalation clause nine times greater than the CPI—the cost of living increases—in any particular year. That is a national scandal.

This has been raised before by my colleagues, Senator Parer and Senator Bishop. It is a matter that the government keeps trying to push under the carpet. The government hopes that it will go away; it has no response to it—no genuine response at all. It is a shonky deal and it goes right to the heart of putting taxpayers' moneys in the Labor Party's pockets so that it may continue working at election time.

It is a major national scandal. I agree with my colleague Senator Kemp that it requires further investigation. If the Labor Party does not have the decency to renegotiate this lease of its own accord, it should be forced to do so by public pressure—by people calling for that lease to be looked at again. If the Labor Party still will not do that, this parliament and this chamber should look very seriously at instituting some form of inquiry into it. It smacks of all the worst sorts of government excesses in putting money into the pockets of one political party. I urge the Senate and the people of Australia to consider this matter very carefully and to bring about some redress from this scandalous situation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot this day, relating to Airspace Rules.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer given by the minister was quite misleading; there have been huge changes in Australian air traffic procedures. I say at the outset that the direction of those changes has been quite laudable—many of them are worth while—the real criticism is that they have been administered in a terribly incompetent way.

PARA.TAB: Broadly, what the Civil Aviation Authority did was to set out to change the Australian air traffic control procedures to the international ICAO standards. One would have no argument about that. The trouble is that the CAA did introduce a number of procedures, like the MTAF and CTAF procedures, which do not exist under the ICAO system. There is a great deal of concern in the aviation community about the changes and the way they have been administered. The big difficulty is that there is not a simple vehicle by which pilots can express their concern to either the CAA or the minister on this matter.

It is very wrong for the minister to hang it all on—to use his own description—an idiosyncratic Dick Smith. Mr Smith has taken a leading role in pointing up some of the problems with the air traffic control procedures, but in no sense is he alone in his position. That was just another cheap shot from a master of cheap shots in the form of Senator Collins.

I would like to say something briefly about the administration of air traffic control procedures. Pilots do things in a predictable way. They learn procedures and they apply them automatically so that everyone does the same thing in a predictable way in all circumstances. Therefore, there is an ingrained reflex pattern of behaviour. If procedures are going to be changed, it follows that there must be a really good educational program to introduce the new practices. That simply has not occurred in all cases. It certainly has occurred in the airlines, which have training schools and training captains. But something like 70 or 80 per cent of the pilots in Australia are private pilots who fly infrequently and do not have the benefit of those training schools. There has been no effective education of those pilots because of the cost-cutting of this government.

Once, pilots were taught to always get a weather forecast before they flew cross country. Now they cannot get a weather forecast unless they own a fax machine and have a PIN number. They have to dial in a code. They have to have all the facilities of a sophisticated office to get a weather forecast. When they get it, it is in code and it means nothing to the average person. The other thing that we always taught pilots was to put in a flight plan. Now a flight plan cannot be filed very readily. People are discouraged from doing so. Again, there is a need to have a fax machine and all sorts of elaborate things.

I think the greatest difficulty for the majority of pilots is the fact that the briefing offices have now gone. Once upon a time, if at the weekend I wanted to fly to Rockhampton, for example, and I had not flown for some months, I could go into a briefing office at Archerfield and say, `I'm going up to Rockhampton. What do I need to know about getting into Bundaberg for fuel and into the control zone at Rockhampton?'. In 30 seconds someone would refresh my memory as to what was required. None of those facilities are available for private pilots today. The consequence of all this is that there has been a great reduction in the assurance of air safety in Australia. That is the point that the pilot community is concerned about.

I did not rise to speak about the changes in air traffic procedures but to answer the very unfortunate charge that Senator Collins, in his sneaky way, made about my declaring an interest in aviation. He has made that charge about me twice in this chamber. The first time I let it go. Characteristically, he did it on a broadcast day. The inference was that there is something dishonest about my involvement in aviation.I want to put that on the record straight away.

My interest in aviation is as someone who has been a pilot for 30 years. I have owned, operated and maintained my own aircraft in a purely private capacity for about 25 years. As such, I know far more about the administration of aviation and the huge costs of maladministration than Senator Collins will ever know. I am a user of air services. I do not benefit from them in any way at all. I make a very large financial contribution for the few meagre hours that I am in the air.

I very much resent Senator Collins getting up and smearing me by implying that there is something dishonest or underhand in my taking an interest in aviation. My interest is in seeing safe, efficient, relevant and affordable systems of aviation administration in Australia. Such a goal will never be achieved while we have Senator Collins as an interfering minister in charge of the department.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Chris Evans this day, relating to recovery of doctors fees.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with the disgraceful failure of the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, to detail many facts in the attack he made—the quite unfair slander, in effect—on a decent and honourable Nowra doctor. In particular, I want to contest his allegation that this was a pay or kill proposition. I find it appalling that Senator Richardson should have failed to mention that the client of the doctor had failed to pay his bill for a period of two years. Senator Richardson did not mention this in alleging that the doctor had behaved badly.

PARA.TAB: There were 10 requests for payment of one kind or another that were not responded to by this patient. Yet Senator Richardson was prepared to endorse the fact that Mr Knott, the honourable member for Gilmore, described this doctor as not being a fit and proper person to be a doctor. At least, he certainly did not deny what the honourable member for Gilmore had said and appeared to endorse his remarks.

Most important of all, all the patient had to do was to take or post one of the 10 bills he had received for this same service over two years to the Medicare office, get a cheque made out to the doctor and give it to the doctor in satisfaction of the account. He did not have to pay a cracker himself. All he had to do was get off his backside, go to the Medicare office and provide a Medicare—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or post it.

—Or post it—he did not even have to go to the office. This would have been in satisfaction of the account in circumstances where patients have financial problems. This doctor in Nowra—whom I know because he was my anaesthetist when I had a little problem of a hernia some years ago—has invariably accepted a Medicare cheque as payment for patients who have approached him and said, `We have financial difficulties in meeting this bill'.

PARA.TAB: In fact, this is what eventually happened. Ten bills and two years after the event, he eventually got off his backside to present a Medicare cheque. Yet here we have Senator Richardson saying that this is a pay or kill situation. This is a disgrace. This patient regarded it as a discretionary bill: if he did not need to pay it, he did not choose to pay it. Frankly, if he does not really need surgery in future—if it is discretionary—I would imagine that, surely, the doctor should be entitled to make the offsetting discretionary choice that he is not available unless his bill is paid.

The key point is that this patient never, ever sought relief or explained any difficulty either in paying his bill or getting off his backside to get the Medicare rebate cheque and send it to the doctor. There is no suggestion of service not being provided in an emergency. However, the doctor has in fact said that he will rephrase his letter in future to soften the fractured sensibilities of people like Senator Richardson.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators are reminded that the 90th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference is to be held at Parliament House next week. Pre-conference meetings are scheduled to be held from 10 to 12 September 1993, and the conference will be conducted from 13 to 18 September 1993. More than 1,000 parliamentarians and others from almost 100 national groups have indicated that they will travel to Canberra to attend the conference. Arrangements have been made for services to be provided for the delegates in Parliament House from 9 September.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators who are not members of the Australian delegation and who wish to have opportunities to meet with our international parliamentary colleagues are welcome to observe the conference proceedings and to participate in the social functions of the conference. Invitations to attend these functions have been distributed to honourable senators by the conference secretariat. Identity badges for honourable senators intending to be involved in the conference will be available from the registration and information desk.

Seating for the concert will be available from the accompanying persons, recreation and touring desk, which will also be located in the marble foyer. The desks will operate from 3 p.m. to 6.30 p.m. on Thursday, 9 September, and thereafter daily until 18 September from 8 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. Any help that honourable senators could extend to our international visitors in making them feel welcome will be appreciated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 30 June 1994:
An examination of the current methods of means testing pensioners and veterans and the development of options for means testing in the future:

PARA.TAB: (a)taking into account the following:

TAB.TAB: (i)the impact of Australia's ageing population on age pension and veterans' service pension outlays,
(ii)the diversity of investment options that are available to pensioners and veterans,
(iii)the Government's stated policy of encouraging greater self-reliance in retirement,
(iv)the objectives of the relevant programs in the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs,
(v)the need to increase national savings, and
(vi)the interrelationship between income tests, assets tests and relevant taxation provisions; and

PARA.TAB: (b)including findings and recommendations on:

TAB.TAB: (i)the identification of any inequities, inconsistencies and inefficiencies in the current methods of means testing pensioners and veterans,
(ii)how any identified inequities, inconsistencies and inefficiencies can be overcome, and
(iii)what options should be considered for a more equitable and cost-effective system of means testing pensioners and veterans to the year 2000 and beyond.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)That in conducting its inquiry the committee, not later than 60 days after the passing of this resolution, commission a panel of at least 4 independent experts, to be chosen by unanimous resolution of the committee, to prepare reports on the matters referred to the committee under paragraph (1).
(3)That the panel, to be called the Community Affairs Committee Panel of Independent Experts on Means Testing, be comprised of at least 4 experts as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)at least 2 are to have extensive working expertise and experience with, and be representative of, pensioners' and veterans' interests;
(b)at least 1 is to have extensive working expertise and experience in the types of investments typically accessed by pensioners and veterans; and
(c)at least 1 is to have extensive working expertise and experience in taxation and superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)That in the absence of agreement to the appointment of the members of the panel, duly notified to the President, the Senate shall determine who shall be appointed as members of the panel.
(5)That:

PARA.TAB: (a)the committee, by unanimous resolution, appoint 1 of the experts to be chair of the panel;
(b)the panel convene as soon as possible after the appointment of a chair and draw up procedures for the preparation of any report on the matters referred to in paragraph (1);
(c)the procedures referred to in subparagraph (b), and any revised procedures, be approved by the committee by unanimous resolution within 30 days of the committee receiving them from the panel; and
(d)in the absence of agreement on any matter under this paragraph, duly notified to the President, the Senate shall determine the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: (6)That for the purposes of preparing any report the panel of experts may ask any person for information which the committee has power to ask for, and if the information is withheld the panel shall report that to the committee and the committee shall consider whether to exercise its powers to order the production of that information.

(7)That the question whether to make an order for the production of the information referred to in paragraph (6) shall be decided by unanimous resolution of the committee, and in the event of disagreement, duly notified to the President, shall be determined by the Senate.
(8)That any report of the panel be incorporated in the final report of the committee and presented to the Senate within 2 weeks of its receipt by the committee.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 7 September, from Senator Boswell:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The government's onerous budget decision to increase excise on petrol and diesel leading to greatly increased costs for road and rail transport, harm to Australia's rural and other export industries, substantially increased weekly costs of living for families and the continuing reduction of excise spent on roads.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, before you proceed, I understand that, by agreement of the whips, the first two speakers shall have allotted unto them 10 minutes each; the third, five minutes; the fourth, 10 minutes; the fifth, five minutes; and the last two, 10 minutes each.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The government's onerous budget decision to increase excise on petrol and diesel leading to greatly increased costs for road and rail transport, harm to Australia's rural and other export industries, substantially increased weekly costs of living for families and the continuing reduction of excise spent on roads.

I have moved this urgency motion on the last day of the sitting fortnight because I believe this is one of the most important issues facing Australia. In his budget speech, the Treasurer, John Dawkins, said:

PARA.TAB: The primary objective of this budget is jobs: jobs in the short term by providing a further fiscal stimulus to the economy this year—to sustain Australia's economic growth until the motor of world recovery kicks in. And jobs in the medium and longer term by boosting the capacity of Australian business to expand production on a world-competitive basis.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the rock which the budget was built upon. That budget included an increase in excise of $1.2 billion; it added $175 million a year in excise to the road transport scheme and $20 million to the rail scheme. That will have a tremendous impact on the lack of jobs, with no jobs coming through, as the increased cost of fuel bites into our export commodities and our overseas debt.

PARA.TAB: If we were in government, the transport industry would now be $2.2 billion better off. That would be the benefit to the transport industry. The $2.2 billion is made up of the removal of the excise and the removal of sales tax from the purchase price of transport such as prime movers and trailers, as well as spare parts, batteries and tyres. Overall, the industry would be better off by $2.4 billion a year. Instead of that, we get a 19 per cent increase in excise rates of up to 29c a litre. That is no way to encourage jobs or growth. It is the absolute direct opposite of what the government has said and what it has based its budget upon.

The increase in excise will impact heavily on primary industry in the more remote states. Senator Collins, in answer to a question that I asked him the other day, admitted that the increased cost on transport would be between 2.5 per cent and five per cent. That would be an average increase around Australia. The increase could be higher than that for the more remote areas. It has been estimated that the extra cost amounts to about $3 per week on a trolley of groceries. For the remote states like the Northern Territory, which Senator Collins represents, and Western Australia, represented by the two Green senators, the increase will be about 25 per cent. This increase in excise will totally depend on the reaction that the Greens from Western Australia and Senator Harradine have. I do not know how Senator Harradine will respond; I have not discussed it with him. In normal circumstances, Senator Harradine will stand up very firmly for the State of Tasmania. This increase in excise will be determined by the actions taken by the Green senators. If they support the government's budget, they will be inflicting a heavier cost on their electors in Western Australia who will pay a higher proportion of road transport costs on the products that they receive into Western Australia and on the exports that they transfer to the east of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they vote with us, the Democrats are irrelevant.

—That is one of the points which the Greens must now consider. The Democrats have backed this budget and they are going to support the government's increase of $175 million a year on the diesel fuel excise and another $100 million a year on sales tax. The cost to the average road owner operator will increase by $6,000 for diesel fuel and by $4,000 in extra sales tax.

PARA.TAB: Seventy-five per cent of all freight is moved nationally by road. The road transport industry employs 177,000 people and road transport is used at every stage—from the farm to the supermarket. It is really the only mode of transport that takes goods from the farm gate. The goods may then go by rail but are then transferred to another road operator into the factory or wherever. The recession has increased competition and has reduced road transport's average profit margin by between four and two per cent. The short haul sector will have to increase its rates by up to three or four per cent and the long haul sector will have to increase its rates by something like five per cent.

The government's increased costs cannot be absorbed by the industry. Freight rates will have to be increased. The road transport industry will have to take cost cutting measures on board. That will affect the environment, safety, and employment; all the social impacts will be there. The climate is not right for freight cuts. We will have to increase the cost of freight and that will have an impact on our $60 billion worth of exports. Agriculture earns $17.4 billion; mining earns $20.1 billion; and the manufacturing sector earns $17.6 billion; and they are all large users of transport.

It seems to me that the Labor Party and the Labor government do not understand what competition is about. We have to be out there competing in world markets. We have heard ad nauseam from the various ministers of the government how we have to become internationally competitive and how we have to meet competition in world markets. But I continually say that it is so difficult when the government keeps increasing the costs to our rural exporters, our primary industry and our mining industries, and now it is increasing costs to the 700 small businesses that have broken through the market and are exporting.

SPEECH.PARA: When the government keeps increasing costs, it almost reaches the stage of impossibility.

PARA.TAB: I want to compare taxes in Australia with those in the United States. In Australia the government charges on fuel are 17c per litre; in the US they are only 4c per litre; and in Canada they are 12c per litre. For long haul trucks, US government taxes are only 10c a litre; they are 17c a litre in Canada. But in Australia the tax amounts to 27c a kilometre. That makes us terribly inefficient and anti-competitive. When the order book comes around to be filled, it puts Australia in a position where we find it so much more difficult to compete and therefore we lose market share.

One of the reasons we have one million unemployed is that government charges—this is only one aspect of government charges but a very significant one—exact $1.2 billion in excise from our overseas exporters and primary industry. It is now very difficult for the government, having made its mind up and the Democrats having backed the government's decision—(Time expired).

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I always pay careful attention to what Senator Boswell says since small business is one area of my portfolio. He is one of the very few people on the other side of the house who is genuinely interested in small business activities and is quite willing to discuss the subject.
—Come on!

—No, it is true. Senator Boswell approaches me and raises issues about small business that are thoughtful and constructive. I might not always agree with them but he certainly raises them. The other day he raised the issue of the newsagency arrangements in Queensland—a very reasonable issue. I always listen to Senator Boswell's remarks, particularly those relating to small business. However, this motion is not about small business; it is about a political activity in this chamber to create public debate on the present budget. Therefore, I do not think I can give it the same credibility as a small business issue since it is part of a political campaign by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: What I find interesting about Senator Boswell's motion which seeks to condemn the government's onerous budget decision to increase excise on petrol and diesel, et cetera, is that in 1979-80 the coalition brought about the biggest increase in excise on petrol in Australia when it decided to go to world parity pricing. That was the biggest increase in petrol prices for the consumer, whether they be domestic or applying to industry, in Australia's history. Some people may say that there were rational economic reasons why that decision had to be taken to go to world parity pricing, but it amounted to the biggest cost increase on the transport industry in living memory. The coalition took that decision. I would have liked to have seen some comment in Senator Boswell's speech today about how that fitted into the picture and hurt the transport industry in Australia.

Senator Boswell talked about international competitiveness. Even with these increases announced in the budget, I would point out that Australia had the third lowest petrol prices of the OECD countries before the budget. We still have the cheapest petrol of our major competitors in the marketplace. So even with these increases, in terms of international competitiveness we are still maintaining our advantage.

I also want to point out to the opposition that in 1981-82 excise revenue was 14.6 per cent of total Commonwealth revenue. In 1992-93 that figure declined to 10 per cent of Commonwealth revenue. So even with this increase, there has been a substantial decline in excise in Australia as a proportion of the tax revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, what does that tell you?

—I know that shortly Senator Crane will blame the trade unions for this increase. The usual line that we hear from him is that it is all the fault of the trade unions—it is Bill Kelty's fault or the fault of someone else in the trade union movement. He will soon bring into the argument that it is the fault of the BLF or something on those lines. To Senator Crane every issue in this place is a conspiracy by the trade union movement. I do not know whether he is speaking in this debate, but if he does take part I would bet my last dollar, or even the last litre of petrol in my tank, that he would be blaming the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell, using some colourful language, said that these increases will mean the end of Australian industry. He did not claim that they would lead to the end of motherhood and christianity, but he nearly went as close as saying that. If it is a political plug that Senator Boswell wants to make—we all accept in this place that from time to time we are all guilty of gilding the lily to sell our political statement—I would point out that in regard to the impact on the CPI, the initial 3c per litre increase in excise will add around one-fifth of a percentage point to that index. When all the excise increases have been phased in, the total impact on the CPI will be around one-half of a percentage point. That is a very modest increase on the CPI over a number of years. It is nothing compared to the increase in the CPI caused by the former coalition government in 1979-80 when it went to world parity pricing. There was a much bigger increase at that time.

In the whole period of this government, the average inflation rate has always been below the average inflation rate of the Fraser government. One of the reasons is that within a year the coalition jacked up world parity for everybody in Australia. The coalition should not bleat in this chamber about its concern for the impact on the transport industry. In 1979-80 the coalition gave it the biggest hit in the back of the head that it has had in the postwar period by going to world parity prices.

I conclude by commenting on the general political context of this motion. We are now seeing in the Senate an attempt by the opposition to recover from the extraordinary tactical mistake made by Dr Hewson the day after the budget when he said, `We will oppose carte blanche every tax increase and every tax revenue measure in the budget'. That was the biggest tactical mistake that the opposition dealt itself from the pack of cards. It took away any bargaining position. Much to its angst now, all the opposition did was pass the bargaining chip down to where the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine sit. They received the bargaining chip and the ability to say, `We'll discuss this with the government', because they knew that the opposition was implacably opposed. Dr Hewson again showed abysmal political perspicacity by saying carte blanche, `We oppose everything'. The opposition was out the back door, out of the loop in terms of having any influence.

If the coalition continues to take that role, all it will do is make the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine very thankful for the coalition's political stupidity. That is what those opposite have done. This motion is an attempt to pull a political stunt in here today.

Dr Hewson, with all his stupid political acumen—and it is stupid—helps us every time. Come the next election, with Dr Hewson as Leader of the Opposition, we will have a great chance of winning. He gave us the election victory last time because of his stupidity and lack of political skill, and is at it again. The real problem for Dr Hewson is not only his own lack of political skill but the lack of political skill in the rest of the opposition.

I said in a debate a week or so ago that for the first time in the history of this parliament, in nearly 93 years, no opposition member in the Senate from a non-Labor Party has had ministerial experience. For the whole history of federation there has always been someone opposite who has had ministerial experience, even when in opposition. There have been people who have had previous ministerial experience who know about the parameters and responsibility of government.

No current members of the opposition in the Senate have any ministerial experience. As a result they have become the permanent opposition and have an oppositionist mentality. We in the Labor Party know what it is like because we were in that position in the 1950s and 1960s. But we now understand the responsibility of government. Those opposite have slipped into the disease of the Labor Party of the 1950s and 1960s—permanent opposition. The decision they took to oppose all the revenue measures in the budget indicates that, and they will pay a big penalty for it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather interesting that the opposition invokes the workings of the market so much in debate and in its rhetoric, and yet when we are dealing with a question that pre-eminently concerns the user pays principle—the underpinnings by which the market gives the correct price signals to those who consume goods and services—those opposite jump up and down and complain.

PARA.TAB: Half the world's leading Nobel prize winning scientists have said that we face an urgent problem with respect to greenhouse gas emissions. Australia is one of the worst polluters in the world with respect to greenhouse gases on a per capita basis. The use of motor vehicle fuels on the road probably costs roughly $1,000 at least per motor vehicle in deaths and accidents.

We have the problem of lead in children—a problem which has been raised particularly in recent days but which has been around for 20 years. Some statistics suggest that 44 per cent of children in the under-four age group may be suffering some mental impairment because of lead in petrol. These are all significant costs on the community which are directly related to the use of petroleum and are clearly not being represented in the price structure of petroleum. Therefore, they represent distortions in the market. People are not getting the right price signals and they are not making the right judgments regarding the use of fuel. Therefore, they are causing these things to be imposed on their fellow citizens.

Having said all that, I point out that in our Getting to Work document, which we launched in July last year, we set out a much better alternative to what the government has proposed. This afternoon we are not debating our budget, but the government's budget—a budget that has been moderately amended through a process of consultation and negotiation. It is not our preferred budget, but it does go some way towards addressing this problem of putting in the right price signals.

However, there are still two basic problems with what the government is doing, and to that extent we agree with the motion. First is the issue of equity, particularly in respect of country people. Undoubtedly, this increase in price, which the government has modified to some extent, still impacts adversely on country people. My colleague Senator Woodley will address that issue.

Secondly, because this increase in price is going into general revenue, my primary concern is that it is not being used to address those very significant problems that I alluded to earlier. I refer to the problem of greenhouse gases, looking to ways of addressing the excessive use of fuel in this country and the development of alternative fuels, increased expenditure in areas, such as rail transport and so on, which would address that problem, and solutions to the problem of getting the lead out of petrol.

Recently Senator Schacht answered a supplementary question of mine in which he said that by the year 2002 lead would go out of petrol simply because there would be so few cars using lead in petrol that it would be uneconomic to the petrol companies to market leaded petrol. He admitted that the government's lead strategy is simply falling into line with the petrol companies.

We believe that there is a solution to this problem, which is to use alcohol as a supplement to petrol. That would allow us within a period of two years to get lead out of petrol and make a fuel alternative available to those people who continue to drive cars needing octane enhanced fuel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) moving an amendment to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment substitutes all the words after `export industries' with the words `without proper compensation and without adequately addressing the serious problem of lead in fuel'.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to extend the debate at all, but I want to reiterate the point that our concern is no longer so much the increase in the price of petrol. The minister has said that, compared with 24 OECD countries, Australia has the third lowest priced petrol and the second lowest rate of excise. We are one of the worse polluters when it comes to greenhouse gas emissions and we have one of the highest levels of lead in our fuel.

We agree with the price increase. However, the questions of equity, getting lead out of fuel and getting us to use less fuel, have to be addressed. So the amendment goes to the heart of that matter. It criticises the government for specifically not compensating those people, and it addresses the issue which was raised by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Collins said, this is just a revenue raiser.
—I agree. To that extent, we agree with the opposition that this money should not go into general revenue. It should be targeted specifically into these areas so that there is proper compensation—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understand that there is a time limit on this debate. As I understand it, Senator Coulter is now seeking an extra five minutes. Is that an extra five minutes? Does it come off any other speaker? Is this contrary to the spirit of the agreement?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Senator Coulter is within the standing orders to take five minutes to speak on the motion that he has moved. That time will not come off the time of any other speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have really completed what I wanted to say. I hope that the suspension of standing orders and my amendment will be supported.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment (by Senator Coulter) proposed:
Omit all words after "export industries",
substitute:
"without proper compensation and without adequately addressing the serious problem of lead in fuel".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to support the urgency motion moved by my colleague from Queensland Senator Boswell. It relates to the increase in the diesel fuel levy. While the debate about the increase in wine tax has been raging around Australia since the budget was brought down—and I believe that debate should have raged—the massive increase in the diesel fuel levy has been somewhat neglected.

PARA.TAB: The increase in the wine tax amounted to $70 million in 1993-94 and $95 million in a full year. But the diesel fuel intake is $441 million, which is an increase of 16.7 per cent. Added to that is the $100 million for the administration of the rebate scheme—I will come back to that later—less the $95 million increase in the overall rebate. On a quick calculation, it appears that the government will take at least $350 million to $360 million out of the diesel fuel rebate around Australia in one financial year. This adds a massive burden to the transport industry and to primary industry. Those like me, who live in rural and remote areas of Australia, will understand that. No matter what we do, diesel fuel impinges on every aspect of life. A third of the cars these days—that figure might be a bit high; perhaps it is 15 to 20 per cent—run on diesel fuel. All four-wheel-drive vehicles run on diesel fuel.

I suppose one could dodge paying the increase in sales tax on wine. I have no trouble in dodging the increase in sales tax on wine because I do not drink wine at all. For those people who drink wine and want to dodge the tax increase, the solution is to either reduce their intake or cut it out entirely.

The situation in relation to diesel fuel is totally different. If we want Australia to keep moving—Australia moves on its transport and is financed by rural and mining production—we have to have diesel and we have to pay the increases. A publication I have from the Road Transport Forum states:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional excessive taxes are proposed for people consuming items transported by road in the 1993/94 Commonwealth Budget. These increases involve
*an additional 5c per litre on diesel (or 19% on the existing rate of 26.73c per litre) implemented through

PARA.TAB: .an extra 3c per litre from 17 August 1993
.an extra 1c from February 1994
.an extra 1c per litre from August 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of these increases will mean an increase of $2 to $3 a week for a basket of simple household shopping items. I presume that most housewives these days cannot afford to stock the house for the whole week, so they go shopping probably twice a week. This is the sort of increase they will have to face.

PARA.TAB: The road transport industry in Australia is a very important one and the government in the past has recognised this fact and has made certain arrangements. The publication I referred to earlier also states:

SPEECH.PARA: This fact was recognised by the Federal Government when it established the National Road Transport Commission to reform road charges and regulations to improve road transport safety and efficiency.

The Transport & storage sector in Australia contributes 5 percent share of Australia's Gross Domestic Product and employs over 385,000 people directly. Road transport . . . alone contributing 2.4 percent of the national GDP. In comparison with other modes of freight transport, road transport:
*moves 75 per cent of freight nationally (990 million tonnes)
*directly employs over 177,000 people, or 49% of transport employment
*contributes $6 billion of Gross Product (45% of transport).
Having gained some efficiencies in the measures that were brought in in the last parliament, the government is going to wipe them out by the addition of these extra fuel taxes.

PARA.TAB: Another factor borne out in this publication is the impact of the increases to the diesel excise and wholesale sales tax on vehicle operating costs. The figures relate to cents in the dollar. Fuel taxes and levies alone would increase long distance operations of transporters by 18.4 per cent and on the short haul, which includes the urban situation, by 13.7 per cent. There is to be an increase of $2 to $3 a week in the shopping basket of families. There will be an increase of roughly $5,000 to $6,000 to road transporters per unit they operate.

Now we come to rural sector in which I am vitally interested. It has not escaped because this budget takes from it a fair slice of the off-road component—the return will not be as much. Transport, especially in the grain industry, is the biggest single item cost.

This government brought in a $100 million administration fee to administer the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The diesel fuel rebate was brought in in 1957. I contradict Senator Schacht because at an estimates committee he told us that the diesel fuel rebate was an aid to industry. It is not. It was brought in 1957 to pay back to off-road users the excise they paid on fuel used off-road.

The government of the day decided that road transport operators would pay their fair share of road maintenance. I quote very briefly from a speech which a former minister, Mr Osborne, made in this parliament in 1957. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will no doubt recall the introduction in this House on 3rd September this year of Customs Tariff Proposal No. 5 and Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 which, amongst other matters, gave effect to the Government's decision to impose a duty of one shilling a gallon—
which I presume is 10c a gallon—

on imported and Australian diesel fuel of the type used in diesel-engined road vehicles. The object of the tax was to ensure that operators of diesel-powered vehicles made a reasonable contribution to road construction and maintenance, as is the case with petrol-driven engines.
The government has forgotten to put that money back into roads. Mr Osborne continued:

. . . it was necessary to impose the duty on all automotive-type diesel fuel irrespective of the purpose for which it would be used but that reimbursement to the extent of one shilling a gallon would be made to those persons who used this type of fuel other than in the operation of road vehicles.
So Senator Schacht should take note that it is not an aid to industry; it is simply giving farmers and other off-road operators back what the government has taken from them.

PARA.TAB: I do not know any other government tax that has been introduced as an administration charge. We have had provisional tax in Australia for a long time. Does this government charge people an administration tax for giving them back their own provisional tax? No, it does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Personal tax refund.

—Yes, the personal tax refund. I hope the government does not get any ideas. It is getting $100 million, gives no credit for the money it has got in that time, and no credit on the rebate that operators

SPEECH.PARA: forget to reclaim. I will get to the figure in a moment. It is $100 million, plus the interest forgone and the eligible rebate that is not claimed. When we are trying to keep costs down for transport, farmers and industry in this country, we have the Greens of Western Australia advocating a massive rise in fuel by only returning, in their leaked paper, about half of the diesel fuel rebate, which is totally unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: It is as unacceptable as the way in which their accountability went out the door this morning on ATSIC, ably aided and abetted by the Democrats.

Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are in sympathy with Senator Boswell's urgency motion, but the problem is that it does not take us anywhere; it does not propose the kinds of initiatives we believe would truly assist rural people. We acknowledge Senator Boswell's proposal for the administration fee on the diesel fuel rebate. We are taking that seriously and we will give our response in due course. Let me cite some figures from the farm facts lifestyle survey. The average private distance travelled by farm families is 31,270 kilometres a year, compared with 19,240 kilometres a year for a capital city family. One can see the significant difference. That is why we are as concerned as Senator Boswell about this one issue, but we see that issue in a much wider context.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have put forward extensive proposals to compensate rural people and to return resources, people and hope to the bush. These proposals include exempting the family farm from the assets test for Austudy; compensation through reduced registration fees and thirty party insurance, as proposed in our getting to work proposal; and tax incentives and other incentives such as the selective use of tariffs, value adding, subsidies and import replacement.

In line with that, I inform honourable senators that Australia and New Zealand are the agricultural odd couple. The latest figures indicate that 11 per cent of Australian farmers' incomes and five per cent of New Zealand farmers' incomes are attributable to government subsidies. In Europe, the figure is 48 per cent; in the USA, 30 per cent; and, in Japan, 68 per cent.

I remind Senator Boswell that he voted for the government's tax cuts in 1992. Many commentators agree that to go ahead with the tax cuts is lunacy, given our current economic situation. We believe it is pointless to attack budget revenue measures without proposing alternatives, as we have done by opposing the tax cuts and by agreeing to other measures that the government has put forward. I understand that not only are community peak bodies such as ACOSS opposed to the tax cuts, but so is the National Farmers Federation. An article in yesterday's Australian states:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party federal council has resisted an internal push to have the Coalition oppose the Government's personal income tax cuts in the Senate.
But party leaders have been put on notice that they must take a higher profile in opposing the Government's sales and fuel tax increases . . .
That internal push came from the National Farmers Federation. I was interested that one of the main speakers in that debate was Senator Bill O'Chee. He said:
If we proceed with the original resolution we will become the issue, not the Government's tax rises . . . frankly, I want to see—
and I will not repeat the word that is used—
(Mr Keating) swing on a gibbet because he can't justify these tax cuts and we should make sure he is held accountable for them.

I say to both the government and the National Party that, while they play these political games, it is rural people who are paying the price. In this place I have recounted some of the hardship and the personal tragedy that I have come across as I have toured western Queensland. For those reasons we support the original motion as amended. We believe that Senator Boswell's original motion does not achieve what Senator Boswell wants it to achieve, but we do believe that our amendment does that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator Boswell and Senator Panizza with respect to this urgency motion. When the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) delivered the budget on 17 August, he boasted:

PARA.TAB: The government will meet its announced objectives, without the introduction of a massive new indirect tax. The government will maintain indirect tax exemptions for the necessities of life as traditionally recognised in the Australian tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never heard such a load of hogwash as that. Labor's system of indirect tax, particularly in relation to the wholesale sales tax and the fuel tax, is, in all but name, a consumption tax on the necessities of life. Worse than that, it is a system which directly discriminates against Australians who live outside our major cities.

PARA.TAB: In my home state of South Australia, about 75 per cent of the fuel sold outside Adelaide is leaded fuel. On the Tuesday of the budget petrol was selling in William Creek for 95c a litre and in February 1995 leaded fuel will cost at least 1.02c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —$1.02 a litre.

—I thank Senator Reid. It will cost $1.02 a litre. I do not know whether the Treasurer has ever considered the fact that fuel tax is a tax on primary production. Many trucks, utes and farm engines can use only leaded fuel. Farming families cannot afford to upgrade to newer cars which use unleaded fuel because of the particular economic difficulties that they are going through at the present time. It will cost farmers and primary producers more to get their products to markets, wherever they may be, and to the waterfront; and it will cost more to buy farm inputs and have them delivered because of the effect of the extra fuel tax.

PARA.TAB: Fuel tax is a tax on small businesses and the services that they provide. Small businesses in country areas travel further. Anybody who provides a service in the country—delivery companies, travelling salesmen and saleswomen, company and insurance representatives, the plumber, the electrician, you name it—has to travel long distances. So fuel tax is a tax on the services that they provide. Businesses outside the metropolitan area will have to pay more for goods to be delivered and the base price of goods will increase as the extra cost of fuel is built in down the line.

Fuel tax is a tax on employment. It costs country people more to get to work. More of their weekly wage will go to the government in fuel tax. Businesses will face an even higher tax burden, further discouraging them from employing new staff. Fuel tax is a tax on education. It will cost more to drive children to school and to school bus stops. It will cost more to drive children to music lessons, scouts, girl guides, after school sport and weekend sport, which is all part of the way of life of people who live outside the metropolitan area. It will cost more for tertiary students to travel to campuses, especially those in the capital cities. It will cost more for tertiary students to drive to whatever part-time job they are lucky enough to have and, if they are lucky enough to own a car, it is more than likely one which uses leaded fuel.

Fuel tax is a tax on health. It will cost more for country people to get to a doctor, a dentist, an optometrist and a hospital. It will cost more for doctors to make house calls.
