It will cost more to drive to major cities for things that many city people take for granted, such as the trips to the orthodontists and the trips for mammograms or any special tests and services.

Fuel tax is a tax on tourism. Eighty per cent of Australians taking holidays use a private vehicle or a vehicle of some sort. Tourism to remote places in states like South Australia and Western Australia, where there are no air services, will be especially hard hit. I am sure Senator McKiernan is very pleased to know what sort of effect it will have on tourism in Western Australia. Places like Coober Pedy, Lake Eyre, the Flinders Ranges, Port Lincoln and Ceduna in my home state of South Australia will all suffer because fuel tax is a tax on tourism.

Fuel tax is a tax on sport and entertainment. On weekends it will cost more for people to drive to sporting events, which can often be a round trip of over 100 kilometres. It will cost spectators more to travel with their teams. It will cost more to go to all other sorts of entertainment that people would like to visit, particularly those who live outside metropolitan areas.

Fuel tax is a tax on household items. The Treasurer says that it is not a tax on the necessities of life, but it is a tax on every household item that we have. It will cost more to transport household items and non-food groceries to country towns. But they will go up in price anyway because of the increase in the wholesale sales tax. It will also cost more for people to drive to major centres to buy items that are not readily available in the country. Such items are becoming even less readily available because of the economic hardships being suffered in rural communities.

Last but not least, fuel tax is a tax on food. It costs more to transport food to regional, rural and remote areas. It costs more to buy food because it will cost farmers more to produce food. I have already been contacted by a beekeeper who lives in a remote part of Kangaroo Island and who will be putting up the price of a simple thing such as honey as a direct result of the fuel tax increase and the extra costs that he will have to bear. So the Treasurer should not say that fuel tax is not a tax on the necessities of life, because it is. Most of all, it is a tax on food, particularly for those who live further out from the major cities.

What is even more strange is that all this comes from a Prime Minister who is on record as criticising tax collection through the petrol pump. I know that not many honourable senators here will remember, but in 1980 the now Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what we have seen is a massive tax by stealth operating on the Australian public, with every petrol pump in the country becoming a branch of the taxation office.
In 1981 he said:
Australians are being slugged, not just through the normal tax system, but by the growing impost which is levied by way of this indirect tax through taxes on petrol.
Our Prime Minister is very consistent; he hates a petrol tax. In 1982 he said:

The motorists have paid tax at the pump, the refiners have collected the money and given it back to Esso and BHP . . . We do not believe this is in the interests of anybody, particularly the Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just shows that you guys have done it all before.

—It just shows how consistent the Prime Minister is; unless, of course, the government is absolutely desperate to raise money because after 10 years in government it has completely stuffed up this economy. Fuel tax is the consumption tax that one has when one is not having a consumption tax. It impacts on everything. More than that, it makes it even more expensive to live in the country at a time when most rural families, most rural communities and most rural small businesses are facing considerable hardship and some are facing financial ruin.

PARA.TAB: Country people rely on fuel. Everything they buy, including the necessities of life, is more expensive because the cost of fuel must be added in. The government pretends to take an interest in the wellbeing of low income and disadvantaged families, yet the measures announced in this year's budget actively discriminate against one of the most disadvantaged sectors of the Australian community—the rural and regional communities.

A tax on fuel is effectively a tax on consumption, and one which will have an exaggerated and particularly cruel effect on those people who happen to live outside the metropolitan area. It is quite obvious from Senator Schacht's contribution that the government really could not care less about people who live outside the metropolitan area. Rural and regional areas have never been in so much trouble economically. What is this government's response? Slug them a bit more; squeeze the last drop out of the lemon. We will find that that approach to country people will make sure that many of them are further down the road to ruin than they already were because of this government's taxing policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I congratulate you on your election to your very esteemed office. I am sure you will carry out your functions with great style. This afternoon we are discussing yet another urgency motion. Such motions arise in this place each and every time a budget is introduced. I am not saying that just because I am a Labor Party government senator, because it has happened previously—a long time ago when those opposite were in government and introduced budgetary measures which increased taxes and increased revenue and which were opposed by the then opposition. There is absolutely nothing new at all in what we are doing here this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: There is also nothing new in the fact that it is sometimes difficult for people on this side of the chamber to defend measures such as the ones being debated here this afternoon. As an individual member of the community who also happens to be a member of parliament, I do not enjoy paying tax. I do not enjoy paying tax out of my income which is stopped before I even get the money into the bank account. I do not enjoy paying tax on the fuel that we purchase from the petrol pumps. We do not enjoy paying tax on the alcohol that some of us from time to time consume. The same applies to all the taxes that we have to pay. Very few people in the community enjoy paying tax.

As a member of parliament, I have not been inundated with constituents coming in to see me and telling us to increase taxes, but all governments do. All governments have done so from time immemorial. Not only do they do it at a Commonwealth level but also at a state level. In my state of Western Australia we know this as much as anybody else, although perhaps the Victorians are hurting a bit more on the state side of things. But governments do raise revenue through a variety of measures which include taxation and excise.

The increase in the fuel excise that we are debating this afternoon will undoubtedly hurt the community. Those who buy petrol or diesel at the moment will pay, or are paying currently, more for those products. The government realised this when it took those measures; it took it into account. They are very considered measures and it was known that they would have an inflationary impact on our society. Not only does one have to take account of the cost of the actual product that one purchases and puts into the fuel tank of the vehicle one is using; there is also the spin-off effect in that it will be inflationary. But it is not gloom and doom.

TALK.START.PARA: —You knocked a bit off.

—We have knocked a bit off. I am pleased about knocking a bit off. I will come to that in a little while. The measurements that the government has taken on this particular matter indicate that it will have an inflationary effect. The government is not running away from that at all. But the measurement it has come up with is that, at the first level, the effect will be one-quarter of one per cent of the CPI. That is not gloom and doom. This society will not end merely because an extra one-quarter of one per cent will go on to the consumer price index.
—You put up the cost by five per cent.
—You screwed it up.
—I did you the decency, Senator Boswell, of staying out of the chamber and refraining from interjecting when you were on your feet.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! Senator McKiernan, please address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. The real heavyweight contest going on here across the chamber was somewhat distracting. The increase of one-quarter of one per cent in the CPI does not mean that Australian society will end overnight or even end next year when additional measures come into force. Certainly, it will be hard, but I am sure that the Australian population will cope. Some people will have it harder than others as the measures filter through.

PARA.TAB: We have heard those arguments and the predictions of gloom and doom before. One example that springs to my mind very readily, coming from Western Australia as I do, is the measure we implemented some years ago when we removed the taxation exemption on the gold mining industry. The predictions then were that it would be the death of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was.
—It was a bad move, the gold tax.

—Of course it was not the death of the industry, as time has since proven. We have a very viable industry that is now making a contribution to our society. Let me move on to argue why the government has increased its share of the cake by implementing this measure.
—It is revenue though.

—It is revenue. Why does this government need revenue? It needs revenue to serve society. The government has no money of its own. The money that the government spends is raised from the taxpayers in a variety of forms. Fuel tax is just one form. How does government spend the money? It spends the money in a variety of ways. For example, we have seen in recent days—last week as a matter of fact—the expose that one of the senators on the other side tabled or made available to the media in relation to the travelling expenses of a particular opposition senator. Those expenses have to come from somewhere—$93,000, I think it was from memory—
—And that was only for air travel.

—No. From memory, I think there was an element of motor vehicle travel in that as well. But the money to pay Senator Bishop to travel around Australia to enhance her leadership ambitions has to be raised from the taxpayers of Australia. Whose pocket does that money come out of? It comes out of the pockets of each and every one of us and those of the constituents whom we represent in this place. It comes out of pay as you earn income tax and other taxes, such as fuel tax.

PARA.TAB: I have a certain amount of sympathy for the earlier arguments I have heard about the impact of this particular measure on people in rural areas of this country. There are more rural areas in my state than there are in any other state of Australia. I am sure Senator Panizza will agree with me on that because we both do our best to represent the interests of people from Western Australia. Western Australians are very resilient people, particularly those who come from rural areas. They are not whingers. They accept the good times with the bad times.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not accept this budget.

—They are accepting it, with all due respect, Senator Boswell. My office has not been inundated with claims against this particular tax measure. In actual fact, after the recent federal budget, fuel tax is probably one of the sleepers in the budget. It certainly has not come to the fore.
—They are probably ringing Senator Panizza.

—I have no doubt that they are probably ringing Senator Panizza. They are probably ringing him in Perth, but they are not raising the matter with me. I would not be surprised if they did raise it with me because like any increased tax, it will be unpopular. It is unpopular, but the people will rally to the cause and will pay up and accommodate the budget accordingly to take into account the additional expenditure that has to be forked out.

PARA.TAB: I want to make one final point in closing my contribution to the debate—I do not think it will be accepted by people on that side of the chamber, but it is a very important point. To raise revenue by increasing taxes on fuel is not a new phenomenon. In 1981-82 the government of the day raised 14.6 per cent of the total Commonwealth revenue from excise on fuel. In 1992-93—the last complete year for which statistics are available—we brought that down to 10 per cent. So fuel is actually cheaper than it was more than 10 years ago when those opposite were in office—or when their predecessors were because none of this lot has ever served on the front bench; they do not have an `honourable' among them! So that is a point that has to be taken into account. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks on some of the previous speeches. Senator Schacht led the debate for the government and the only defence of the budget that he could come up with was to delve back into dark history and say that 74 per cent of the people believed that we did the same thing in 1981.
—It was only 1981.

—Well, that is 12 years ago. That was the only defence that Senator Schacht could come up with. Senator McKiernan thought that increasing tax was a pretty good idea because it was the only way that governments could get revenue. It is not the only way that governments can get revenue. I point out that the previous Queensland government had a very low tax base, even to the point that it left the chest full for the incoming government. Even last week, the Queensland government did not put up taxes because it can rely on what was left from the previous government. Therefore, it is not absolutely essential for governments to put up tax—not if they are efficient, do not have a million people unemployed and do not spend huge amounts on social welfare benefits.

PARA.TAB: We have now got to the point that every time a budget comes round we have to look at the budget papers under a microscope. We have seen the most minute details of how the government is trying to screw $1 million here, $1 million there and $0.5 million here, such is its desperate need to increase revenue to run its deficit down. But I think one of the most ludicrous or mean tax grabs is the one per cent administration charge on the diesel rebate which will bring in $19.6 million for the government; in other words, the government will charge the farmers a fee so that it can give them a rebate—that is quite nonsensical.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them their own money back.

—Give them their own money back, as Senator Ferguson said. Senator Ferguson and Senator Panizza made their usual well-judged contributions, and the two Australian Democrats split their time into five minute intervals. I know that it is very difficult to make any points in that time, but they have moved an amendment—and no doubt they will be calling a division—which we will not be accepting.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I point out that this has been a very serious debate today. The contributions made by the speakers on this side were passionate because Senator Panizza and Senator Ferguson are rural representatives of their states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very passionate.

—Yes, they were very passionate in the defence of their states. The point that should be raised and hammered home in this debate is that Senator McKiernan's state will come out the worst. This increase will have the heaviest impact on his state. The Northern Territory, which is represented by the Minister for Transport and Communications, will also be badly affected.
—And most of our community will get the benefits of the tax cuts.

—Senator Collins's territory is the one that really cops it. It will have to bear an increase of five per cent in transport costs. It does not matter how he tries to wriggle out of that, the increase in the transport costs in his territory will be felt in the price of goods in the grocery trolley. That is where the low income earners up there will feel the impact the most. Instead of paying an extra $3 a week for their groceries, they will probably pay an extra $4 a week. I say to both Senator Collins and Senator McKiernan that they have failed their respective constituencies. I do not know what Senator Collins was doing when this was going through.
—We will only get to that figure if freight accounts for the total cost of the goods—all of it.
—Senator Collins can put any spin on it he likes but his constituents in the Northern Territory and Senator McKiernan's constituents in Western Australia will be the ones who are hurt the most.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether Senator Collins got the same mushroom treatment that Mr Crean got in respect of the wine tax where he was not consulted, was not told and then had to beat a hasty retreat and try to back away from it in the press. Senator Collins has not done that; he has taken it on the chin. But there is no way in the world that both of them should not have stood up for their states and defended them. What happens in this respect will depend on what the Green senators do. As I said before, Senator McKiernan's state of Western Australia will be hurt. Perth will be hurt and, more to the point, the more remote areas of Western Australia will be hurt.

The Democrats have agreed to let the budget go through in an amended form. The fate of this budget now rests heavily with the Greens. If they want to be representatives of Western Australia and if they want to occupy that little independent section of the market that the Democrats normally take, then here is their great opportunity to stand up for Western Australia and claim that ground. I can tell them as an old Western Australian that they will win some accolades over there if they stand up for their state of Western Australia.

The Greens have the opportunity to do it now and if they drop the ball this time they will just get swamped by the Democrats. But if they stand up for what they believe in, if they stand up for what they went to the polls on—that is, defending the rights of Western Australians—then they will make some political ground. It is up to them. Their future is really in their own hands. I hope they will vote with the coalition to defeat this budget which 74 per cent of Australians believe is a budget of despair that offers nothing for them. Most Australians just want the government to go back, start again and redesign the budget. The fate of the $1.2 billion increase in excise is now firmly in the hands of the Greens.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes on the terms of reference part (1)(a), together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I will start off in a way that these sorts of speeches often end, and that is to thank the secretariat who prepared this report. The report has just got to us after some quite desperate work from Elton Humphery and Winifred Jurcevic who did all the typing. They deserve to be thanked.

PARA.TAB: The Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes has a few terms of reference, one of which is the subject of this report—and there is another report to follow. Part (1)(a) of the terms of reference states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes be appointed to inquire into and report upon the following matters:

(a)the extent to which the Minister for Transport and Communications discharged his ministerial responsibilities in relation to satellite and MDS tender processes having particular regard to the appropriate contemporary definition of ministerial responsibility and including any different responsibility which might attach to the role of a Minister during the caretaker period of an election . . .
The majority of the committee, four to two, made findings and reached conclusions. The findings were:

PARA.TAB: In both tendering processes—

SPEECH.PARA: the process for the satellite pay TV licences and the MDS tendering process—

the Minister may have taken action different to that which was actually taken had he appreciated the full and accurate facts relevant to each. However, he was not aware of them and proceeded in both cases on a version of facts which in vital respects was incomplete and inaccurate.

PARA.TAB: On the version of facts which he accepted he acted reasonably and in the circumstances prevailing at the time was reasonable in accepting this version.

The Minister is now aware of deficiencies in his department at the relevant time and of the need to remedy them. He and the Department have taken action to rectify them and the Committee is required by part (1)(b) of its terms of reference to report on the adequacy of this action. It will proceed to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The conclusion reached is:

PARA.TAB: To date—

SPEECH.PARA: and the point of the phrase `to date' is that the committee has yet to consider other parts of the terms of reference—
the Minister for Transport and Communications has discharged his ministerial responsibilities in relation to satellite and MDS tender processes.
It continues:

PARA.TAB: The Committee reserves judgment on the Minister's discharge of those responsibilities requiring action to be taken to rectify the administrative deficiencies until after it completes the second part of its inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: That will be an inquiry into what has been done to rectify problems in the department.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston and Senator Tierney put in a dissenting report to the findings and conclusions reached by the majority of committee members. I am sure that both honourable senators will speak to the report and point out why they dissented. The dissenting report contains the following quote from Winston Churchill:
I did not know. I was not told. I should have asked.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee as a whole would agree with that quote, but it does not apply in the present situation. The minister did not know all the facts that were relevant. He was not told. But, in the view of the majority, the proposition that he should have asked is not a valid criticism. In the circumstances at the time, he was informed of certain issues, but not all of them. The way he acted, as I have already said, was reasonable in all the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The proposition that people should not be punished for acting other than they might have acted if they had known the full facts, having acted in the light of the facts as they understood them, is a concept that runs very deeply in our law. That is borne out by a statement from one of the greatest, if not the greatest, common lawyers in the history of the common law world, Mr Justice Dixon, as he was during the case I will quote from. He later became a very eminent chief justice for the High Court. In this case, Proudman and Dayman, he was talking in circumstances quite different from the present one; nevertheless, the statement he made is relevant to it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a general rule, an honest and reasonable belief in a state of facts which if they existed would make the defendant's act innocent affords an excuse for doing what would otherwise be an offence.

Of course, this is not completely relevant to the present circumstances, because what he was talking about then was an offence under the Road Traffic Act of South Australia. But what about the proposition that we cannot hold people responsible for acting on an honestly held and properly ascertained view of the facts simply because those facts are wrong? The minister was not reckless in accepting the facts as he saw them. He honestly believed those to be the true facts.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston and Senator Tierney do not accept that proposition. No doubt they will both argue very strenuously that their proposition is correct. They will say, no doubt, that the facts as I have outlined them are wrong and the facts as they will outline them are correct. It is a matter for the people who are listening to this debate to make up their own minds as to where the truth lies.

The view of the majority was formed on the basis of facts very similar to those found by Professor Pearce. There are four senators responsible for the majority report, three of whom are government senators, who are no doubt keen, and whose minds might be considered biased in favour of the minister, a person who has been in caucus with them for a long while. It is understandable that those people—Senator McKiernan, Senator Loosley and I—may be biased because of the situation we find ourselves in. That is a proposition that no doubt will be put forward by Senator Alston and Senator Tierney. But then, of course, we are supported by Senator Bourne, who, I venture to say, would be considered one of the most fair-minded senators presently in this chamber—and, I think, one of the most fair-minded senators who have ever been in this chamber. Nevertheless, there is no doubt that she is in this political atmosphere and perhaps could have been overborne by the vigour of the moment.

Now we come to Professor Pearce, who went away and made the report divorced from political considerations; a person who was absolutely independent of all this. That is the problem that Senator Alston and Senator Tierney face. They know that they can get up and say that the three government senators may be prejudiced. They have a lot more trouble with Senator Bourne. But their real problem is Professor Pearce. That is why in their dissenting report the attack is not on the senators but on Professor Pearce. That is the exercise they have engaged in. They might be right, but let us have a look.

The opinion of the majority, as expressed in the majority report, is couched in very measured terms. It is my proposition that it is consistent with a measured consideration of this case. If we look at the dissenting report, we see phrases such as `this advice was extraordinary'. They are talking about an advice that they had dealt with earlier in their opinion. On the same page, we see these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is extraordinary that at no stage did he apparently turn his mind to how Cabinet's request could be facilitated. Indeed he seems to have been blissfully unaware. . .
Over the page, the report says:
It is also extraordinary that there appear to be no minutes of the meetings
In these circumstances it beggars belief that Professor Pearce. . .
On the same page, it says:
It is also verging on the unbelievable. . .
We can see the following phrase:
. . . is not able to be presently located is also highly convenient. . .
On the same page, the report says:
If these events are true then they suggest that the Minister's office was indeed a shambles. . .
Over the page, it says:
Pearce—
not `Professor Pearce'—

simply notes that there were no discussions with the Minister or his advisers relating to the tender process to be included in the determination. He makes no adverse comment on what is obviously a deficiency in the chain of reporting and accepts the Minister's specious proposition
Pearce seems oblivious to the fact that intervention to require a deposit could not in any circumstances be construed as favouritism.
The findings of Professor Pearce in relation to term of reference number 4 are a complete whitewash.
On the bottom of the page, the report says:

Senator Collins cannot possibly be excused for treating this as just another document. To the extent that he was unaware of its significance he was guilty of a gross failure to exercise reasonable care. . .

Are those sorts of terms consistent with a considered statement of what happened in relation to the two tender processes? These are the words that Senator Alston and Senator Tierney use in putting a proposition that is contrary to the findings of four senators and of Professor Pearce. Senator Alston and Senator Tierney are good members of the Liberal Party and do the best they can for their party, and certainly it would be of advantage to the Liberal and National Party coalition if Senator Collins were brought down. It may just be that that matter affected their minds.

PARA.TAB: I turn to another issue in the context of what happened during this inquiry. At a committee hearing in Canberra on 20 August this year Senator Alston and Senator Tierney made the very reasonable request that a Mr Bruce Meagher be called before the committee. Mr Bruce Meagher was a person who could have given evidence relevant to the matter we had before us. At the time he was a member of Minister Collins's staff. As chairperson, I asked Senator Collins whether he would object to Mr Meagher being called. Senator Collins said he would object on the basis that Mr Meagher, as a member of the minister's personal staff, should not be called and that it was a bad precedent to set. In fact, it would have been a precedent because there is no evidence that this has ever been done before.

As chairperson I ruled in favour of Senator Collins. I said that of course there is a public interest in having all facts before the committee and that any witness that might be able to throw light on those facts would be quite valuable. But I said there is also a public interest in not calling members of a parliamentarian's personal staff or a minister's personal staff because it was likely that it would be prejudicial to the confidentiality which as parliamentarians we all come to rely on when we are getting advice from our personal staff or from our personal advisers. I felt it would be a bad thing to prejudice that confidentiality. I am still of that view.

If that precedent is set, the House of Representatives could call on the personal staff of the Leader of the Opposition, or it could call on the personal staff of every shadow minister, and indeed of every member of the opposition, and ask that person to give an account. If it were taken too far, parliamentarians could call on members of the press to disgorge what their sources had told them in confidence. The whole concept of confidentiality would be prejudiced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he talk to Pearce in confidence?

—I am asked,`Did he talk to Pearce in confidence?' He did. That is one factor that might be taken into account in deciding whether or not to call him. He had spoken to Professor Pearce and there was no suggestion that what he told Professor Pearce was wrong.

PARA.TAB: The point is that I ruled against Senator Alston and Senator Tierney, who objected strongly, and properly so. I thought about what Senator Alston, who is a very experienced person in the procedures of this place, a person who once adorned the legal profession, would do. I thought he would go to the Senate and say, `Look at this outrageous piece of conduct on Senator Cooney's part. I want the Senate to order'—as it could—`that Senator Collins's personal adviser, Mr Meagher, appear before this committee and give evidence'. But Senator Alston did not do that; he has not moved. One can legitimately wonder how interested he really was in calling this person.

This happened on 20 August and there have been several sitting days since then. There has been no motion from Senator Alston. He has not come in here and said, `I am going to move a motion, which I will get through here tomorrow, that Mr Meagher be called before this committee'. He could have done that but he did not. Instead, what he did—and this indicates what he was really on about—was put out a press release on the same day that this happened. The press release is headed, `Looks like a cover-up, smells like a cover-up'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Three Government members today bludgeoned through the Senate Pay TV inquiry an unprecedented resolution refusing to allow a key witness to appear before the committee for questioning.
Discharging Mr Meagher from this responsibility is unprecedented and has the hallmarks of a crisis management exercise. It is nothing more than a government cover-up.
The two Coalition members—
I felt sorry for them because when we look at Senators Alston and Tierney we see that they are of the delicate variety—
who are outnumbered on the Pay TV inquiry committee, expressed outrage at this clumsy attempt at a cover-up and unprecedented decision allowing a witness not to give evidence.
Although Mr Meagher—
This is a fairly gracious concession—

would have been the first political staffer to appear before a Senate inquiry, there is nothing stopping him from doing so. His Minister was quite happy for him to give evidence to the inquiries conducted by Professor Pearce—which coincidentally did not examine the question of ministerial responsibility—so why the coyness now?
Is the Minister seriously asserting that his own hand-picked inquiry is more important than the Senate?
The minister hand-picked this inquiry, and I am wondering why he hand-picked Senator Alston. What is there between Senator Alston and the minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Pearce, Pearce.
—No. Senator Alston has said this. He said, `. . . his own hand-picked inquiry'—
—The hand-picked inquiry is Pearce.
—No. Senator Alston said, `. . . his hand-picked inquiry is more important that the Senate'. Senator Alston is talking about this inquiry which he and I were on.
—No, the hand-picked inquiry was Pearce.

—I will accept what Senator Alston says, because I think that is proper. What I find interesting is that, when Senator Alston had this major point about the chairperson's ruling that this person could not be called, he did not come into the Senate to correct that; he immediately went off and sought a profile in the media. That is all right; that is what we are all about. But if somebody tries to get a profile in the media rather than try to correct the situation and have this person called before the committee, we begin to wonder how anxious that person is to have him called.
—You could have called our bluff and brought him along, couldn't you?
—I was looking after Senator Alston's interests because if we had called him we might have had to call lots of others.

PARA.TAB: There are a few points I want to make about the general proposition of ministerial responsibility. We found that ministerial responsibility is really a hard concept to define because, if I can just go back to my days in law, it is a bit like the defence of provocation in murder. Even if one reads all the books, it is very hard to explain the concept of provocation because one really has to look at the situation where that woman was provoked into killing that man or vice versa or whatever. We really cannot define it because we have to look at the particular circumstances. It is the same with the concept of ministerial responsibility: we have to look at it and say, `In all the circumstances, this person has gone a bit beyond the pale'.

Whether a minister stays or goes depends upon the leader. It could be said that that is a cynical approach. But it is a realistic approach and it is not a cynical approach because the pressure is on the leader, as we said in the report, to rely on his or her own sense of morality. The political ethics within which he works, parliamentary pressure, peer pressure, party sentiment, community standards, community reactions, media reaction and precedent all play a part in bringing moral imperatives into the equation. But it is wrong—and I would like to hear Senator Alston comment on this—to show too great a tendency to treat the concept as some sort of legal concept and say, `We have all these existing and specific laws and we find out facts. Then we join the two together and apply the principles of natural justice to get a decision'. It is not like that at all; it is a political process with a lot of elements to be taken into account.
Section 64 of the constitution makes it clear that it is very much the Prime Minister who decides what happens. Section 64 of the constitution says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General may appoint officers to administer such departments of State of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish.

Since the Governor-General acts—or should act—on the advice of the Prime Minister in this case, it is the Prime Minister who decides. That is not to say that parliament is excluded from considerations in cases such as this; in fact, it is included in such considerations. In this report we used the expression `accountability to parliament' when referring to the responsibility of the Prime Minister. There is nothing that can stop parliament bringing a minister to account, as was done in the case of Senator Collins. He was questioned in here, he was subjected to issues raised in debate about him, and so on. That is the good, vigorous part of what goes on in the political world, and it will continue.

PARA.TAB: We have the concept of ministerial responsibility and responsibility to the Prime Minister. He or she alone can make the person resign, or else dismiss, demote or not promote him or her at a later stage. On the other hand, Parliament, through the various proceedings available to it—which are so well exercised—can do something about it.

In any event, we worked out some tests which may be applied in a case such as this. On those tests the majority concluded that Senator Collins had not breached his ministerial responsibility. Having said that and having applied those tests—I did not know, I was not told, I should have asked—to Senator Collins, we concluded that in our view Winston Churchill would have come to the same conclusion as we did.

The real argument in this case is the interpretation of facts and the facts that are relied upon. We simply say—and I end on this note because I think it is the important issue in this matter—that our findings of fact are consistent with those of the independent fact finder, Professor Pearce, a man well respected in all areas, and therefore better deserve to be relied upon than the findings and interpretations of two other people who, no matter how wonderful they are, are nevertheless properly members of a political party and are advocating a position which their political party would no doubt want them to advocate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had half an hour's worth from Senator Cooney but at no stage did we really get down to what I would have thought were the fundamentals of this debate—that is, what standards ought to apply in judging ministerial conduct and the extent to which there ought to be an ethical component in that standard.

PARA.TAB: We only have to go back to Senator Collins who, in his usual smart alec way, said that as far as he was concerned one only ever resigned if one lost the confidence of the Prime Minister, and I think he then added `and a few of his close mates'. That fundamentally misunderstands what the doctrine of ministerial responsibility ought to be about. It might be stating the application of the rule as far as the Labor Party is concerned. In other words, if one has no moral compass, if one thinks one can tough it out and is basically like the New South Wales Right—a collection of spivs on the make—and one does not have any moral values to guide one, then of course one's judgments are determined by things such as public opinion polls, editorials and the extent of community outrage. At some stage one says, `It is getting a bit hot in this kitchen; we are coming up to an election; we had better cut this bloke loose'. That is the sort of morality that operates on the other side of the chamber.

That is why I was a bit disappointed that someone of Senator Cooney's high moral standards would not recognise that this ought to be a debate about what is to be expected of figures in public life, not what they do in practice when they happen to be part and parcel of a caucus and attached to the moorings of the current Prime Minister who never ever seemed to recognise the concept of morality in public life. That is where I think the majority has been fundamentally misled.

I am not here to say that this is simply a collection of biases on one side or the other, or a strict exchange of prejudices, if you like. It is more a matter of trying to analyse the findings and decisions that have been made. Page 10 of the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Rules of natural justice do not apply to leaders' decisions to have ministers dismissed.

The government just does not understand the concept of natural justice. Natural justice is the right to be tried and heard by a tribunal free of bias. Even by the very murky standards of those opposite, I would have thought that a minister in their government ought to be entitled to have his case properly considered by the Prime Minister of the day and for that Prime Minister to then make a decision free of bias against the minister. Surely that is a reasonable proposition. Yet Senator Cooney seems to think that somehow rules of natural justice do not apply to leaders' decisions. Maybe they do not in practice, but they certainly should. Government members confused the normative and the positive constantly throughout this report. That is where they simply go astray from the outset.

PARA.TAB: Unless we try to identify standards of behaviour and then judge whether people measure up to those standards, we do not even begin to deal with what ministerial responsibility is all about. If we take Senator Cooney's approach, it is simply a matter of what one can get away with in terms of public outrage.

Again, we can go to the report's conclusions. I would have thought that Senator Cooney would be very conscious of the difference between actual and constructive knowledge. Yet what we have under the heading `Findings' is this:

SPEECH.PARA: In both tendering processes the Minister may have taken action different to that which was actually taken had he appreciated the full and accurate facts relevant to each. However he was not aware of them and proceeded in both cases on a version of facts which in vital circumstances was incomplete and inaccurate.
The obvious question is whether he ought to have known.

PARA.TAB: I recall—Senator Cooney might also remember this—the old days where in company law there was a case of a company director who was charged with negligence because of all sorts of heinous things that had gone on over a period of years. It was not Foss v Harbottle. In any event, his defence was, `You cannot blame me. I have not been to a board meeting in 32 years'. Does Senator Cooney remember that one?

TALK.START.PARA: —And he escaped!

—He got off; that is my point. One could not do that these days. One cannot say, `I am the minister, but no-one told me about this, so I wash my hands of it. I was in Darwin in January watching the cricket, and I was getting ready for the election. Because the department did not ring me and the ministerial staff were out to lunch, that is not my fault'. That is not what constructive responsibility is all about.

PARA.TAB: There is an obligation on a minister to keep himself fully informed, to ensure that he has competent people around him, to seek advice where it is necessary and to heed it when it is given. What happened in this case? This minister has not been in the job five minutes. In fact, even by January this year he had been in the job longer than his three predecessors combined. But certainly he was not a Johnny-come-lately.

Senator Collins might have been a failed opposition leader in the Northern Territory, but he has been in politics for a considerable number of years. He knows the game backwards. He is quite proud of the fact that he was a gutter politician in the territory, because he has told us so in the chamber. By this stage, he was not only in his first ministerial portfolio but in cabinet. Therefore, one would have expected someone in that position to be acutely aware of the need to ensure that cabinet decisions are carried out.

What happened at the time? Senator Richardson was wandering around the world in March last year. He got informed, as he should have, about tendering processes and the change of approaches taken by regulators. He came back with the considered view that beauty contests are not really on these days and that one needs to have some sort of pre-qualification process but essentially a price based allocation system. That all made a lot of sense. Senator Richardson took it on board and then got the chop.

Who should then come along but Senator Collins. The first thing that Senator Collins should have done was inform himself about current practices and where things were in terms of tender processes. He well knew, as he has conceded, of the AM-FM conversion fiasco. Therefore, this had to be a top-of-the-mind issue. Indeed, he was going into a brand new era of regulation. He was going into a system that was clearly going to be quite different from that which had preceded it. He was going into it for both satellite and MDS. Quite clearly, there was a critical responsibility for the minister to ensure that he was fully on top of what was likely to occur.

Cabinet took a decision that it wanted a pre-qualification put in place. It set out five propositions that ought to be included as hurdles. One of them is capability and whether there is a sound financial and business plan. One presumes that Senator Collins knew that, because he took the submission to cabinet. That having been the case, one again would think that he would have been acutely conscious of the need to ensure that, by one means or another, that sort of process was put in place.

But what seems to have happened is that from that point on he was off with the fairies. The department then went ahead, obtained some advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the submission could not actually deliver in those precise terms. No-one ever seems to have gone back to the minister and told him that, let alone invited him to explore some options. Any minister worth his salt would have done just that. He would have said, `Hang on. This is what cabinet wants. It wants a pre-qualification process. It does not want mickey mouse, fly-by-night tyre kickers', as we ultimately got. It wanted serious long-term players in the industry.

Any minister who was at all interested in outcomes would then have said, `Hang on. How have they done it around the world? They have been able to have pre-qualifications hurdles put in in England and elsewhere, because we have had our bureaucrats over there talking to them. Let's work out a way of ensuring that we meet cabinet's dictates'. In fact, he did nothing of the sort. He basically was oblivious to all that was going on around him.

I would have thought that that is culpable negligence. If ever the minister had an obligation to be an active player in the process to ensure that what cabinet wanted was what transpired, it was this. But in fact, he did the opposite. What did we end up with—an absolutely ludicrous scheme that allowed people to put in place multiple bids without any deposit requirement.

One applicant said to me, `You only had to put up $500. If you think that is a problem, I rang them up and said, "I can't actually get a bank cheque. Will you take my personal cheque?", and they said, "Certainly. Just send it in"'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cancel it tomorrow.

—Indeed. You could have got in for two bob. We are all kicking ourselves that we did not take advantage of this. We have to leave it to former smart operators like Neil Brown to get in and get a slice of the action.

PARA.TAB: That is how ludicrous this whole system was. Here was a minister presiding over probably the greatest fiasco one could ever conceive. If we really wanted the thing to go off the rails and become an international laughing stock, this is pretty much the perfect formula: make sure that people can put in silly bids at silly figures which do not preclude Minister Beddall going out and saying, `These figures are absolutely right. I always thought that people underestimated the value.' He thought $389 million was pretty good. I reckon he will be pretty happy if the government ends up with about a third of that in due course.

The fact is that Senator Collins was in the unique position to ensure that the proper processes were put in place. He did none of it. When it comes to Senator Cooney's assessments, one finds not one word about constructive knowledge. There is not one word of what he ought to have done.
The preceding page, headed `Operation of the Private Office', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has acknowledged shortcomings which occurred in the operation of his private office, due in particular to staff absences during the January holiday period which led to breakdowns in the processing of documents through the office and to being distracted during the 1993 election campaign.
That is a plea of guilt out of his own mouth. That is precisely what Senator Collins said. Talk about an excess of frankness! He said:
It is like an airline disaster . . . The reason you rarely have an airline disaster is that it is a collection of a whole series of failures

. . . The bureaucracy narrows down very quickly to a couple of people in the cockpit of the aircraft—if you like, my senior adviser, sitting in the seat next to me, and me as the captain of the aircraft, as the Minister, finally. When errors occur that combine failures on the ground, in the control tower, in the systems management and finally compounded in the cockpit, you get a disaster. I think the analogy is exact and I am part of that disaster.

Game, set and match. If the captain is not responsible, who is? It is like him getting the aircraft off the ground and then going down the back of it, drinking himself into oblivion for the next couple of hours and then wondering why it went down. The co-pilot—the senior adviser—was not even allowed to be called.

PARA.TAB: Let us be perfectly clear on this: one thing Pearce was not allowed to do to earn his $37,000 in two weeks was to pass judgment on ministerial culpability. He was not there to do that. For the committee to spend the bulk of that report saying, `We accept the findings of Pearce' is absolutely irrelevant. It is totally beside the point. I have gone through the report in some detail to analyse the shortcomings in Pearce's evidence to the extent that they bear upon any culpability.

At the end of the day, Pearce was simply not competent, on his own terms of reference, to pass judgment on this minister. That finding was the obligation of the committee. The committee cannot cop out of it by saying, `We accept Pearce's findings'. Pearce was not paid to do that job. The job he did does not assist the committee in passing judgment.

One really could not get better evidence. I have seen some records of interview in my time, but when the defendant gets up and says, `I am part of that disaster', I would have thought there is a fairly good prima facie case of culpability. But we get the classic whitewash, `We are satisfied with all the circumstances'. The committee cannot go on with all that sort of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Proudman v Daymon?

—I am afraid that Proudman v Daymon does not get the committee anywhere. All Proudman v Daymon does is to say, `Where you have an honest and reasonable belief in a state of facts which, if true, would exculpate you, you are not guilty'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins is not here charged with a criminal offence. Even his worst enemies would say that he is not in the classic mould of a criminal. But that in no way says that he is not incompetent or that he does not have a case to answer or that he did not muck this up from beginning to end. That is what this issue is about.

If one is judging ministerial competence there is no point in coming in here and trotting out some criminal law proposition that one learnt in first year law. It has nothing to do with whether Senator Collins informed himself of what was going on, took an active interest in the process and carried out his job.

Why pay these ministers $100,000 plus—it is probably $150,000 with all the perks—if they are going to leave it to the department to make all these decisions and then say, `They did not tell me. A lot must have gone on and with hindsight, I wish I had known. But the fact is that I was up in Darwin in January and the phone did not ring, so I just signed this document.'

As we say in the report, some of reasons that were given and some of the findings that were accepted by this committee are classical. They reflect precisely what Senator Collins would have said to Professor Pearce. The report states:

The findings by Professor Pearce in relation to Term of Reference number 4 are a complete whitewash and heavily reflect the tenor of remarks made publicly by Senator Collins and presumably repeated in private to Professor Pearce. The statement that "the Minister signs a large number of documents of different kinds. He cannot be expected to peruse each of these closely" is pure Collins.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where I think it is verging on appalling that Professor Pearce should be drawn in in that way. Professor Pearce surely knows that this was not just another document. This was a document that started off a multimillion dollar process, something unique in the annals of television history that one day will hopefully lead at least to satellite pay television getting off the ground. This was a document that was a quite extraordinary start to a process.

PARA.TAB: Yet for Senator Collins to trot out, as he has here—and obviously as he did to Professor Pearce—that he signs a lot of documents and cannot be expected to know what they are all about is Jim Cairns stuff. He got his and so should Senator Collins. He cannot say, `Well, I just sign anything that is put in front of me.' He has to ask a few questions.

As I said before, why do we pay these people heaps to be ministers. We pay them heaps because presumably they bring with them accumulated knowledge, experience, understanding of the processes and some basic commonsense. All of this should add up to a minister saying, `If I am given a document, I ought to know what it is about. If I do not understand, because I could not get into law school, then I get some advice from elsewhere. I ring up my staff or the department, or I make sure there is an accompanying brief so I know what I am signing.' None of that happened.

I would have thought Bruce Meagher is the classic example of a cover up. Bruce Meagher is a person in the unique position to tell us what Senator Collins really wanted of an adviser. What do ministers pay advisers good money for? They are paid to advise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you get him called?

—Senator Cooney sounds as though he thinks we would have got somewhere if we had done that. My impression was that Senator Cooney and his good friend Senator McKiernan, and no doubt Senator Bourne and her colleagues, would have been vigorously opposed to that.

PARA.TAB: Senator McKiernan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not too late. We can have him brought before the Senate. Would those opposite be interested if we jointly sponsored a motion?
—As long as we call a few others as well.

—We could call anyone else who is relevant to the inquiry. Who else would those opposite suggest? I am sure my colleagues are trying to be as helpful as usual. Undoubtedly they recognise that Bruce Meagher was a vital witness. They fought hard and long to keep him out of the clutches of the committee because they know that it is not good enough for him to go before Professor Pearce and say a few things in private. If it is good enough to go before Professor Pearce, then I would have thought that it is good enough to go before the committee.

PARA.TAB: One can take the point of privilege, plead the fifth amendment by all means, but one must plead it to Professor Pearce too. One only has to say, `Sorry, you will be interviewing Senator Collins. He is my master; he can tell you anything that I could have told you.' That is not what happened. Yet it would have been very important for us to understand precisely what Mr Meagher knew and when, what he passed on to the minister and what he did not pass on. If we take the evidence of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody on the committee except Senator Bourne had a purpose in mind.

—It ill becomes Senator Cooney to suggest that people were making judgments based on their political affiliations. Those opposite ought to be able to be objective about these matters. If a witness can contribute to the evidence surely we should allow that witness to come on.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite wheeled him up to Professor Pearce, presumably to bolster their own case. If that is not so why does he not say, `Sorry, I will send along Senator Collins. I do not want to contribute.'? But he does not. He goes along and does his best for the side no doubt. It is all in secret, so we never know who said what and we do not know who asked him any questions. Who knows? No-one was there to cross-examine him. He probably sat across the table, said a few things to Professor Pearce who noted it all down and put it into his report. It is a classic exoneration formula.

If those opposite were fair dinkum about this exercise they would have allowed witnesses to come forward who could have had a significant bearing on the inquiry. If there was one person who could have done so, it was Bruce Meagher.

I think it is just another objective sign that those opposite had a lot to be afraid of. I can understand it because, if we take his evidence at face value, Bruce Meagher would have confirmed that Senator Collins was not particularly interested. He delegated all these matters. He said, `Basically it is a matter for you. You make sure that it is all happening. If there are instructions to give, you give them. If there are problems, you solve them. If there are decisions to make, you make them.' All of this is a total abdication of responsibility. That is what this issue is all about. What standards does the government expect and has he met them?

I noted that Senator Cooney did not attempt to refute any of our assessments of the quality of Professor Pearce's findings in the areas where they are relevant; all he did was point to the way in which we had expressed ourselves. This has nothing to do with the merits of the argument. If our points are valid, surely we are entitled to express them strongly. All those opposite have said is, `We used some soft rhetoric, you used some tough rhetoric and somehow that proves something'. It does not. The government has to look at the arguments and attempt to refute them. Those opposite made no such effort. All I can say is that they have done a pretty good job today in confirming our worst suspicions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the most important part of this first section of the inquiry, of which we have the report here this evening, is that which looks into the appropriate contemporary definition of ministerial responsibility. The first two hearings of this committee involved several former leaders, strategists, senior public servants, many academics and other experts in this field, if indeed we can say anybody is an expert in this field—although we feel that we are getting a bit closer now ourselves.

PARA.TAB: Those hearings were quite fascinating. They were some of the most interesting I have ever been to. It was interesting that two points of view came out of them. Very substantially the first point of view—and I think it was the most prevalent—was that ministerial responsibility does exist. Only the Prime Minister—in fact really only the Queen—can take away somebody's ministerial responsibilities. But the Governor-General or the Governor, on behalf of the Queen, does that only on the advice of Prime Minister or the Premier.

It does come down to whether the ministers themselves have the confidence of the Prime Minister of the day and of their own caucus. To a certain extent it does come down to whether they have the confidence of the parliament in which they find themselves and whether they are able to operate effectively in that parliament.

The second point of view that we heard was that it was none of our business. A couple of people did not really know why they had bothered to come before us to give evidence. They were being generous to us, so they gave us the benefit of their wisdom. That was actually the lesser view. There were only a couple of people who said that and they were related by ties of loyalty. It is a legitimate view. We found the other point of view was far more prevalent. The other point of view is the one that we have reflected in our report.

In the hearings involving the department I do not actually recall hearing or, indeed, reading anything which had not previously come to light in this chamber, in estimates, in Professor Pearce's reports or in the documents. I think there were about 2000 pages of documents that were tabled in this chamber.

What that part of the inquiry came down to is this: the whole pay-TV process was a disaster. We all know that. The disaster started years ago with Aussat. It was magnified by the legislation that was forced on this country last year by the government and the opposition and which then had to be corrected. That correction involved an accumulation of omissions, mistakes and, most of all by far, unforeseen consequences. I must say that, in some cases, the Democrats did foresee those consequences, but people would not listen to us. Fortunately, they were forced to in the end.

The minister has acknowledged his own and his officers' shortcomings in the tendering process. It now comes down to the vital question of whether the minister is able and willing to correct the problems which have been identified. A lot of problems have been identified and we want to see that they are corrected. That is what the second part of this report is about. I believe the second part of the report is vital to this whole inquiry. That is when we find out whether the minister has fulfilled his ministerial responsibilities in a mature and reasonable way.

I do not want to take up much more of the Senate's time, but I must say that I am very disappointed with the dissenting report by Senator Alston and Senator Tierney. It does seem to me that mentioning the minister's size in this dissenting report is most unnecessarily personally offensive to the minister. I know the minister has a problem with his weight, but I do not think that needs to be put in a dissenting report. I have a very colourful turn of phrase on occasion, but I believe personal offensiveness in a report such as this is totally unnecessary. Not only is it totally unnecessary; it makes the dissenting report less credible than it could otherwise be. I recommend to any senators who are considering putting that sort of thing in any report that it just devalues their own report.

Senator Tierney has used his favourite quote from Winston Churchill: `I didn't know; I wasn't told; I should have asked'. I prefer the quote from Yes, Minister myself. The minister is told he should have asked a question, and he says, `But I didn't have the information to ask that question. How am I supposed to know what questions to ask?'. Sir Humphrey says, `That's the secret, Minister. We have to make sure you never know what questions to ask'. That is just as easily done to any individual or group in this place as it is to a minister. We have to keep in mind that we are not alone in that, and neither is the minister.

I am disappointed with this dissenting report. I do not believe that this inquiry allowed enough time—and this could be my fault too—for the opposition to adequately go through everything with the rest of us. The opposition was not interested in doing that, and that could have been a case of timing.

We have the second part of the report to go. I am really looking forward to this one being taken absolutely seriously by all of us and being a conclusive report. I hope the second part will be something that we all can agree on and that we are all proud to have our names associated with, as is the majority report of this first half of the report on pay-TV tendering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want the delay the chamber too long, but I want to comment on this very important report which has been presented here this afternoon by my colleague, the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes, Senator Cooney. The first matter I want to draw attention to could be overlooked due to some of the hyperbole that has been mentioned since the chairman of the committee brought down the report. Page 33 of the report lists the findings and conclusions of the committee. Speaking on behalf of the government members of the committee, I think we did give consideration to this matter. We did not merely stick our hands up because our hands were expected to go up at a particular point in time. We gave detailed consideration to whatever matter was before us. I believe our very measured conclusions reflect the deliberations that the government members put into this select committee.

PARA.TAB: In his contribution, Senator Cooney drew attention to a press statement released by Senator Alston on 20 August which outlined matters raised at one public meeting of the committee. If it were my wish to delay the Senate further, I would go on and speak about that meeting, but I would not speak as generously as Senator Alston did. However, I do not think that refuting back and forth across the chamber should happen. An agreement was reached by the committee in private session but, unfortunately, when we returned to public session, members of the committee who sit in the opposition benches then sought not to honour the agreement and a little political stunt was pulled for the benefit of the television cameras. I do not think that stunt damaged the committee in any way and I certainly do not believe it damaged the report. I hope that stunts like that will be put to one side when we continue with the second reference.

Speaking on behalf of the government members of the committee—and Senator Bourne may or may not agree with me—I believe that, from our point of view, the committee took an unusual step in its deliberations. The government senators agreed—and we did have the numbers to stop it; there is no question about that—that the minister appearing before the committee would be sin-binned while the public inquiry was going on. I was not totally in support and in favour of following this course of action. However, for the sake of the committee and the inquiry—because it is an important inquiry—we agreed to do that. We did not take the decision lightly, and I do not believe the minister was particularly pleased with our actions. But I think it shows to some extent the lengths that the committee was prepared go to in order to have full, open and deliberate discussions on the matter that the Senate had put before the select committee.

I want to spend a bit of time speaking about the minority report that has been presented by Senator Alston and Senator Tierney. Senator Tierney and his wife Pam had their 25th wedding anniversary last Saturday. We on all sides of the chamber congratulate them on achieving their 25th year of marriage. We wish them well for the next 25 years.

The minority report shows that there were obviously intrusions on the good senator's time in developing the minority report over the weekend. His mind was on other matters. To that extent, he did not spend the time examining the evidence that was presented to this committee at the various public hearings that were held. Unfortunately, Senator Tierney took the opportunity in the minority report to attack Professor Pearce and the Pearce reports. They had earlier been presented to and debated in the chamber and that was the time when criticism should have been made of Professor Pearce.

The two reports were presented: the first report, which related to the circumstances surrounding the non-requirement of a deposit for satellite pay-TV licences and related matters, was presented on 20 May; and the second report, which inquired into certain aspects of the MDS tendering process in 1992-93, was presented on 26 May. Obviously, Senator Tierney had other matters on his mind. I do not know what was on Senator Alston's mind; I will not speculate on that matter. But they went into some depth and some detail to have a crack at Professor Pearce. In paragraph 33, they started by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Pearce made no attempt to inquire why it was . . .
In paragraph 34, they conclude by saying:
. . . and that Pearce has not even commented on such absence.
Paragraph 35 reads:
. . . it beggars belief that Professor Pearce is able to say in paragraph 20 . . .
Paragraph 36 states:
It is also verging on the unbelievable that Pearce was unable to identify the origin . . .
Paragraph 37 reads:
Professor Pearce makes no criticism of the fact . . .
Paragraphs 39 states:
Professor Pearce finds it surprising that senior officers . . .
Paragraph 40 reads:
Pearce regards the failure to require a deposit as not constituting a change in departmental practice . . .
Paragraph 41 states:
Pearce simply notes that there were no discussions with the Minister . . .
Paragraph 42 states:

The findings by Professor Pearce in relation to Term of Reference number 4 are a complete whitewash and heavily reflect the tenor of remarks made publicly by Senator Collins and presumably repeated in private to Professor Pearce . . .
Paragraph 44 starts:
Professor Pearce said that in a perfect world . . .
Paragraph 45 reads:
Pearce implies that the Minister's advisers deserve criticism . . .

And so it goes on. Unfortunately, what appears to have happened is that, with his preoccupation with other matters over the weekend, all Senator Tierney has done is sort out the speaking notes that were prepared for him and Senator Alston when the Pearce reports were being debated in the parliament. They thought they might recycle for use in the debate on this report notes that were not used at that time. Senator Tierney and his colleague Senator Alston stand condemned for their actions in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The minority report goes to some length in reaching its conclusions in paragraph 69. It repeats in full a remark made by Senator Collins at a public hearing. Senator Collins said, `It is like an airline disaster'. This was also mentioned by Senator Alston a little time ago. I wonder why Senator Alston and Senator Tierney, either individually or together, did not examine the Senate Hansard. If they had wanted to pick up a quote in which Senator Collins likened the happenings in the pay TV debacle—we all agree that there have been some big problems with it—to something else, why did they not use a quote from the superior forum, the Senate, as opposed to a Senate committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —This was the most recent quote.

—What has happened here is that Senator Tierney was preoccupied over the weekend celebrating his 25th wedding anniversary. We again congratulate him on that. But the minority report is inadequate because it does not detail the full information. Senator Alston and Senator Tierney went for what was most recent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney also ought to be congratulated on the fact that not only were they able to have included at the beginning of the report Winston Churchill's quote `I did not know. I was not told. I should have asked', but they mentioned it again. That is really going over the top and filling out a minority report with something that is of no real help to the process. This really is not a minority report in the strictest sense of the word. We will certainly expect better from them when we consider the committee's second term of reference.

It is fair to say that in paragraphs 60 through to 68 of the minority report, Senator Tierney and Senator Alston have a go at Mr Meagher and the minister. Senator Tierney would be aware—and this is not mentioned in the minority report—that the committee sought advice from the Parliamentary Library to establish what precedents had occurred in this place or in the other chamber as to when a staffer, a member of a minister's staff, had been called to appear before a parliamentary committee. We sought that out; we asked the library for that information. The answer came back that it had never happened in the 93 years of the history of this parliament.

The committee took that matter into account when it deliberated and made its decision not to call Mr Meagher before it. We were acutely aware of the fact that, had we acceded to the request by Senators Alston and Tierney, we would be creating a precedent. After presenting the report, Senator Cooney went to some lengths to explain why we should not do that. I support the remarks made by Senator Cooney and also the remarks that he made during the deliberations of the committee.

I will add a further dimension to those remarks. I remind those opposite of one of the matters that Senator Cooney addressed in regard to the report. He said that if we established a precedent it might be possible down the line for committees, such as a select committee of the Senate, to be in a position to call an adviser to a leader of the opposition—for example, the person who advises the Leader of the Opposition on what might be put into a Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or an adviser to Mr Reith at the moment.

—Or, getting closer to home, perhaps even more interestingly, an adviser to Senator Bishop. Anyway, I did not want to waste too much time of the chamber. Let me add a further dimension to this matter—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you might try to help me with the interjections; they are becoming a bit overbearing. You can probably hear them better from where you are than I can from here; nonetheless, they are distracting.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Senator McKiernan, I will take on board your suggestions, but I am monitoring both sides of the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am aware that you are doing that. With your assistance, I will continue with the final point that I want to make on this very important report that has been tabled this afternoon—namely, the precedent of bringing in ministerial staff. Had we established a precedent in the case of Mr Meagher, it would be repeated down the line somewhere in the future. That precedent could be used to bring in not only ministerial staff and staff of presiding officers but also staff of members of parliament, including the staff of senators.
—Why did we talk to everyone except—
—Order! Senator Tierney, I would ask you to cooperate so that Senator McKiernan can make progress on his speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. A Ms Jackie Watkins is currently on my staff. It could be quite embarrassing if at some time in the future she were required to appear before a parliamentary committee because that particular individual happens to be my spouse. We have not been married 25 years like Senator Tierney and his good wife Pam have, but it would open a whole new set of doors if we set this precedent.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order: with the greatest respect, the standing orders do require relevance. I know that Senator McKiernan is trying to draw a parallel between Ms Watkins and certain staffing arrangements in Senator Collins's office, but it is my understanding that Mr Meagher is not Senator Collins's spouse. I am starting to think that this whole analogy is becoming irrelevant. It is showing how futile and thin the arguments are on the other side. I respectfully suggest to you that you ask him to become more relevant.
—Senator McKiernan has repeated that point on several occasions. He is being relevant. Nevertheless, I will listen closely and I will monitor his speech to make sure that relevance is maintained.

—Had Senator O'Chee been listening rather than interjecting, he might have heard that I was talking about a point of precedence which the committee addressed. This is contained in the report, which he obviously has not read and probably would never read. The other thing he probably would not understand is the relationship between husband and wife.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making is that the precedent can go much further than the individual precedent of calling Mr Meagher before a parliamentary inquiry on this particular occasion. Once the precedent is established it is possible that it will be used by this chamber or the other chamber. A future parliament may seek to use it. I think that is an awfully dangerous precedent to set. The minister said when he appeared before the committee that he could answer any questions that were going to be directed to Mr Meagher.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one challenged that either.
—No questions were directed to the minister. Nobody challenged the fact that Senator Collins could not do it.

PARA.TAB: It is more than unfortunate that the opposition members of the committee did not approach this inquiry in a spirit of getting to the bottom of the matter set out in the terms of reference that we were given by the chamber to investigate. Instead, they tried to turn it into a political football. That has been resisted by the majority report that has been brought in here this evening. When members of the public analyse what the majority report contains, they will reach their own conclusions and dismiss what those opposite put forward in their minority report simply for what it is—political rhetoric of a very low order.
Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the Senate's resolution of yesterday concerning the tabling of Prismod related modelling results, I table a letter from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and attached documents. I seek leave to make a very brief statement with regard to these documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in the speech in relation to this matter, it has not been possible to comply with the literal terms of the resolution because many—perhaps all—of the documents requested to be tabled do not exist. Nevertheless there are some documents which I think are an indication of Prismod estimates of budget revenue measures dated 16 August; Prismod estimates of distributional affects of selected budget revenue and outlays measures dated 27 August; some explanatory memoranda, and a letter from the Treasurer to me dated today outlining the background to the documents which are tabled.
