This adds to the fact that there has been more of this information provided with regard to this budget than any other. Accordingly, I table the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Without having seen the documents that Senator McMullan has just tabled nor the letter from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) accompanying those documents, it is impossible to give a full response to Senator McMullan's action, other than to make a couple of points. First, the order to return of the Senate called on the government to respond and to lay these documents on the table by 5 o'clock today. I note that that time was not met. I understand that it was close to it, but nevertheless I make that point.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, and again in relation to what is contained in the documents, I note that Senator McMullan has said that it is not possible for the government to reply literally to the requests made of it by the Senate yesterday because—and I think I quote him fairly accurately—many of the documents do not exist. That is not a sufficient reason for refusing to comply with the order of the Senate. The whole history of the concept of a return to order goes back hundreds of years into the British parliamentary system. The whole purpose of it was to request governments to provide the parliaments of the day with information required by the parliament in terms of its legitimate role of being the custodian and to take account of people's rights, and also the need to hold governments of the day accountable and responsible for their actions.

The fact that the material does not literally exist at the moment is no valid defence of the fact that apparently the government has not complied with the return to order of the Senate. Indeed, we had a similar situation just a few months ago where the government did comply with such an order, which was moved by Senator Harradine, requiring documentation in relation to some work involving Australia Post. Those documents did not exist at the time that Senator Harradine made his request either, but the government did comply with the order by getting the necessary documentation done. So it is a totally specious and false defence that Senator McMullan has given in that sense.

Not to answer an order to return is a very serious contempt of the Senate in respect of a matter quite fundamental to its essential role; namely, the scrutiny and passage of budget legislation. Failure to answer a return to order of any nature is a very serious contempt of the Senate. That is what the government appears to have done tonight. It has continued its practice of holding the parliament, and in particular this chamber, in contempt. It has done it in a technical way tonight as well as in terms of the spirit of the government's feelings on this. The opposition will let this matter rest.

I understand and acknowledge the fact that the government was given a brief period in which to reply to the Senate's request. For that reason, I will not be moving any further action on the matter tonight, but will request the government to reconsider the matter. If Senator McMullan, who on behalf of the government has just committed a major contempt of the Senate, has the courtesy to face us, to stop reading a paper and listen to something that is pretty serious, I want to ask him whether the government will reconsider the matter over the next couple of weeks, given that the Senate is not sitting at that time, or whether the government is now complete and adamant in its response that it will not provide any further information. I ask him to answer that when I finish my remaining few words.

It is not credible for the government to say that it cannot obtain the material that has been sought by the Senate in its return to order. The material that is being sought was line ball with the material that was provided by the government to the parliament. Admittedly we had to draw the government's teeth to table the material in March 1992. That information related to material that was prepared in the latter part of 1991 concerning the opposition's taxation and expenditure proposals contained in Fightback. That information made it quite clear that material of the nature being sought in this return to order request by the Senate was available then. The Treasury's Prismod model, which had been set up solely for the purpose of analysing the coalition's Fightback policies, and the other modelling that is done in association with it can provide the material that has now been requested.

In March 1992, the then minister in his tabling statement referred to the analysis that had been conducted in the Treasury using the new Prismod model—or, to put it in full, the price revenue incidents simulation model, which models the impact of changes, particularly of a taxation nature but also outlays, on households and individuals.
That analysis was done at that time. Indeed, the statement the government tabled in March last year in connection with the various tables that were presented stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The remaining 12 tables bring together our modelling of the distributional implications of all of the individual components of the Opposition tax and expenditure package, including
.indirect tax changes;
.compensation arrangements and other increases in transfer payments;
.the effects of bracket creep;
.certain expenditure cuts;
.illustrative household specific price effects of the health proposals described above; and
.the hypothetical roads charging proposals . . .

Those items—the indirect changes, the effects of bracket creep and several others—are all fundamental to the government's budget this year. All those things contained in this Keating budget of 1993—the government's 55 per cent increase in the wine tax, its increase of between 10 and 20 per cent across the board on all sales taxes in Australia and its increase of up to 7c in fuel prices, which was to have been 10c—have significant distributional effects on households right throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: If this parliament and this Senate are to properly do their job of analysing and considering, on behalf of the Australian people, the implications of the 1993 budget—a budget that has never been exceeded in terms of the degree of public disquiet and disgust at it—then it is quite essential that that distributional analysis be obtained. If it has not been prepared, it can be prepared.

I do not accept at all the explanation that Senator McMullan has given tonight. As I say, we have not seen the documents he has tabled. We will look at them and decide the best course of further action to be taken with a view—this is the bottom line of all of this—to obtaining a situation where we can, on behalf of the Australian electorate, do our job as a Senate, as the elected representatives of the people, in analysing the impact of this very harsh, very cruel and very unfair budget on all Australians.

I am amazed that the person on whom the return to order was in effect served—that is, the Leader of the Government in the Senate; not Senator McMullan but Senator Gareth Evans—has not done the courtesy of responding. I am amazed as well that Senator McMullan sees fit to come in here and, without any adequate explanation at all, commit what is certainly a most serious contempt of this chamber and arguably as serious a contempt of this chamber as can be committed. I can assure Senator McMullan that we will be pursuing this matter further at the appropriate time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the first report of the Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes, which is a split report. We have a majority report from the government members of the committee and a minority report from the opposition members. The majority report is totally unacceptable to the opposition. Let me pay tribute to Senator Cooney, who in the last few days has been trying to bridge the yawning gap between the view of the government and that of the opposition on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The conclusion the government members finally came to was that Senator Collins has discharged his ministerial responsibilities in relation to the satellite and MDS tendering process. The opposition does not accept that. They gave him a pass and I just wonder what a minister in government has to do to get a fail. Since the month of May when this matter broke, we have had an absolute debacle which in a sense is continuing as the very poorly thought out pay TV tendering process runs its course.

I was very disappointed by the contributions made before dinner on this matter. Senator Bourne spent most of her time talking about some absolutely obscure reference which she thought was a personal reflection of the physical attributes of the minister. It was so obscure that I had to read it several times to find it. Half of the speech was devoted to that. Seeing as the Democrats seem to be controlling the country at the moment, there does not seem to be much hope for us if that is the best they can contribute.

Senator McKiernan made a very long speech and filibustered very well to play out his time. He spent a lot of time talking about my 25th wedding anniversary. It was not a honeymoon; it was a 25th wedding anniversary. It did not really distract me greatly from the writing of this report.

The report we have written is in response to the enormous amount of time spent in the Senate and in the press and discussion in the media generally on what has been an absolute shambles in terms of running a government department. We believe our response is really the only realistic response to the inadequate and incompetent handling of this department.

It is amazing that this minister has retained his position. He has embarrassed the government to the extent that in May it actually dropped in the polls. We have become the laughing stock of the overseas investment community, and Australian business that wanted to get seriously involved in the pay TV issue and take part in the development of this exciting new industry has been left in total confusion.

One would wonder why the minister took the approach that he did. If he knew anything about the history of the Department of Transport and Communications, he should have realised that a duty of care was necessary with a department that has had a very troubled history. Let me quote from what one of the icons of the Labor Party, Mr Whitlam, said at the hearing in Melbourne. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The department concerned is the inheritor and the amalgamation of the two greatest disaster areas in federal administration during the 1980s. The department, in both its character, the electronic media and transport, has clearly been staffed at crucial levels by incompetent people.

If we take the track record of the department and add to it the very rapidly changing technology in communications in this country and the fact that we are restructuring that industry and moving from a monopoly position to competition and if we have a situation where the department has been `administered'—for want of a better term—by six different Labor ministers in a very short period of time, one would think we would have a minefield, a disaster waiting to happen. Given that history, the minister's approach, in which he has not shown a duty of care, is quite astounding. He certainly has not been on top of his department; he has been on tap, but he has not been on top.

PARA.TAB: I think both the satellite pay TV and the MDS tendering processes have shown that the minister did not know what was going on, and he did not ask. Although the other side does not like me using the quote from Churchill, let me put it on the Senate record. At the fall of Singapore, Churchill said:

SPEECH.PARA: I did not know; I was not told; I should have asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of what possible relevance is that?

—It is of relevance. There were a lot of questions the minister did not ask; he did not even think to ask them. Surely, if we are moving into a new technology, like pay television, and we are expecting people to invest in a multimillion dollar industry, an industry worth hundreds of millions of dollars, it is not just any old bit of paper the minister is signing; it is a very vital determination. If the minister did not understand it, he should have made sure he had support staff there at the time who did understand it and who could advise him and say, `Hey, Minister, how about the five per cent deposit? That is not here. Sometimes with the tendering processes of the department of communications we have deposits; at other times we don't have deposits. There should have been a deposit here'. That is what an adviser worth his salt would have done; in this particular case it did not happen.

PARA.TAB: The minister's excuse was quite pathetic. He said, `Well, I sight hundreds of documents'. But this was no ordinary document. He should have understood what he was signing. Since May he has been trying to blame everyone but himself. He said at first in May that it was the department's fault; he said it was the election's fault. But, really, he hit the nail right on the head in the hearings into pay TV—and I think it will go down as one of the classic quotes in Australian politics. Again let me tell the Senate what he said. In describing the pay television tendering processes, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's like an airline disaster . . . The reason you rarely have an airline disaster is that it is a collection of a whole series of failures . . . The bureaucracy narrows down very quickly to a couple of people in the cockpit of the aircraft—if you like, my senior adviser, sitting in the seat next to me, and me as the captain of the aircraft, as the Minister, finally. When errors occur that combine failures on the ground, in the control tower, in the systems management and finally compounded in the cockpit, you get a disaster. I think the analogy is exact and I am part of that disaster.
After saying that the minister should have offered his resignation straight away.

PARA.TAB: What are the standards of public administration in this country? Can ministers actually do anything, have no duty of care and just let any disaster happen? What would happen in private enterprise? How long would a CEO who took that broad approach last? But that seems to be the approach that we have had here.

Probably most disturbing about the approach—and certainly about the whole history of this inquiry—is that, even though we have been able to talk to every relevant public servant who had anything to do with this, from a fair way down in the department of communications all the way up to the minister, there was one vital piece missing. That was the co-pilot—to continue with the minister's analogy—Mr Meagher. He seems to have possessed some critical information. That seems to be our view. But, according to the minister, no, he could speak on Mr Meagher's behalf. Why could Mr Meagher not speak for himself?

We had hearings here in Canberra and the government used its numbers to block the committee calling Mr Meagher. I think that made the situation worse. If Mr Meagher had nothing to hide, why did he not come before the committee? It just left everyone wondering. The suspicion is accentuated by the fact that, when I was looking over the final report, I could not find any reference in the last section to Mr Meagher. I went back to the first draft, and there it was all set out. Somehow between the first and last draft it mysteriously disappeared. Is it any wonder we do not have any confidence in the government report? That is one of the reasons why I think we were quite right to bring in a minority report.

The main thrust of the government report, of course, is to absolve Senator Collins. The basis on which government members would do this largely goes back to what I call the Wran line in the hearings. Ex-Labor Premiers Wran and Cain said that determining mini-sterial responsibility and whether a minister should be sacked or not was really a judgment based on the severity of the minister's misconduct. It was not really that, but it was the reaction—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Tories didn't disagree either.

—To the public media. I ask Senator Loosley to have a look back at what Mr Hamer said. I do not think he took that line. Mr Wran, a former barrister, had a brief to defend the minister, so he put as liberal an interpretation on the whole matter as was possible. Really, he just said that the whole thing is a political exercise. But the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, as we argue in our minority report, is far too important to be treated as a political exercise.

PARA.TAB: What do other former leaders say about this matter? Former Prime Ministers Hawke and Fraser rightly supported the maximum penalty of ministerial resignation in situations where a bungle of key importance to Australia's future occurred in a department. They made moral judgments on these matters and decided that the minister is responsible to the parliament and the people—not just to the party. This judgment should be reflected in a call for resignation by the Prime Minister of the day. It certainly should have happened in this case.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should assess the seriousness of the minister's actions, rather than what the effect of those actions is likely to be on the government's popularity. Instead of ministerial resignation being a means to remove pressure from the government, it should be a means to make the minister responsible to the Prime Minister, the parliament and the public.

I will not spend more time going through the section in our minority report relating to the satellite tendering process and also the section of the report relating to the MDS tendering process. Senator Alston has covered this in great detail, and people who want to read more about it should read the full report.

In conclusion, I return to Senator Collins's reference to this matter being like an airline disaster. He said, `I am part of the disaster'. I remind senators that the minister is the vital link between the cabinet and his department He therefore has a duty of care to ensure that cabinet decisions are carried out properly. If the minister fails to understand what he is implementing through his and his department's actions, then I ask: what is the point of having a minister?

Prime Minister Keating should heed his own words and put morality and ethics above politics in this matter. Senator Collins made Australia an international laughing stock and instead of accepting ministerial responsibility tried to shift the blame. He has so mishandled this policy area that I am highly surprised he has not resigned or the Prime Minister has not called for his resignation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the majority report as well as to address some of the issues raised previously in the debate. The first thing that ought to be said is that it is not a government report; it is a majority report. Senator Tierney's terminology is designed to be a deliberate slight of Senator Bourne. Senator Bourne exercised her own judgment and discretion, worked through the report and came to a conclusion which is shared by a majority of senators on the committee. Senator Tierney said some other things about Senator Bourne in the course of his remarks and I will come to those a little later.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the manner in which the committee has operated, time and time again Senator Cooney has gone out of his way to be fair and reasonable to the coalition. Time and time again he has been much harder on Senator McKiernan and me, in terms of the manner in which the committee has conducted its business, than he has been on Senator Alston or Senator Tierney. That is simply a matter of record, as honourable senators can see from looking at the committee deliberations in some detail.

When the opposition has resorted to the crudest possible stunts because of the presence of a television camera—klieg light politics—and when it has resorted to the absolute crudities of politics, Senator Cooney, in the chair, has endeavoured to maintain his equilibrium and has turned aside the protests of Senator McKiernan and me. Agreements reached in private session have been broken in open session because the coalition, having descended totally into oppositionism, is now capable only of trying to grab 17 seconds on the evening news. There is no way in which those opposite can fashion a reasoned response to the majority report of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the minority report.

—There is nothing in the minority report that can be described as anything other than unsubstantiated assertion and hyperbole. There is no factual basis or substance to it. If the coalition had worked through the committee's deliberations in the manner in which Senator Cooney, Senator McKiernan, Senator Bourne and, I hope, I have done, those opposite could not possibly have come to the conclusions that they reached. There is no question about that whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: The chamber ought to be aware that on the final day of public hearings Senator Tierney ran out of questions to ask Minister Collins or the department. Senator Alston was absent from the committee. A search party had to be sent for him. Senator Cooney left the chair and made a phone call looking for Senator Alston. Minister Collins volunteered to check the neighbouring men's room for him.

Where had Senator Alston disappeared to? The fact of the matter was that Senator Alston was off drafting a press statement accusing the committee of being involved in a cover-up. He was not even prepared to be there in open session asking the questions that supposedly were so vital to clarification of these issues. The chamber ought to be aware of this because, frankly, the committee has been a waste of taxpayers' money. Members of the coalition did not come into it with open minds. They did not come into it with any approach of fairness or commonsense. It was an absolute waste of taxpayers' money.

The problem with some of the parliamentary committees that we have established of recent times is that an absolute and utter waste of taxpayers' funds has been the only consequence. In this circumstance the coalition was never prepared to come to any conclusion other than to continue the personal vendetta against Senator Collins to which Senator Bourne referred earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the Hansard record and you will see why.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! Senator Tierney, I would ask you to allow the honourable senator to complete his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —The process has been nothing short of the most abysmal waste of taxpayers' funds. I turn to ministerial responsibility. We had a day's hearings in Melbourne. Some of the contributors have been referred to earlier in the debate. I was impressed by the manner in which Sir Rupert Hamer gave evidence. Mr John Cain, Mr Neville Wran and Mr Gough Whitlam, among others, also gave evidence. I think former Senator Macklin also gave evidence. Again, regrettably—Senator McKiernan might be able to refresh my memory—I think Senator Alston was missing.
—Yes, again.

—Again, this was vital, but Senator Alston was missing on the very day that we had agreed that we would take evidence from a range of people across the political spectrum on what ministerial responsibility meant in the modern Australian political context. It was agreed by just about all the commentators and all present that, by far, the best observation was made by Mr Neville Wran, who said that it was not possible to define the notion of ministerial responsibility.
—He had a brief from the government.

—Senator Tierney guffaws—it might be the most considered political response of which he is capable—but he did not challenge that on the day in the Melbourne Parliament House. After Mr Wran's evidence, virtually everybody at the table who had contributed earlier agreed with his assessment.

PARA.TAB: Mr Wran's assessment ran along these lines: it is not possible to define ministerial responsibility other than to look at the political circumstance confronting the prime minister or the premier of the day, the context in the parliament, the notion of the mistake or the misdemeanour, and the appropriate political response. Everyone agreed with that. Later on that night, on Lateline, Mr Whitlam and Mr Wran again talked at some length. A similar conclusion was reached. The simple fact of the matter was that, when put to the test, that was the best conclusion that the committee could reach.

If we take that a logical step further, we see that Senator Collins has not breached any Australian notion of ministerial responsibility. We sat there for hour after hour and worked this matter through, unfortunately in the absence of Senator Alston, who probably was writing another press release, was missing or was late.

In the chamber it is a different matter. In the chamber it is grandstanding; it is oppositionism. When the work is there to be done, he is missing—absent. In the chamber, or under the klieg lights, it is grandstanding, which is all we have seen from the coalition in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stunts and grandstanding.

—Senator McKiernan is absolutely right—just stunts. Those opposite have the gall to come in here and trash Senator Bourne for having come to a similar conclusion, when all the evidence leads inevitably to the conclusion that the majority of the committee has reached. If we look at the conclusion reached, we see that Senator Bourne has made more of a contribution than either of the coalition senators. She has suggested clauses that should be incorporated and changes in the language and terminology. This has not been the case with the coalition.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney actually bent over backwards and went much further than anybody else on this side of the chamber would have gone to arrive at a consensus, to try to group everyone under the umbrella of a consensus finding, based on the evidence and based on the submissions. The coalition was never prepared to accept that.

The minority report is nothing other than hyperbole. There is a remark about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What on earth does that remark about the Prime Minister have to do with Minister Collins's responsibility? There is no evidence to suggest that Minister Collins breached any concept of ministerial responsibility. As a matter of fact, in terms of Minister Collins giving evidence to the committee, the coalition was so concerned about what he might say that we spent more time discussing where the minister should sit in relation to the committee than was spent at the Paris peace talks when they were trying to seat the NLF in 1972.

In the end there was a compromise that he should sit off to one side. This only lasted a day or so; then the minister was seated with his bureaucratic advisers, similar to the estimates committee procedure, which Senator McKiernan and I had argued should apply. The chairman, in order to be fair to the coalition, had agreed upon its proposition. This only lasted a day and was seen as being totally impractical.

At one stage I suggested to some of the departmental advisers who were giving evidence that all they should do was read the transcript of previous answers to the committee into the transcript of that day's hearings because all Senator Tierney and Senator Alston could do was repeat the questions they had asked either in the chamber or at the committee—not for the second or third time, but for the sixth or seventh or eighth time. It was a classic display of lack of originality. The process was so tedious, as Senator Tierney alleged earlier, because of the absolute and utter lack of originality on the part of the coalition.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to look in this report and find one original idea from the coalition senators, one original question in any of the transcripts of the committee's deliberations in any of the hearings, or to find anything new. That is why they ran out of material. That is why Senator Alston had to disappear and write yet another press statement. We were so impressed with the press release that Senator Cooney wanted to incorporate it in the committee's findings. It was just a nonsense.

It would be comical in total if public funds were not being wasted on this nonsensical approach to politics. The coalition ought to be able to do better. The simple fact of the matter is that we have now had more than 70 questions on this matter in the chamber. We have now had eight debates—this is the eighth debate—on this matter. There is absolutely nothing new in anything that Senator Alston or Senator Tierney have said today—nothing new; not an original thought.

People on this side of the chamber and people in the Democrats have actually tried to work the matter through and come to a logical conclusion. That is why there is a degree of non-partisanship on the basis of the majority report. The partisanship is to be found opposite from Senator Tierney and, again, from the absent Senator Alston. I anticipate yet another press release later tonight. Again, unfortunately, Senator Alston is absent. But I say to the Senate: look at the transcripts; look at the deliberations; look at the evidence; look at the hearings. There is no other conclusion possible. As for Minister Collins, he could not have been more accessible to the committee; he could not have been more open with the committee. Taking the words from Senator Tierney directly, `He could not have been more honest with the committee'. Where fault was to be found, he accepted it and the majority of the committee members respected that. The opposition endeavoured to restrict Senator Collins in what he might make by way of contribution but, in spite of that, he was accessible, he was open and he was honest.

Senator Tierney referred to the yawning gap which existed on the committee. Honestly! The only yawning that took place was that done by the government senators on the basis of the questions being asked ad nauseam, time and time again. That brings me to the point about all of the departmental advisers being called before the committee time and time again. It is similar to people being required to attend estimates committee hearings at 3 a.m., 4 a.m. or 5 a.m. Look at the waste involved in that—the waste of energy and endeavour and the waste of public funds.

This is a manifestation of oppositionism—an absolute reflection of oppositionism. No matter how much those opposite caterwaul, they cannot get around that. Those opposite are really sliding away. It reminds me of what the Labor Party was like in the early 1960s. That is how grim things are opposite. It took us a decade to come out of opposition; it will take those opposite another decade the way they are going.

Senator Tierney referred to a debacle. This committee has been a debacle. We are lucky that the report is so good, that it is possessed of such clarity and such reasoned conclusions, and Senator Cooney and the secretary can take credit for that. Senator Bourne made some suggestions and alterations. Senator McKiernan and I were happy to endorse the findings. But the committee has been a debacle.

When people deliberately come aboard an endeavour for the express purpose of making nothing other than political nonsense, it will be a debacle every time and the Senate really ought to take note of that. It really needs to take on board the manner in which we create some of these select committees. I think there is a place in the system for select committees, as I think there is a place for joint and standing committees, but there is no place for manipulation and the sheer indulgence of oppositionism.

I thought the remarks of Senator Bourne earlier in the debate were entirely appropriate. I defend her on the basis of respect for a colleague in the chamber but, more importantly, I defend her on the basis that she is a friend, and friendship has to count for more than politics. Senator Bourne brought a greater sense of perspective and realism to the report than anybody else who sat on the committee. She has a specific portfolio responsibility, which neither Senator McKiernan, nor Senator Cooney, nor I have. In Senator Alston's case, we could have been forgiven for thinking that his policy expertise was to be found in trade or foreign policy rather than in communications, given the lack of expertise demonstrated during the committee's deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's get back to the topic.

—That brings me to the impact—I thank Senator Bell. It is an issue of fairness. It is also an issue of decency. This is not an issue in the broad Australian community; it is not an issue in Newcastle or Sydney or Melbourne. There is no breach of ministerial responsibility here, full stop. I defy honourable senators to contradict that statement. On any reasonable assessment of the evidence it is impossible to reach anything other than that conclusion.

PARA.TAB: The Australian electorate is not obsessed with pay television in the way that Senator Tierney and Senator Alston would suggest in the chamber. Time and time again, the coalition has sought to make this an issue in the broad community. We saw the Canberra Times leak in the past 24 hours or so. Time and time again, people have tried to whip this issue up into an issue of community concern. It is not. The debate tonight will not cause that to alter.

I draw particular attention to Senator Tierney's reference to Mr Whitlam. At Senator Cooney's request, I asked Mr Whitlam to appear before the committee. He made a first class contribution, as always. What Senator Tierney did not tell the chamber was that Mr Whitlam's contribution, manifesting itself by way of absolute contempt for the performance of communications during the last political generation or so, was a specific reference to conservative governments; that what he said about the changes which had occurred was a specific reference to conservative governments. If we look at the transcript, that is borne out.

I say again: despite the Churchillian quotes which represent only a gesture of imperial loyalty by Senator Tierney, despite all that nonsense about Singapore and so on—those people opposite really ought to grow up—the minority report throws no light on anything. There is no original conclusion to be drawn. There is nothing new in anything that has been said in the chamber by either Senator Tierney or Senator Alston. As for the trashing of Senator Bourne, it is routine for the coalition to trash the Democrats—for what purpose, it escapes me, but it is routine. The majority report has confirmed the findings of Pearce. The Pearce report stood the test of another round of intense scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a lot more money.

—A lot more money has been spent on the exercise, as Senator Sherry correctly observes. The Pearce report is again confirmed, as it has been confirmed time and time again in the chamber and elsewhere. I daresay, given the test of time, given the sweep of Australian history—not British history—it will be borne out yet again. What Pearce found was right. Based on the facts, no breach of ministerial responsibility occurred. That is what the committee concluded. The second report will probably make more interesting reading than the first in terms of its sweep and its breadth. I predict this with absolute certainly: without a word of evidence having been taken, there will be a minority report from Senator Tierney and the absent Senator Alston.
—What nonsense.

—There will be a minority report. Let us put it on the record. Senator Tierney says, `What nonsense'. We will see, come the end of the year. I do not know what Senator Bourne will say on the committee during the months ahead. I do know what Senator Tierney will say; I do know what Senator Alston will say. Senator Cooney will again—probably against my better judgment and against Senator McKiernan's better judgment—endeavour to be very fair and very reasonable to people who are unfair and unreasonable, not only in their conduct, not only in their behaviour, but in their conclusions. I support the majority report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum. I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, this bill will amend the tax laws to give effect to a number of changes arising from the 1993-94 budget.
I propose to outline briefly the measures contained in this bill. More detailed explanations of the measures are contained in the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable senators.
Personal tax cuts
The amendments contained in the bill will change the timing for the commencement of the two stage reduction in the tax rates announced in One Nation on 26 February 1992.

The first stage will now commence on 15 November 1993, seven and a half months earlier than scheduled. The bill provides that the second stage of tax cuts will commence at the beginning of a financial year to be fixed by regulation.

Because the first stage of the tax cuts will commence on 15 November 1993, the bill contains the new composite rate scales to apply for 1993-94 and the first stage rates for the 1994-95 and later income years.
The new rates to apply from 15 November 1993 will benefit taxpayers with taxable incomes in excess of $20,700.
The tax cuts will cost the revenue $1.55 billion this financial year. The ongoing cost to revenue of the first stage of the personal tax cuts is $2.9 billion in 1994-95 and $3.12 billion in 1995-96.
Low income rebate

The bill will also provide a rebate of up to $150 to taxpayers whose taxable income for 1993-94 and subsequent income years is less than $24,450. The new rebate will mainly assist those taxpayers who do not benefit from the One Nation tax cuts.

Taxpayers with a taxable income of up to $20,700 will be entitled to a rebate of $150 in their assessments for the 1993-94 and later income years. The rebate will reduce at the rate of 4 cents in each dollar of taxable income in excess of $20,700 and completely phase-out when taxable income reaches $24,450.
The estimated revenue costs for this measure are $530 million in 1994-95, $515 million in 1995-96 and $500 million in 1996-97.
Medicare levy
The bill will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the low income thresholds below which people will not be required to pay any levy.
For 1993-94, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $12,688 and couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $21,366 will not be required to pay the levy.
There will be no change to the provisions which increase the threshold for couples and sole parents by $2100 for each dependent child or student.
The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $30 million in 1993-94, $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Unused annual leave and unused long service leave payments
The bill will remove the concessional tax treatment that applies to lump sum payments of unused annual leave and unused long service leave made on termination of employment.

Payments in respect of unused long service leave accrued on or after 18 August 1993 and payments in respect of unused annual leave made on or after 18 August 1978 will be taxed as normal income. However, there is no change to the tax treatment of these payments if the taxpayer's termination of employment is as a consequence of bona fide redundancy or invalidity or is under an approved early retirement scheme. Nor is the concessional tax treatment of long service leave accrued before 18 August 1993 affected.
The proposed amendments ensure that the tax system does not discourage taxpayers from using their leave entitlements for their intended purpose.
The estimated gain to the revenue is $80 million in 1993-94, $180 million in 1994-95, $165 million in 1995-96 and $180 million in 1996-97.
Taxation of credit unions

The bill will remove the exemption from income tax for income in the nature of interest received by credit unions on loans made to their members and will allow credit unions to be taxed as cooperatives where they satisfy the requirements for that treatment. To give credit unions time to adjust to the new measures, there will be a phasing-in period.

The measure will remove the competitive advantage credit unions enjoy as a result of the special tax treatment given to them, and is consistent with the government's general approach of ensuring tax neutrality between business enterprises.
The estimated gain to revenue is $25 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in 1996-97.
Taxation of friendly societies and other registered organisations
The bill will change the taxation treatment of friendly societies and other registered organisations.
It will phase-out, over three years from the 1994-95 income year, the concessional tax rate for friendly societies in respect of their life insurance and certain other insurance business.

As a consequence of that change, the bill will, from 1 July 1994, extend to friendly societies the same entitlement to deductions as is allowed to life insurance companies for the costs of getting in their life insurance premiums.

Another change will increase, from 1 July 1995, the rebate available to holders of friendly society life policies who are assessed on bonuses. This increase is a consequence of the phasing-out of the concessional tax rate.
The estimated gain to revenue from these measures is $25 million in 1995-96 and $69 million in 1996-97.
Car parking expenses for self-employed

The bill will also amend the income tax law so that, from 1 July 1994, a tax deduction for the cost of car parking for persons other than employees will be denied in certain circumstances. This will place car parking by self-employed persons on a comparable tax basis to car parking for employees.

A deduction for car parking expenses incurred by self-employed persons will only be denied where certain conditions apply. The rules for determining the non-deductible amount of a car parking expense in this bill are similar to the rules applicable to employers in valuing a car parking fringe benefit.
The estimated gain to revenue of this measure is $70 million in 1995-96 and $35 million in 1996-97.
Non-deductible expenses

The income tax law will also be amended to allow deductions to employers for expenses incurred in providing their employees with a range of benefits such as entertainment, club fees, leisure facilities, travel expenses of accompanying relatives, Higher Education Contribution Scheme payments and Student Financial Supplement Scheme payments. These expenses have previously not been deductible.

Benefits of this nature, if provided to employees, are fringe benefits under the fringe benefits tax law. However, the taxable value of these benefits is reduced to the extent to which they are non-deductible to employers under the income tax law.

This amendment, which will apply from 1 April 1994, will allow a deduction to employers for these expenses under the income tax law. In consequence, it will subject these benefits to a fringe benefits tax liability.
The estimated gain to revenue is $435 million in 1994-95, $240 million in 1995-96 and $240 million in 1996-97.
FBT rate of tax

This bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the current rate of fringe benefits tax from 48.25 per cent to 48.4 per cent. The increase will take effect from 1 April 1994 and will maintain the alignment of the FBT rate with the top marginal personal tax rate and Medicare levy rate. The increase reflects the increase in the Medicare levy rate, from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent, on 1 July 1993.
The estimated gain to revenue is $9 million in 1994-95 and $8 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Excess domestic travel

This bill will amend the fringe benefits tax law to impose fringe benefits tax on the amount of a travelling allowance received by an employee for travel in Australia which is in excess of a prescribed amount. The amount will be prescribed by regulation.

The income tax law will also be amended to disallow expenditure incurred by employees or self-employed persons on travel expenses (i.e. accommodation, food, drink, and expenditure incidental to travel undertaken in Australia) which are in excess of the prescribed amount.
The estimated gain to revenue is $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Sales tax

Mr President, I now turn to the three sales tax changes proposed in the bill. The first change will increase all sales tax rates by one percentage point, with effect from midnight tonight. This is expected to raise $435 million this year and $585 million in 1994-95. A further one percentage point increase for all sales tax rates will come into effect on 1 July 1995.

The second change will increase the rates of sales tax on wine, also with effect from midnight tonight. Compared to beer and spirits, wine is lightly taxed. While it is presently subject to sales tax, it does not carry any excise.
It is proposed to increase the rate of tax on wine with an alcoholic content of greater than 1.15 per cent from 20 per cent to 31 per cent.

The rate of tax on low-alcohol wine, that is wine with an alcoholic content of 1.15 per cent or less, is to increase from 10 per cent to 21 per cent. Some low-alcohol wine is currently taxable at 20 per cent and its rate of tax will increase to 21 per cent in line with the proposed increase for all sales tax rates.
The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated to be $70 million in 1993-94, $95 million in 1994-95, $105 million in 1995-96 and $110 million in 1996-97.

The last sales tax change will vary the rate of tax applicable to luxury motor vehicles, also with effect from midnight tonight. Luxury vehicles are currently taxable at 30 per cent on their entire wholesale value. The current sales tax treatment results in a substantial pricing distortion: the addition of one dollar to the wholesale price of a passenger motor vehicle now priced at the threshold would increase the sales tax liability by $4873.

It is proposed to remove this distortion by applying a split rate of sales tax to luxury motor vehicles. Broadly, the ordinary rates of sales tax applicable to motor vehicles will apply up to wholesale luxury threshold. A rate of 45 per cent will apply to that portion of the wholesale value over the luxury threshold.
The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated to be $5 million in 1993-94 and $10 million in 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the Explanatory Memorandum being circulated to honourable senators.
Mr President, I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities and be taken together.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
That these bills be now read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 is one of the trio of so-called deficit reduction bills. That is a classic misnomer as far as at least one of them is concerned—that is, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill—because this year the budget is aiming for an increase in the deficit, not a reduction. The first thing to be said about the trio of bills is that some of them are misleading in their description.

PARA.TAB: The Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill deals specifically with the petrol and tobacco duty slugs announced in the 17 August budget and the additional increases in those charges that have been announced since then as we have moved successively through budget mark 2 and budget mark 3—and I have no doubt that we will soon have budget mark 4. It is that budget and its subsequent rejigging that I wish to say a few words about in this first reading debate.

`Rejigging' is far too polite a term for what has happened to this budget because this first budget of the re-elected Keating Labor government has been absolutely gutted by the government itself in response to the pressure put on by the opposition since it was brought down. Never in my recollection—nor, I would guess, in the memories of very many other honourable senators—have we seen a budget which has unravelled from day one in such a short time as this budget has. It is no wonder, because this budget was the most directionless, harsh, cruel and inappropriate budget that has been brought down in our living memory. The first budget of the re-elected Keating government was supposed to set out the Labor vision for the medium term and reveal the government's thinking and policy on key policy problem areas in Australia. It was supposed to not only deal with the pressing immediate problems but also offer a long-term prospective.

Honourable senators will undoubtedly remember the great build-up to the budget along the lines that it would really put things into perspective for the medium term—a budget that dealt with the short-term problems but which, more importantly, had a path, a vision and an end objective of a better budgetary situation, higher standards of living, fewer unemployed, more jobs and a better quality of life for all Australians. Never have we seen a budget more to the contrary of that.

This budget is completely without vision, it offers no hope, no opportunity and no prospects for Australians for the future, and it has been seen as such not only in the general community but also in the business community and, indeed, internationally. If we look at what has happened to the Australian dollar since the budget details were announced and, more particularly, as it started progressively to unravel, it provides a very stark testimony to what has been an absolute disaster for this country economically, socially and politically.

The problems facing Australia are readily apparent. We have mass unemployment—the likes of which this country has never seen since the Great Depression—peaking at over 11 per cent and unlikely to fall below double digits for at least another couple of years. The government acknowledges in its budget papers the fact that in 12 months time the level of unemployment will be little, if any, different from what it is today.

We have another cataclysmic problem with the abysmal savings performance that this country has been able to put in over recent years, both at the public sector and private sector level. It is a performance that lies fairly and squarely at the feet of this government because of its mismanagement of the economy. We have a household savings ratio of around four per cent, the lowest in our history; public sector borrowings are running at about $20 billion per year; and we have a budget deficit for the Commonwealth alone which, on an accumulated basis, has now totalled $40 billion over the last three years alone. Over that period we have seen an increase in the Commonwealth government's debt to a figure approximating $80 billion, yet only three years ago the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said that Commonwealth government debt would be zero by 1993.

We have a nation that has become increasingly dependent on foreign borrowings to attempt to maintain its sliding living standards. Foreign debt—that is, the extent to which this country is in debt to foreigners—is now over $160 billion in net terms and more than $200 billion in gross terms. That is equivalent to about $50,000 per average Australian family or $12,000 per individual Australian. When this government took office just 10 years ago that net $160 billion figure was about $25 billion. There has been a six to eight fold increase in our debt over that period.

We have an appalling level of investment, which, after having fallen for the past three years to the lowest levels again on record—we have actually eaten into the capital stock of this country; we have seen the capital stock of this country run down over that period—still shows no signs of picking up. As I said, the productive capital base on some estimates is actually eroding.

We do not need any more studies commissioned or white papers prepared to know what our problems are. The national fiscal outlook paper produced at the recent premiers conference, the FitzGerald report on national savings, the forthcoming white paper on unemployment all have, or will, tell us what we already know, which is that these are massive problems; they require creative and visionary solutions and this government's policies have been a complete failure in addressing them.

On election night both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) named jobs as the goal of this government's term. Indeed, on budget night, the Treasurer also mentioned jobs as being the budget's primary objective. What did the budget, with its medium-term strategy, actually achieve? It slugged businesses—the productive job creating sector of the economy—with complex additional taxes which are reflected and contained in the bills being introduced into the Senate tonight.

It more than halved the personal income tax cuts that had been solemnly promised and legislated into, to quote the Prime Minister before the election, `l-a-w'. Personal income tax cuts for lower and middle income households were promised. The government never promised any tax cut for lower income households where the income was less than $20,700 a year. It has now made a completely inadequate, puny attempt to redress that gross inequity in its election policy promises.

As far as the personal income tax cuts that it promised are concerned, the government has pushed two-thirds of them into the never-never. The best the Treasurer can now say is that that major part of the promised tax cuts will occur `probably in 1998'. That is two elections away—five years away. Those tax cuts will never eventuate. The government has obviously abandoned them post haste. They will never be seen again.

By its own forecast, the budget fails to produce or, more appropriately, provide the climate to produce more jobs, investment or savings. It has further increased public sector borrowings to an enormous level. This year, public sector borrowings by the Commonwealth sector alone will exceed $20,000 million. That is a figure which is absolutely and totally inappropriate to the situation that we face as a nation. So on all the criteria to judge it, this budget fails. It is another deceit, a lie, a dishonesty and a breach of trust that this Labor Party and its leader have foisted upon the electorate.

This government seems simply unable, unwilling or unprepared to address the major national problems that it created but never expected to have to fix. The bills that will be introduced into the Senate tonight—there will be much more debate on and examination of them in committee and subsequently in this chamber—simply add to the problems facing our country. They in no way attack in any sustainable, long-term, carefully planned way the problems that we face. They create not one more job. Indeed, they hinder the further development of productive investment and savings, economic production and job creation.

These bills are a disaster of the first order. As the opposition has said many times in recent days, and as 74 per cent of the Australian electorate said in response to a poll that was published in the last 24 hours, there is only one thing that this government ought to be doing about its budget—that is, taking it back to the drawing board and starting again, because there is no way that it could possibly do a worse job than it has done this time. In the interests of all Australians and in the interests of the future of the Australian economy, it is mandatory, in my view, for the government to go back to basics and start again on this budget.
Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (SHIPPING LEVY) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sherry, on behalf of Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Act 1981.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Act 1981 to raise the maximum rate of oil pollution levy which can be applied to commercial shipping using Australian ports.
The levy, which was introduced in 1973, provides funds towards the costs associated with operation of Australia's National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil.

The National Plan brings together Commonwealth, State and Territory and industry expertise and combat capacity under one national contingency plan. Since 1 January 1991, it has been administered by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA).

The levy funds the administration of the National Plan, including equipment acquisition, maintenance and training. It also provides a contingency fund to cover costs incurred in responding to marine pollution incidents.
The Act currently provides that the rate of levy (per quarter) is such rate, not exceeding 4 cents per ton of the tonnage of the ship, as is prescribed.

The rate of levy at present prescribed by Regulation is 2.2 cents per ton. However it is intended that this rate be raised to 4 cents per ton from 1 October 1993. This increase will enable AMSA to implement the recent decisions of Commonwealth and State Transport Ministers aimed at enhancing the effectiveness of the Plan.

These decisions flowed from consideration of a high level review of the National Plan by a Commonwealth/State/Industry Working Party. Additional funds are required to purchase additional response equipment to enhance response capability in the event of major spills and put in place contractual arrangements to enhance fixed wing dispersant delivery capability.

The increase in the prescribed rate of levy to meet these additional funding demands will, however, remove the leeway that has previously existed between the rate of levy prescribed by regulation and the limit on the levy set by the Act.

This leeway is essential to allow AMSA to react speedily to a large funding requirement that might arise in the case of a major incident. While in almost all cases costs of responding to oil pollution incidents are recovered from the polluter, there is an immediate call on funds, and it may be some time before these can be recovered.
In such cases the ability to increase the levy by regulation will allow AMSA to borrow funds at short notice by giving it the financial capacity to service and repay such a loan from the levy.

The increase in the maximum rate of levy that can be prescribed to 6 cents per ton as proposed in this legislation maintains the current relationship between the rate of levy prescribed by regulation and the maximum rate capable of being prescribed.

Mr President, the Government hopes of course that we will never need to raise the rate of levy to pay for the clean up of a major spill. The Government believes, however, that it is essential for AMSA to have the capability to respond quickly should such an unfortunate event occur.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
