SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to the decision announced in the Budget to change the safety net arrangements applying to general patients under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
The PBS, which for more than 40 years has been providing the Australian community with access to necessary medicines, enjoys international recognition for its success.
A number of adjustments are being made to the PBS through the 1993-94 Budget to further improve its cost effectiveness and operating efficiency.

The PBS safety net, which was introduced in 1986 to help people who need a lot of medicines, will remain available. There will be no changes to the safety net arrangements for pensioners and other concessional beneficiaries. Changes are being made, however, to general patients' entitlements under the scheme.
In 1992 the use of medicines under the free safety net for general patients increased by more than 150 per cent over the previous year.

With an ageing population and the development of new drugs, the costs of operating the PBS are increasing every year. In 1992-93, for instance, costs increased by 25 per cent over the previous financial year to around $1.5 billion. This cost must eventually be borne by the taxpayer.

As well, there has been a growing tendency for people to stockpile medicines. In 1992 more than 70 per cent of the annual number of prescriptions for general patients were supplied in the last two months of the safety net period.
This bill introduces a number of changes to address these issues.

The safety net scheme has been simplified for general patients by eliminating the second (free) limit and increasing the first (concessional) limit to $400 per year (indexed). Once a general patient and members of his or her family have this amount recorded on their Prescription Record Form, pharmaceutical benefits will be available at the concessional rate of $2.60 (indexed) for the remainder of that calendar year.

This replaces a more complex two-step safety net system under which a general patient qualified for concessional benefits after spending $312.30 on pharmaceutical benefits in a calendar year and then for free benefits after spending a further $52.00 in that year.
This change is expected to reduce outlays by $12.4 million in 1993-94, $32.0 million in 1994-95, $33-4 million in 1995-96 and $34.9 million in 1996-97.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Bounty Ships Act 1989 to extend the shipbuilding bounty from 30 June 1995 until 30 June 1997. The bill implements a government election commitment to phase down the bounty in line with general manufacturing tariffs. The new rates listed in the bill are between 10 per cent phasing down to five per cent in 1997 compared to the old ones, which would now be on a five per cent rate ending in 1997. The coalition will not be opposing this bill. It is a bill for which the government announced its proposals before the election. Apart from that, we do not have a problem with it.

PARA.TAB: The coalition does have some concerns about the bill. Our major concern is, as with so many other industry assistance measures, as to the approach taken by the Labor Government to these matters. The latest buzz phrase `world's best practice' is a very important term, despite the jargon, and really means something that is fundamental to the future well-being of our economy. The government's approach to this need for world's best practice, the need for Australia to be internationally competitive in our manufacturing and indeed in all other sectors of productive activity, is: `Not yet, not ready, not able and not willing'.

This defeatist approach is self-evident from the government's failure to achieve the necessary micro and macro-economic reforms that are so essential for us to compete with the world's best. If one listens to the rhetoric of the government one would be fairly impressed. It talks tough but acts weak, if at all. It is a bit like the budget that we have seen over the past couple of weeks. There is a bit more spending, a bit more tax, a bit more debt, no strategy, and no vision. The government's attitude is, `Let us deal with the problem as it comes along and try to patch it up'. As a result we have had a massive unravelling of the budget and it is typical of the government's approach to economic policy, including industry policy.

Labor has not taken the steps that are necessary if we are going to see manufacturing industry in this country, be it shipbuilding or any other form of manufacturing activity, achieve the international competitiveness that the nation so desperately requires. Unless we are prepared to take the necessary decisions and actions, and not just utter fine words, to actually lower our costs, not only in absolute terms but also relative to the rest of the world, then we will never increase our international competitiveness and therefore our ability to sell around the world. That involves taking many significant actions.

Labor, for example, has failed totally on industrial relations—productivity agreements are limited and only introduced with union fiat. As we have seen over the last couple of days, the government has capitulated in a most appalling and craven manner to the ACTU on the question of the role of unions in enterprise bargaining.

We have a seen a situation in which the government and the Prime Minister have completely reversed the situation that was outlined during the election campaign. The Prime Minister said that non-union members ought to be able to negotiate and participate in enterprise agreements. Bill Kelty, the ACTU and the union movement did not like that too much, so over the past couple of days we have a seen a total capitulation by the government to the ACTU on that issue. Unless we get the necessary flexibility into our wage fixing systems and into the whole question of industrial relations, we will never be able to get the arrangements that will enable us not only to benefit the individual workers involved but also, and equally importantly, to produce the competitive situation which will allow jobs to be created, our economy to grow and our living standards to be increased.

Labor has also failed equally abysmally on tax reform. The government seems to know pretty well how to increase business costs, slug businesses and also families. Under this government's `smother everything' tax policy, tax law has become an administrative and financial nightmare. We had an exercise last year or the year before to simplify sales tax and finished up with a more complicated mess than before. Not only have we seen a failure in the administrative sense, but we have seen massive increases in taxation. We now have the government leaving open the option of introducing a wealth tax and an income tax levy on high income earners when it specifically said before the election that it would not increase taxes or introduce any new taxes.

We have a government that is increasing the tax on one of Australia's most promising export industries, the wine industry, by no less than 55 per cent. That is a staggeringly high increase and it will cause great damage to the wine industry as it attempts to build its way still further into international markets and thereby contribute to Australia desperately needed foreign exchange earnings.

This government in its last budget imposed further savage increases on transport of all descriptions in Australia. The budget through its fuel tax increases has placed added operational costs on railway enterprises throughout Australia. For example, in the case of Australian National Rail alone the increase will be $4 1/4 million. In my own State of Victoria it is will increase rail costs by $2 1/2 million; in New South Wales by around $9 million; and in Western Australia by $2 million. There is no logic at all in increasing the price of everything that has a rail freight component.

So one can go working one's way right through the budget measures and the general policy measures that have been introduced by this government over years as it has worked its way into a situation where it deliberately engineered the greatest recession that Australia has had since the great depression of the 1930s. Australia is still in a deeply recessed state with almost a million Australians officially unemployed, another million Australians underemployed, investment going through the floor and with no prospect of any significant recovery in the economy.

Former finance minister Mr Peter Walsh said in a speech the other night that the government is not addressing Australia's fundamental economic problems. He said that the fundamental economic problems will not be resolved by having debates and conventions about flags and constitutions. Mr Peter Walsh is absolutely right. That seems to be about the only way that this government feels it can go at the moment in terms of policy direction. It is a sure sign that this government has lost the plot. It is directionless and it is drifting. That is a very dangerous situation not only for the government but much more seriously than that, for the Australian nation to find itself confronted with. Labor has failed to create an environment for savings and investment. Without these key interrelated economic variables, Australia's recovery prospects are grim.

Unfortunately, every time the government introduces an industry bill, we have to go over the same issues time and time again. It has been going on for a decade now and still the government does not seem to be able to listen, to act or to understand the essentials underlying the problems that we face and the problems that have become much more deeply ingrained as a result of the government's incompetence.

The reasons for the extension of the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1993 reflect the types of issues I have raised tonight. I urge the government yet again to try to get its act together in terms of a policy for industry which actually reduces costs and which helps industry to become more internationally competitive, more productive and, therefore, able to make the contribution that, with the right environment, it has enormous scope and potential to do on behalf of all of us. If we do not have a viable, dynamic manufacturing industry, then we, as a nation, are very much the poorer. It is about time this government understood that and it is about time this government started to understand the basic challenges facing it and its basic requirements of achieving those objectives on behalf of not only the industries but also, as I said, the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1993. The main purpose of the bill is to implement the government's election commitment announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 24 February 1993 to reduce the shipbuilding bounty at a rate which reflects the reduction in general manufacturing tariffs as set down in the government's Building a Competitive Australia statement on 12 March 1991.

PARA.TAB: In practical terms, this will mean that the phase-down of the bounty rates in the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989 is slowed down from an immediate drop of a full five per cent, which is currently scheduled for 1 July 1993. In its place, a more gradual phase-down rate of one per cent each financial year will apply so that the current 10 per cent rate is reduced to five per cent after 1 July 1996.

The decision to introduce a more gradual reduction in the shipbuilding bounty was made `after consultation between the government and the Australian Shipbuilders' Association'. It is designed to sustain the competitive gains made by the industry. As industry spokesperson for the Australian Democrats, I did not take the government's word for it. I sought to undertake some consultation with the shipbuilding industry. I found that, in general terms, those people with whom we were able to consult certainly agreed that this was a welcome measure for the industry.

I am a little cautious in expressing my view. Invariably, one cannot consult with everyone in the industry and, just like the small winegrowers, it is mainly the family vineyards that would be taking the brunt if the government were successful in introducing the wine tax. So there are bound to be some shipyards and some producers in this industry which may find even this measure a little difficult.

Nevertheless, it is a welcome change for the government to undertake what appears to be a carefully thought out plan for an industry. This stands in contrast to measures such as the proposed wine tax. That measure was simply used as a revenue raising measure, without any thought of its consequences for the economic wellbeing of the industry and the social effects on the people who are employed in it—let alone the future prospects of the industry.

The shipbuilding industry certainly appears to be one of the bright spots on the Australian manufacturing scene. The industry has become a major export earner for Australia and is likely to enjoy strong profitable growth in the next century. Australia currently leads the way in the design and production of high-speed ferries, luxury motor yachts and patrol boats, and is poised to spearhead the ongoing development of the high-speed technology to other applications, such as large size passenger ferries and fast freight vessels.

It would appear that we are looking at an industry that can contribute considerably in the future, both to the export earnings and to the creation of employment opportunities within Australia. It is an example that I would hope the government would see its way clear to follow in other industries and stands in marked contrast, as I said before, to its general policy of following an ideology of removing all tariffs, all bounties and all protection devices in the face of other countries not pursuing this particular path but doing everything they can to assist their industries. I trust that the government will see its way clear to use this example for other industries. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I echo many of the comments made by Senator Spindler. Whilst the Greens will be supporting the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1993, we feel that some of those people within the industry may feel like it is a choice between death by bullet or death by starvation. We agree to the bill because it enables some time for the shipbuilding industry to adjust to the effects of a reduction in the bounty that is currently paid. But it tends to be made necessary by the loss of government revenue caused by tariff reductions and the need to be consistent with the current blind faith in free trade. Neither has been assessed as to its social and economic implications.

PARA.TAB: I ask that, before we go so far that we cannot turn back, there is some attempt to assess the impact of the removal of both tariffs and bounties. Perhaps we should ask some questions. Are we gaining jobs? Are we becoming more efficient? What are the effects on our balance of trade and our balance of payments? This is often used as the reason for which we take these policy actions.

The kind of information that is available in policy performance statements would help us a great deal, should we ever be given the chance to choose with regard to that great level playing field in the sky—the Uruguay Round of GATT. The Greens would suggest that perhaps, as we make great changes to our trade policies that will affect people as we go along, it would only make sense to assess whether they are achieving what they say they are achieving, so that we can make better decisions in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have spoken in support of the legislation. I will not delay the Senate for long. People have been brief in their contributions on the legislation; therefore, it would not be appropriate for me to be lengthy in my response. As at least some senators have indicated in their contributions, this legislation is a reflection of an election announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to extend the shipbuilding bounty in line with the general manufacturing industry tariff; that is, to reduce the rate at which the tariff is phased down. The legislation was introduced in the last session and we are proceeding with it here today with somewhat greater speed than we were until yesterday. I am grateful for that and I promise to say no more on that, as I caused enough trouble about that yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The current legislation, as everybody knows, would have provided for the bounty to be reduced from 10 per cent to five per cent much more quickly. This would have been ahead of the average of the general manufacturing tariff. As a whole, it will reduce to five per cent from 1 July 1996. This is an industry that has been very successful. The legislation reflects the government's belief that Australia's builders in this area deserve at least the same backing from the government that other Australian manufacturers get while they tackle the competitive challenges ahead.

I will not divert to respond to the comments made by Senator Short and, in particular, Senator Spindler. I missed the last of Senator Spindler's comments while I was walking down to the chamber. But we have had these sorts of discussions in the past, and I will not reiterate them. I have to apologise to Senator Margetts. I missed the thrust of her comments. I will have a look at them in the Hansard and follow them up. I cannot respond intelligently because I heard only the last few words. I missed her contribution while I was walking down here.

While in the Senate we have diverse views about issues of tariffs, protection, assistance to industry and industry policy generally, I think we all share in the pleasure that a successful industry with strong export growth such as this provides. This is legislation which will assist the transition process and maximise the possibility of the industry continuing to be successful. I thank the Senate for its support and commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to amend several acts: the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, the Radio Communications Act 1991 and the Telecommunications Act 1991. The amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act will allow Australia Post to operate a national change of address scheme.

PARA.TAB: Section 92 of the act imposes a duty on Australia Post employees and persons performing duties for Australia Post not to disclose, among other things, affairs or personal particulars, including the address, of a person. By amending section 92 of the act, a customer's name and address will be able to be disclosed to other persons, organisations and classes of organisations where a customer consents in writing to the disclosure of the new address on a form available from Australia Post.

This national change of address scheme will mean that, when customers shift address and advise Australia Post of their new address and/or request mail redirection, they can give consent—or not give consent—for their name and address to be disclosed. Obviously, this scheme will be of particular use to businesses and other users of Australia Post sending out large amounts of correspondence. However, the privacy of Australian citizens must be protected.

All disclosures will be recorded by Australia Post and any information obtained through the scheme will be handled in accordance with information privacy principles as set out in the Privacy Act 1988. The coalition is satisfied with the privacy safeguards contained in the amendments to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 and will therefore be supporting them.

Amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 will require suppliers of telecommunications services to consult with law enforcement agencies about new technologies they are intending to introduce and assist agencies in carrying out their law enforcement responsibilities. More specifically, the amendments will impose conditions requiring suppliers of eligible services firstly to consult, in accordance with Austel directions, with Commonwealth, state and territory law enforcement agencies about proposals to use or to develop new technology in their telecommunications activities; and, secondly, to provide Commonwealth, state and territory officers and authorities such help as is reasonably necessary to enforce criminal law and laws imposing pecuniary penalties, to protect the public revenue and to safeguard national security.

As honourable senators would be aware, the new GSM digital mobile telephone technology is currently being introduced in Australia. Telecom was the first to switch on its digital MobileNet service on 27 April. This new technology has many advantages, including the security of the network. As we all know, callers using the 018 network are not assured of the security of their calls. I might add that there have been some celebrated cases of security breaches in the past because people using sophisticated scanners can pick up private telephone conversations.

In contrast, the new digital technology is far more secure. While calls from a digital mobile phone to an ordinary phone and calls which pass through a base station on their way to another digital mobile phone can still be bugged, calls from one digital mobile phone directly to another cannot currently be tapped. This is a feature that will make the digital mobile telephones more attractive than the current 018 service.

Under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, security agencies—including ASIO, the National Crime Authority, the Australian Federal Police and state police—are allowed to tap phone calls in certain circumstances. Concerns have been expressed by these security agencies that the new mobile telephone networks operated by Telecom, Optus and Vodaphone are so secure that existing technology does not allow them to monitor communications. It is interesting to note that the release of GSM digital technology to some Middle Eastern countries has been delayed because of concern that it would be too hard for intelligence agencies to intercept calls made on this network.

However, these problems will be overcome in Australia. The government has announced that over the next two years $25 million will be spent to re-code and re-encrypt the A5 algorithm to enable law enforcement agencies to listen in—where they are authorised, of course. The end result will be a mobile telephone network which is virtually untappable by the general public, unlike the existing 018 service, but which will eventually be able to be tapped by our security agencies.

Obviously, it would have been preferable if this money had been spent prior to the introduction of the digital GSM networks rather than being spent after the fact. The way the government has handled this issue means that criminals and others wishing to avoid officially authorised interceptions of their telephone calls have been handed a two-year loophole in which they can make calls undetected. Nevertheless, the coalition does not believe that the majority of the Australian public, which is not involved in criminal activity, should be denied access to the latest technology because of the government's lack of foresight.

GSM mobile telephones will offer several advantages over the existing 018 service, including clearer voice quality, flexibility of use through access cards, longer battery life and the possibility of extending the service into direct data and facsimile transmissions. I note with some concern, however, that the ability to transmit data via a digital mobile phone will not occur as quickly as might have been implied by the publicity surrounding this new technology. The digital mobile phones on sale in Australia are phase one phones which cannot support data transmission and therefore cannot receive or send faxes or other vital information. I understand that phase two is required for data transfer and this will not be available until at least the middle of next year.

Also next year, I believe users of digital mobile phones will be able to use the roaming features of these phones. Users will be able to take their phones overseas and use them everywhere in Europe and in most of Asia, but not in America or Japan because their networks are based on different technologies. Of course, this feature will not be used by very many people—though perhaps some ministers on overseas trips might find the feature quite useful.

We welcome the amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 because now situations such as this will be avoided in the future. As a senator who is based in a rural area, I have noted with some interest that the new digital network will cover 55 per cent of Australian consumers but only those based in Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, the Gold Coast, Newcastle, Geelong, and Victoria's Mornington Peninsular. The whole of the Northern Territory, including Darwin, is missing out as well as the rest of regional, rural and remote Australia. The O18 network presently covers 84 per cent of Australian consumers, and I hope the digital network will be expanded to achieve at least this level of coverage.

In conclusion, the amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 contained in the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 reflect similar conditions imposed on the licences of the three telecommunications carriers—Optus, Telecom and Vodaphone—and the opposition will not be opposing these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support my colleague on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I know the minister is getting tired and wants to knock off, but I will very briefly address a couple of points that Senator Ferguson did not. The amendments to the Motor Vehicles Standards Act 1989 will correct some minor drafting errors in relation to the term `road vehicles'. Obviously it was just slack or sloppy drafting to merely refer to vehicles as `road vehicles' when we all know that some vehicles are not necessarily road vehicles. There are a few points in relation to penalties but I will not address them now.

PARA.TAB: The Motor Vehicle Standards Act has also been amended to provide for a penalty where conditions to import a non-standard condition are breached. No doubt permits are given to import vehicles that are not standard but are subject to bringing them up to standard. The main reason that these vehicles are not standard is that they are brought in for wrecking. When the sharp dealer gets such a vehicle, he decides to make a quick buck by putting it back on the road.

SPEECH.PARA: Vehicles should be dismantled if the import licence has been issued for that purpose.

PARA.TAB: In addition, vehicles are brought into Australia for transport, subject to modification. Penalties are put into place for the ones that do not make the modifications but which are still used for transport. I could not really see the reason for this provision in relation to licensing because such a vehicle surely would be picked up at inspection. What is the use of having any sort of vehicle, especially one that has been imported and has cost a reasonable amount of money, that will not pass licensing inspection?

At this point, with your indulgence, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will just go back to another subject that was pretty topical at the time. I refer to former Senator Button's $12,000 tariff on imported second-hand Japanese cars. Intense lobbying by Australian motor dealers, especially second-hand motor dealers, convinced Senator Button at the time to bring in this $12,000 tariff on what were mostly imported second-hand Japanese cars. The cars were a maximum of five years old at the time.

I believe that the government might be ruing this move at present because it is driving out of business firms who operate in this field. I know of one firm in Perth which employed 300 employees and which was virtually closed down. The present budget contains measures to increase the price of leaded fuel to try to drive lead-using vehicles off the road, whereas by reducing the importation of vehicles which were a maximum of five years old and which already had unleaded engines, the government has held up the changeover to the use of unleaded fuel.

In Australia at present the average car is 10 years old, which means that the average car that is being driven around Australia is a 1983 model. I find that hard to believe but statistics show that that is right. So we have another four years to go before the average car in Australia is unleaded—based on the 1987 model. If Australia had continued to import those vehicles, the changeover to unleaded fuel would have happened faster. Senator Murphy is shaking his head, but I assure him that those suppositions are correct: the changeover would have occurred much more quickly. Of course, we would have had the cleaner air that the Australian Democrats and the Greens are always talking about, and that is a point worth making.

It appears that in the past couple of weeks the government has talked of taking off the $12,000 tariff on imported second-hand cars. I cannot see why Senator Murphy is shaking his head because it has been said that the government will take off this tariff. The businesses that imported such cars have been wrecked and driven out of business and it will take them a while to crank up. Perhaps the government has seen the folly of its ways, because we would have been in a far better position by now. We would have had cheaper second-hand cars and would have changed over much more quickly to unleaded fuel.

I believe that the sooner the government takes off that tariff the better, so we can get back to some sense and give car dealers—whether new car dealers or second-hand car dealers—a bit of competition so that they can see what the real world is like. We support the bill, and in due course we will see what happens about Japanese second-hand cars.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and their support for the legislation. I want to respond to one substantive point that was made by Senator Panizza. He asked why action needed to be taken in respect of people who import a vehicle for a specified purpose—for example, for a transport purpose or for wrecking—and then use the vehicle for some other non-specified purpose. Senator Panizza questioned whether that would be picked up during the registration procedure.

PARA.TAB: There is no question that in major communities with facilities for vehicle inspections that could well be the case, but there are a host of smaller communities around Australia that do not have that provision. I see Senator Panizza nodding, and I am sure that would be the case in Western Australia. It is certainly the case in the Northern Territory where we do have vehicle inspections, but there are numerous communities where they simply cannot afford those facilities. My experience is that the usual course is that the local police carry out the inspection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the shire mechanic.

—Senator Panizza would know what that involves. In Aboriginal communities where I have worked and lived, my experience is that the police check lights, brakes, indicators, windscreen wipers and so on to ensure that the vehicle is in roadworthy condition. But the police would not be able to carry out a full mechanical inspection in terms of those compliances. For that reason, the government requires this additional provision to take action where those conditions are breached and not picked up in a full registration inspection process.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Murray-Darling Basin Bill 1993 provides for a revised Murray-Darling basin agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The agreement incorporates a salinity and drainage strategy to address the key problems of the River Murray, salinity and water logging, as well as a system of water allocation. Overall, the bill, which replaces the Murray-Darling Basin Act 1987, offers improved management of land, water and environmental resources.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that the Murray-Darling basin covers more than a million square kilometres, virtually all of inland south-eastern Australia or approximately one-seventh of the continent. The annual value of the basin's primary and secondary production is about $10 billion a year with the area producing about half of Australia's agricultural and forestry output. The area also supports 25 per cent of Australia's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and crop land, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigation land. Consequently, we have strong economic, cultural and environmental reasons for looking after this agricultural heartland, not to mention the future of the two million people who live within the basin catchment.

Back in 1914, the first River Murray waters agreement was signed and the River Murray Commission established. It divided and regulated the river flow between the three states, a move important to South Australia at the bottom end of the river system. In 1987, the River Murray waters agreement, which established a ministerial council and the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, was signed by New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Commonwealth. Complementary legislation was passed by the states.

The ministerial council was set up to provide effective planning and management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of water, land and environmental resources of the basin. The Murray-Darling Basin Commission was set up to assume regulatory responsibilities and act as an advisory body to the ministerial council.

The Murray-Darling strategy aims to reduce average salinity levels in the Murray River by 20 per cent as well as drain and dispose of waste water on some 500,000 hectares of land affected by water logging and salinisation. I draw senators' attention to the 1992 annual report of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission and, in particular, to statistics on dry land salinity. According to the report, at least 200,000 hectares are grossly affected by dry land salinity while one million hectares are at risk.

Since 1988, more than $74 million has been spent by governments on salt interception schemes and on joint government-community drainage and salinity management plans. Perhaps the most significant change to the Murray-Darling basin agreement is the inclusion of a salinity and drainage strategy. This has been achieved by intergovernmental cooperation, a process which now warrants legislative backing.

The amended agreement also provides for water allocation through a system of continuous water accounting. This will allow New South Wales and Victoria to draw on their annual water allocation according to need. Unused allocations will be carried forward as credits and, similarly, above allocation drawings will be carried forward as debits against future entitlements. The bill also gives the commission more financial flexibility by allowing the commission, with council approval, to carry over limited funds from one year to the next.

The legislation empowers the ministerial council to modify the agreement through the approval of additional schedules to incorporate new strategies. I understand that following the successful passage of this bill, the first schedule brought forward for approval will be one authorising the addition of Queensland. There is also provision for the commission to have an independent president. The Commonwealth appoints two commissioners and two deputy commissioners, as do participating states.

I am pleased that this new agreement between the states and the Commonwealth allows the commission to take into account matters other than the quantity of water for farm irrigation. My colleague in the other place, the shadow minister for primary industry, John Anderson, recently called on the commission to allocate water for environmental purposes such as the regular watering of Murray River red gums.

While environmentally conscious farmers are keen to undertake water and soil conservation works on their farms, many are hampered by the current economic circumstances and lack of resources. However, the existence of blue-green algae is a clear warning that Australian river systems are in trouble and we therefore have an obligation to develop ways of avoiding or dealing with such problems in the future. The federal opposition supports this bill and I join with my colleagues in commending the work of all those involved in the management of the Murray-Darling basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the Murray-Darling Basin Bill 1993. We believe it will enhance the sustainable management of the Murray-Darling basin. I do not wish to spend a lot of time discussing the problems faced by the Murray-Darling basin. We all know what they are: acute salinity, drainage problems due to the clearance of hundreds of thousands of hectares of native bush throughout the basin, the overuse of water for irrigation purposes, poor water quality due to agricultural run-off and inadequate sewerage facilities along the river, blue-green algae problems, severe and long-term waterlogging, and so on.

PARA.TAB: This bill does appear to address the central problem of water use and water quality in the Murray-Darling basin. It gives effect to the salinity and drainage strategy which is incorporated in the revised agreement. That agreement sets up a system of water entitlements. But here, with the whole management of the area, we see a problem.

Under the system, water users are allowed to build up water credits or debits. In a wet year the total number of credits may not be consumed and the irrigator would then be allowed to carry over the credits to the following year. In a dry season, irrigators may overuse this water entitlement. A debit would then be carried forward into the successive year. This raises the possibility that water credits could be stored up and used in a dry season, causing damage to the river's health. However, I have been told that water credits relate to the water held in the weirs, not to the water level of the river itself. The commission is set to a minimum water level for each weir. Irrigators in New South Wales and Victoria would then be allowed to use their water allocations in a dry year but within the minimum level required in a weir.

I now come to my main criticism of the revised agreement and, therefore, of this bill: it fails to deal with the guaranteed minimum environmental flow. The agreement sets out a system for the allocation of guaranteed minimum flows for irrigation users, but it does not set out a system for a guaranteed flow for the river itself. The allocation of a minimum flow to maintain the river's health lies at the very heart of the sustainable resource use in the Murray-Darling basin.

The revised agreement is still very anthropocentric. We really need to look first at what is necessary for the Murray-Darling to regain its health and integrity. Once that has been established, we can then look at what is left over for irrigation and other uses. But we are still doing it the other way around. Under the system established in this bill, the river still comes last. The question of environmental flow and the river's integrity is admittedly a very thorny one.

The problem is that originally—before all the dams, weirs, locks and water diversions were constructed—the river's flow was extremely erratic. During a dry season, the river in some areas would stop flowing altogether. The river would become a series of disconnected waterholes. These were highly saline and contained a concentrated density of freshwater species. When the rains came, the flowing river would return and the highly saline waterholes would be flushed through with fresh water. The species in the river system adapted to this highly variable environment.

The river today is radically different. It is a network of interconnected lakes characterised by predictable water flows. The rhythms of flood and drought have been lost. This loss is irreversible. So, when we talk about maintaining or regaining the integrity of the river or about protecting the river's health, we are really talking about an increased flow for the river, rather than resurrecting the river's natural rhythms.

However, an increased flow for the river is extremely important. It is shocking to realise that only about one-third of the total volume of the river flows into the sea; about two-thirds is used or stored for human use. When we add to this the problems of salinity and pollution, we can see why the river is in such a sorry state. It is simply not being flushed with clean water. Salinity problems therefore become permanent, rather than a transitory feature of the river.

I considered the idea of moving a second reading amendment to require the Murray-Darling Basin Commission to allocate water entitlements to the river itself; in other words, a guaranteed minimum flow. But an amendment would not have been accepted due to the fact that the legislation implements an agreement signed between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, and because the states have already introduced complementary legislation. I decided not to go ahead with a second reading amendment because I have been informed that the ministerial council is already addressing this issue and there may well be a schedule developed down the track to deal with the matters I have raised.

Another issue I would like to touch on is that of the role of trees in helping to prevent salinity. I was pleased to see in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last year a commitment to the funding of a national corridor of green along the Murray River as well as a number of other clean water initiatives. I was pleased to see that the government had provided further funding for the program in the budget—and it is one of the few commendable things that the government put in the budget.

The role of trees as nature's engineering works is finally being recognised by the Murray-Darling basin ministerial council. Trees have the capacity to lower rising saline watertables and to improve the soil structure along the river. They have many other benefits, such as improving biodiversity and providing shade and shelter to livestock and wind breaks to crops. I hope that the government will continue to fund this program which is so important to the health of the Murray for longer than the four years promised in the statement.

As a Queenslander, I am glad to see that the Queensland government has finally adopted a cooperative approach to the management of the Murray-Darling basin. Given that approximately a quarter of the basin lies in Queensland, including the headwaters of the Darling River, integrated management of the area is simply not achievable without Queensland coming to the party. The premier has now signed a schedule for the accession of Queensland to the agreement. I expect that the Murray-Darling basin ministerial council will speedily approve the schedule once this bill becomes law.

This brings me to the last point I want to make: the bill allows for greater legislative flexibility in dealing with changes to the Murray-Darling basin agreement. The ministerial council from now on will be able to approve schedules to the agreement. I see no problem with this process. The ministerial council is clearly moving towards a more integrated and environmentally responsible approach to the management of the basin. I am happy to say that the Democrats fully support this bill. We have no amendments to propose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Murray-Darling Basin Bill gives effect to a revised Murray-Darling basin agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improvement of the management of the land/water environmental resources of the Murray-Darling system. As of July 1992, the agreement has been operating in principle pending the passage of this particular piece of legislation. So it is good to see that we have the Australian Democrats as well as the government and the opposition all agreeing with this particular bill.

PARA.TAB: The revised agreement incorporates a salinity and drainage strategy which addresses the dual problems of salinity and waterlogging, particularly in the upper Murray reaches. The amended agreement provides for water allocation through a system of continuous water accounting. This will allow New South Wales and Victoria to draw on their annual water allocation according to need. Unused allocations will be allowed to be used as credits. The bill also gives the Murray-Darling Basin Commission more financial flexibility by allowing the commission, with the ministerial council's approval, to carry over limited funds from one year to the next.

Finally, following the successful passage of this bill, the first schedule to be brought forward for approval will be one authorising the assent of Queensland to this agreement. This is significant because all states that are part of this system will now become party to this agreement; for example, Senator Woodley pointed out to us the significance of the Queensland head water system. This is important because this is a vital resource for this country and it is extremely important in terms of its agricultural productive capacity.

The Murray-Darling system covers more than one million square kilometres—virtually all of inland south-eastern Australia and approximately one-seventh of the entire continent. The river system is one of the longest in the world, draining a region 1,450 kilometres long and 1,000 kilometres wide. Three-quarters of New South Wales, my state, is located in the vicinity of the basin, as is well over half of Victoria, 15 per cent of Queensland and seven per cent of South Australia. It also includes the entire Australian Capital Territory. Canberra, interestingly enough, is the largest centre of population of this basin. Altogether, nearly two million people live within the basin's catchment, and a large number of people outside the catchment region are supported by its resources. The annual value of production in this basin in the areas of primary and secondary industry is about $10 billion, which accounts for about 30 to 40 per cent of the total production from Australia's natural resource based industries.

We can see that the basin is of immense importance as an employer and a creator of wealth for the whole of Australia. Half of our crop land is included in this basin. Half of our sheep flock and one-quarter of the beef and dairy cattle are in the basin's region. From these statistics we can see that the basin is critical for the future of Australian agriculture, for the many jobs it creates and for our wealth. It is, therefore, disturbing that in a continent like Australia, which I remind the Senate is the driest continent in the world, this whole area is at considerable risk through the way in which we have managed the land over the last 200 years. We have one of the most fragile soil systems in the world and we have incredible problems with salinity in much of this area.

One projection is that if this is not treated properly this area could become a desert within 90 years. This has happened in other areas of the world. It has happened in the areas around the Nile and in the areas in Iraq around the Tigris and the Euphrates. The Murray-Darling system is no exception. We have to be very careful in our future management of land resources. We really need to work on the ways in which we have damaged the land to date and to introduce a number of corrective strategies. That is why legislation such as this, particularly as it is a cooperative effort between the states and the federal government, is so important. It is the reason why the River Murray waters agreement was originally conceived.

In 1987 this agreement, which established the ministerial council and the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, was signed by New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Commonwealth. Complementary legislation was passed shortly afterwards by the states. Under the agreement the ministerial council was provided with effective planning and management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of water, land and environmental resources in the basin, while the Murray-Darling Basin Commission was to assume regulatory responsibilities and to act as an advisory body to the ministerial council.

The Murray-Darling strategy aims to reduce the average salinity levels in the Murray River by 20 per cent and at the same time to drain and dispose of waste water on some 500,000 hectares of land affected by salination and waterlogging. Since 1988 more than $74 million has been spent jointly by governments on a salt interception scheme and joint government and community based drainage and salinity management plans.

Currently, the new strategies for irrigation management and water quality management are being developed, and water quality is showing definite improvements as a result of this. It is a policy of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council to maintain, and improve where necessary, water quality in the rivers of the Murray-Darling for the benefit of all the people who live along their reaches. This includes agriculture as well as environmental, urban, industrial and recreational uses.

Water management is of vital and increasing importance to the entire nation. National strategies must be adhered to, while regional considerations must not be overlooked. Resource and environmental degradation of the Murray-Darling Basin should be of concern to all Australians. It is in this regard that important educational activities are being conducted by the communication and community unit of the Murray-Darling commission.

I particularly commend those sorts of efforts because it is only by educating our children that we will ensure that the good work that has been done to date will continue in the future and that we will have the right political attitudes that will support the development and improvement of this region. The basin is Australia's most important agricultural resource and its future is vital to the future of our nation. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of points have been raised that I want to respond to. Firstly, the purpose of the Murray-Darling Basin Bill is to give effect to a revised Murray-Darling Basin agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and now, as a result of at least part of the amendments in this bill, Queensland. It is to ensure and improve management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. This agreement builds on the first River Murray waters agreement in 1914, so this legislation itself is building on the original agreement. It is Australia's most important agricultural region and is a major focus of the government's approach to achieving sustainable resource use.

PARA.TAB: The importance of this region has been well outlined by Senator Tierney, Senator Woodley and Senator Tambling. I thank them for their support of this legislation. I want to respond to two matters that Senator Woodley mentioned. The first is algal blooms. I think we are all aware of the extensive outbreaks of blooms along reaches of the Darling River in November of 1991. Following those outbreaks, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission established a special committee to provide direction in developing policy to combat these types of outbreaks.

The draft algal management strategy was approved by the council of government ministers at its 25 June 1993 meeting. That is being distributed for public consultation and will be finalised at the next council meeting, scheduled for November of this year. As a further step towards removing one of the sources of nutrients responsible for the blooms in the basin, Minister Crean announced that he would approach the states to undertake a joint program to upgrade sewage treatment facilities in the key Murray-Darling towns to remove the phosphate, which is a principal cause of the algal blooms. The second matter that Senator Woodley mentioned—and I certainly share his concern—was some of the practices in the allocation of water whereby in a particularly wet year the surplus water can be carried over to the next year, which may be a dry year. That is the theory, but in practice the water may not be there to carry over. There is a need to establish a practice whereby there is a total allocation of waters.

As Senator Woodley pointed out, that criticism is recognised as having validity. The current commission has looked at the issue and commenced at Barmah-Millewa a new water management program to examine ways of counteracting this problem. In this area, 100 gigalitres—I understand that a gigalitre is 10(9) litres, something else I have learnt tonight—of water has been allocated as the total available water in this particular area.

It is not appropriate to put that sort of detail in this legislative package. It is up to the commission to establish the programs within the framework of this legislation. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, I have visited a number of the irrigations within the Murray-Darling—the Riverland, the Murrumbidgee, areas of the Victorian irrigation sectors around Shepparton and Mildura—and have been very impressed by the amount of work that is being carried out.

We should not be complacent, as Senator Tierney warned us. There are some projections that in 90 years this area could be severely affected by desertification if the sorts of steps that are envisaged and outlined in this legislation are not taken as rapidly as possible. I thank the opposition and the Democrats for their support in this matter and commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1993.
Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 abolishes the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and replaces it with the new Australian Pig Industry Council. Apart from setting up a more effective version of the council, the bill also amends the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act and the Meat Research Corporation Act.

PARA.TAB: Over the years the federal government has established a range of advisory councils for primary industries to inquire, review and report on the strategic direction of their industry. Generally these councils have consisted of producers, processors and other interested parties and have been funded entirely by the government. Unlike these councils, the Pig Industry Policy Council was financed solely by pork producers. Regarded by many as ineffective, the council will be replaced by a new body which will report to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, include other sectors of the industry and consequently receive government funding.

My colleagues in the other place have already commended the pork industry as a great Australian rural industry, an industry which directly employs more than 4,300 workers and indirectly creates 7,200 jobs. The industry is also an important consumer of domestic grain. In fact, 1.5 million tonnes of grain are consumed by the Australian pork industry alone. I understand the value at the farm gate is more than $700 million per year. On those figures alone, the pork industry deserves its status as a great rural industry and is yet another example of the way in which the rural sector can create jobs and wealth.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy reviewed the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council in 1991 and recommended that its membership reflect sectors with direct investment in the industry. The review also found insufficient work on export orientation, a need to increase technology and a need to rationalise the processing sector. It reported that if the council were brought under the Primary Industry Council Act it would be better able to consider these matters.

Under this plan, the chairperson will be appointed by the government. There will be three people nominated by the Pork Council of Australia which represents producers, one from the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, one from the National Meat Processors Association, as well as the chairman of each of the Australian Pork Corporation and the Pig Research and Development Corporation. The composition aims to represent those with a direct or indirect interest in the industry.

The legislation also amends the Pig Industry Act 1986 to recognise the Pork Council of Australia as the eligible representative producer body. The federal coalition welcomes the change because the Pork Council of Australia has well represented the pork producers of this nation. The Pork Council superseded the Australian Pork Producers Federation in March this year.

Some honourable senators may be aware of criticism of the voting arrangement for the annual general meeting of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the Meat Research Corporation. Much of the criticism focused on the requirement for a 75 per cent vote to overturn a levy motion put by a corporation. In reality, no levy motion put before an annual general meeting could be overturned. The amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act and the Meat Research Corporation Act will allow a simple majority to pass resolutions at annual meetings or a two-thirds majority for no confidence motions, but will require at least 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register.

I also draw to the attention of honourable senators the amendment relating to the Grain Industry Council to ensure that its member from the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd is from its recently constituted food committee. The federal coalition will not oppose the amendments that were moved in the other place and, for the record, the federal coalition acknowledges the need for review and trusts that these new arrangements are the most efficient for the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. Provisions of this bill are largely non-contentious and the Australian Democrats will be supporting the bill. Other senators have detailed the amendments contained in the bill. I do not propose to take up the Senate's time going over those again. However, I would like to briefly pick up on a comment made by Mr Andrew, the Liberal member for Wakefield, during the House of Representatives debate on this bill on 18 August. Defending the coalition's stance on tariffs he said:

SPEECH.PARA: For those who do not know, let me spell it out: because the nation has no choice, there is no real difference between the attitudes that the ALP and the Coalition take to the difficult and vexed question of protecting Australian industry.

In other words, the policy direction of the government and the coalition is the same. They take us down the same path. I will restrain myself because there is a lot I would like to say on that, but suffice it to say that the Australian Democrats have great problems with the policies of both the government and the coalition.

PARA.TAB: This bill makes changes to the pig and meat industries. Honourable senators will recall that in June of this year, the Canadian government imposed a 25 per cent tariff on Australian beef. At the same time Canada was exporting subsidised pork into this country. The fact that Canada is a member of the Cairns Group, which supposedly promotes more free agricultural trade, shows clearly that other nations are not about to embrace the free market, level playing field with the great fervour and enthusiasm that Australia seems to be. We simply cannot afford to be the world leaders in the reduction of tariffs. We await the day when the government and the coalition agree with the Australian Democrats on this issue and commit themselves to a more enlightened path. In the meantime, we support the bill.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Senator Reid—Mr Acting Deputy President, we agree to the adjournment being negatived to the extent that it will take only two minutes to complete this piece of legislation.
Debate resumed.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and Senator Woodley for their cooperation. I note that Senator Michael Baume did not make his speech and I thank him for that. I thank the Opposition and the Democrats for their support and commend the legislation to the Senate.
