SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch on aspects of the debate arising from Peter Ryan's article on Professor Manning Clark in the latest edition of Quadrant. Honourable senators will be aware that this article has given rise to a heated debate amongst historians, filled the columns of our newspapers, prompted editorials and, of course, led to the inevitable news and current affairs commentary, not to mention talkback radio. I have never met Peter Ryan, although for a number of years I was a regular reader of his column in the Melbourne Saturday Age.
—Until he got dropped for criticising the Prime Minister.

—I thank Senator Baume. I confess to being rather surprised when the Age, without any explanation to its readers, decided to drop his column. I have been told that surveys showed his column had been one of the better read sections of that newspaper. Perhaps the controversies surrounding the Quadrant article will encourage the editors of the Age to restore his column.

PARA.TAB: I met Manning Clark very briefly some years before he died when he was a guest lecturer at Ormond College, University of Melbourne. However, I would certainly not claim to have known him. My late father knew him well at the university, where they played cricket together in the university XI. My father described him as a likeable and warm person.

I do not plan to canvass all the issues which have been raised by Peter Ryan in his article entitled `Manning Clark'. Rather, I wish to comment briefly on some aspects of the debate which impact on the political arena and which illustrate how intellectual debate is conducted in this country.

In many ways, Manning Clark is one of the few remaining icons of the Left in Australia. I have no doubt that Manning Clark's view of Australia has profoundly influenced the Labor Party and, not the least, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). This is not to suggest that the Prime Minister has read Manning Clark's histories; no-one would ever accuse the Prime Minister of reading a book. However, there is no doubt that the members of the chattering classes that surround Mr Keating have absorbed Manning Clark's view and vision of Australia.

I admit to being surprised that so little has been said in defence of Manning Clark by Labor politicians in this parliament, particularly, as Peter Ryan observes, `It was beyond Manning Clark to be disobliging to the Australian Labor Party, especially in his later years'. It is true that Mr Keating's writers recently strung a few cliches together in order to at least mount some defence of Manning Clark. This is what Mr Keating said in defence:

SPEECH.PARA: Manning Clark's great achievement was to imagine Australia—what it was and what it might become—and he did it so well he helped us all to do it. It is not Manning Clark's politics which some conservative Australians object to. His politics were hardly radical. And it's not the way he wrote history—the way is always open to anyone who wants to write it better.
That, of course, is true. Mr Keating continued:
What they fear is imagination.
With an intellectual contribution like that regurgitated by the Prime Minister, the Left truly has problems!

PARA.TAB: As far as I am aware, Lindsay Tanner, the honourable member for Melbourne, is the only Labor senator or member who has sprung to Manning Clark's defence in the parliament. He made a brief speech on the adjournment debate, suggesting that Peter Ryan's criticisms were politically motivated. But I thought he failed to deal with any of the substantive points which Peter Ryan made in his article. As far as I can see, that is all that has been said in this parliament on the great debate.

The Labor Party may have an excuse in that it has been somewhat distracted in recent weeks. However, I suggest that there may be a deeper reason for Labor's silence. It reflects an inability to come to terms with the criticisms which have been made. I do not suggest that this reflects any lack of affection for Manning Clark on the Labor side of politics. However, a substantive defence of Manning Clark would have to recognise that his vision of Australia is not one which engenders national pride, confidence in the Australian character and Australian institutions. By and large, Australia's heroes are not Manning Clark's heroes. Nevertheless, it is true that Manning Clark's influence on the Labor Party continues.

Two of the great issues of the day which the Prime Minister has embraced with great vigour—republicanism and Mabo—reflect a view of history that is consistent with Clark's vision of Australia. The first, republicanism, reflects Manning Clark's supreme distaste for the British and their influence on Australian history and institutions.

I remember being somewhat surprised when I read Manning Clark's article in a special edition of Time which was produced in 1988 to mark the first 200 years of Australian history. The vitriol with which Manning Clark described our British origins seemed, I felt, quite out of place with the occasion and, I suspect, with the feelings of ordinary Australians. In that article in Time, Manning Clark said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the coming of the British was the occasion of three great evils: the violence against the original inhabitants of the country . . . the violence against the first European labour force in Australia, the convicts; and the violence done to the land itself.

This is just one view of our past. I suspect that most Australians have a more balanced view of their history. They recognise, as indeed they should, the continuing tragedy of Aboriginal Australians. Yet they believe that their ancestors laid the foundations for one of the world's most tolerant, democratic and prosperous societies—a society where, truly, Jack is as good as his master.

PARA.TAB: Manning Clark, however, highlights the negatives in Australian history, often at the expense of our great positives. This is sheer manna for the Left, but is it reality and does it reflect the sentiment of ordinary Australians?

The government's attitude to Mabo and Aboriginal policy expresses the need to recompense for the guilt which Clark attributed. The error of the Left is to think in terms of class and race rather than of the needs of individual people. After all, as the founders of our federation said under the one great slogan, we are one people with one destiny.
Indeed, I suspect that Manning Clark in many ways exemplifies the black armband view of Australian history. As Peter Ryan says:

SPEECH.PARA: If our history were really as black as Clark so wickedly paints it, children would just have to face it. But in fact, Australia's fortunes went up and went down; we won some and we lost some; history is simply life writ large. The great depressions of the 1890s and the 1930s were painful times, but for all that we once enjoyed the highest standard of living on the globe, and amazed the rest of the world with our bold political and social progress. Few of the original convicts wanted to go back home, and today people queue up at Australian embassies the world over, seeking to migrate here. The Australian experience of life for ordinary people has not lacked its rough patches, but by the standards of comparison which the real world allows, it has been unrivalled in its spaciousness and freedom. And these are the people whom Clark portrays not merely as losers but destined to be losers.
I do not believe that Manning Clark's history and his view of Australia is able to answer some of the central questions about our society.

PARA.TAB: Why is it that Australia can claim a longer continuous democratic history than virtually all other nations? What is it in our national character that must be nurtured to ensure that this great democratic tradition continues? What is it in our national character which promotes and, at times, inhibits our economic prosperity? As a historian heavily influenced by a Marxist view of the world, Manning Clark has little to offer on this issue. Why is it that the religious, national and racial tensions of the old world have always found it very difficult to find fertile soil in Australia? I believe that one will look in vain at Manning Clark's histories for the answers to these sorts of questions.

There is one other matter on which I wish to comment this evening. One of the most significant statements in Peter Ryan's article highlights the lack of intellectual courage amongst our academics. Peter Ryan suggests that Clark's history was given a free run and was `largely exempt from criticism by many of our most rigorous scholarly minds'. He continues in his article:

SPEECH.PARA: By the time Volume V was published in 1981 this approached the proportions of a professional scandal. Quadrant, for example, asked five of Australia's leading historians to review it and received five more or less identical replies.
Summed up, these replies said:
. . . it's a terrible book but you can't expect me to say that in print. Such a floodtide of general approbation was running that few dared stand against it.
The Australian newspaper summed it up rather well a couple of weeks ago when it said:

Ryan successfully shows that the historians and reviewers of Clark's volumes lacked sufficient intellectual courage to assess his history properly. There was always a small, dwindling number of critics. But, by and large, Clark became an Australian icon and was treated with reverence, not rigour. Ryan has broken the cycle, and it should stay broken. It is time for a new debate on Australian history to begin.
The Age newspaper also welcomed the beginning of the debate on Clark's histories.

PARA.TAB: It is somewhat ironic that the cartoon drawn by the cartoonist Petty in the Age newspaper at the same time reflected a desire of the Left to keep Clark above criticism. In one of the most distasteful cartoons I have seen for a long time, the cartoonist, Petty, suggests that Ryan's article is somewhat similar to the burning of the books by Hitler.

I referred earlier to some of the central features of Australian society which Manning Clark failed to adequately acknowledge or explain. I believe that one of the great strengths of our society has been the suspicion that the typical Australian has for intellectuals. How else did Australia stand out against the tide of socialism which was running so strongly in so many other countries just after the Second World War?
The academics—almost to a man and woman in the universities—embraced this philosophy in the key departments. The Australian people did not listen to them. They turned in a different direction.
I believe that Paul Johnson, in his book entitled Intellectuals, sums up the attitude that Australians often have to those in universities and academia. This is what Paul Johnson says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think I detect today a certain public scepticism when intellectuals stand up to preach to us, a growing tendency among ordinary people to dispute the right of academics, writers and philosophers, eminent though they may be, to tell us how to behave and conduct our affairs . . . A dozen people picked at random on the street are at least as likely to offer sensible views on moral and political matters as a cross-section of the intelligentsia.

Manning Clark's histories have had a profound effect on the Labor Party. For the reasons which Paul Johnson has stated, they have had significantly less effect amongst ordinary Australians. I do not believe that Australians by and large share, nor ever will they, the Manning Clark vision of this country. The Labor Party will forget this at its peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise tonight what I believe to be not simply the scandal of the piggery interests of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in itself but the manner in which much of the media has been terrorised by the Prime Minister out of reporting it. In particular, I want to talk about the standover tactics, harassment of the media, sackings of individual journalists, silencing of critics and attacks on credibility and professional standing of those journalists who have been brave enough to dare to tell the truth about the Prime Minister's piggery interests.

PARA.TAB: I will begin with a matter that many in this chamber would not feel is significant. It is a simple matter of, if you like, a permanent part-time radio journalist in the Hunter Valley who dared to run an article about pollution from the Prime Minister's half-owned piggery at Scone. For the sake of completeness, I should mention that, as a result of my inquiries and for no other reason, the Senate and the people of Australia are at last aware that what Mr Keating described as an interest in a company which had an interest in a piggery was in fact half ownership of a company that owned several piggeries along with a refrigeration company.

Those companies had filed false, misleading, inadequate and massively late returns with the Australian Securities Commission, having the effect of totally misleading those people who, for perhaps business or other reasons, wanted to know what the financial status of the Prime Minister's half-owned companies really were.

It is not simply the media who reported what I was doing that has been subjected to the sort of harassment, attack and personal abuse that is certainly well known in this parliament. The Editor of the Sunday Age found this out when it dared to run an article on this issue. The Sunday Age was then banned, according to the Prime Minister, from his press briefings for a while. That did not last too long because it was the typical arrogant response one would expect that was simply not capable of being continued in the rational light of day.

This has happened not just to the people who have written the facts that I have provided relating to the accounts that are based on the returns filed with the Australian Securities Commission. It has happened to a permanent part-time journalist on the ABC news. On 29 January this year ABC news ran a story on the concerns of Hunter Valley residents about pollution of local water supplies caused by the Prime Minister piggery. The journalist reports:

SPEECH.PARA: Residents near a upper Hunter piggery in which Prime Minister Paul Keating has a half share want him to investigate what they say is dangerously inadequate effluent disposal.
I am not going to identify the journalist. The journalist continues:
. . . the residents say the company is reckless in its disregard for the animals and the damage being caused to local water supplies.

The Parkville Piggery environmental watch group led by Peter Hodges says raw effluent from the facility is threatening water supplies in Scone, Aberdeen and perhaps even Muswellbrook. Mr Hodges says he and the other residents feel deserted by the regulatory authorities which are ignoring the piggery's non-compliance with codes of practice relating the pig industry. He says pigs are being kept on an area of about 50 hectares when the code recommends about one thousand and the animals are restricted to the same paddocks for up to seven months at a time, saturating the soil with waste. Mr Hodges says the Prime Minister must take some responsibility. Well I think he should listen to the people on the ground yes and not just through reps of his company. . . a damn good look at his piggery.
The result was that the ABC broadcast an apology. It said:
The management of the Parkville Piggery, in which the Prime Minister has an interest—
I love the way it is diminished. Half ownership becomes `an interest', once again because that is the way the Prime Minister chooses to describe half ownership. The apology continues:
has rejected claims, made in ABC news broadcast last Friday, that it was responsible for causing pollution.
The allegations, made by a local residents group, were made without reference to the management of the Piggery.
The report did not contain a response from the Piggery's management, and the ABC accepts their response that the Piggery's operations do not breach codes of practice, relating to water pollution.
Further, enquiries with regulatory authorities reveal no evidence exists to suggest the operation is responsible for causing such pollution.
The ABC apologises to the management of the Piggery for any embarrassment caused by the report.

What a great grovel that is! What are the facts? The fact is that the aforementioned story on the piggery resulted in a threat of legal action against the ABC by Mr Keating's half owned piggery company. I understand the ABC admitted liability for defamation and settled with the claimant for an undisclosed sum. I would like to know how much the piggery company got out of the ABC for a story that was correct. I will demonstrate how correct it was in a minute.

PARA.TAB: There is certain legal opinion that I have seen that suggests that no defamation could be sustained by the claimant at law. No attempt was made by the ABC lawyers to consult the reporter of the story in order to obtain relevant factual and contextual background. One would think that consultation like that would be normal. One would also think that it is especially important that an admission of liability by the ABC would have profound legal implications for the journalists and the ABC itself, irrespective of the ability of the ABC to defend itself with public funds or to make settlements like this.

What are the facts? The environmental impact statement put out by Danpork Australia Pty Ltd—the company that Mr Keating's half-owned company has now joined in a multimillion dollar joint venture—says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current piggery operations impact on the environment in three main areas:
.odour from the pig sheds and waste treatment system;
.accumulation of nitrogen and phosphorus in the soil; and,
.accumulation of nitrate in the groundwater.
The ABC apologised and said, `There is no pollution; how terrible. We grovel and apologise'. The environmental impact statement further states:
These impacts are the result of an operation which was set up under the best advice of the day but has since been superseded.

It then goes on to explain how the wonderful new things that it will do under the great expansion program will fix things up. There is a clear admission of pollution from this piggery at the time an ABC journalist was sacked following a situation where a grovelling apology was run by the ABC. It is clear that improper pressure was imposed on the media and resulted in a withdrawal of a statement that was correct and quite proper and the sacking of a journalist.

PARA.TAB: This leads me to the general question, which I have not dealt with in the past, about pollution and how extraordinary the handling of this whole matter has been. It also interests me that Mr Peter Ryan, who was mentioned earlier, was also suddenly without his job as a columnist on the Age after asking 10 questions of the Prime Minister relating to the piggery. Is it not remarkable the way people who dare question the Prime Minister's piggery end up jobless? There are a couple of other people who have lost their jobs for being brave enough to take on the Prime Minister.

I suppose one should not criticise too strongly the organisations that have dismissed people for all sorts of other reasons. I suppose it is an expensive hobby to attract this kind of legal attack by the Prime Minister. I know that only too well. I have just paid a solicitor's bill for some very good advice on some matters in which the company and Mr Keating have taken action against me, or are saying that they are going to take action against me. But the legal action is not on these specific matters that I am detailing here, so there is no question of sub judice.

It is interesting that the question of the environmental benefits or otherwise of this piggery in the Hunter Valley has not received much of an airing—and I use the word loosely—in this chamber. I understand that the Environmental Protection Authority will be responding to the environmental impact statement put out by the Danpork consortium which wants to massively expand the Parkville Piggery in the Hunter Valley.

As I understand it, Danpork has lodged a development application with the Scone Council to expand the piggery from 2,400 to 10,000 sows and to build a meat processing plant catering for 600,000 pigs a year. At a meeting in Scone only last week, the Mayor of Scone, Councillor Rose, said that there were concerns raised about the capacity of the developers to deliver the water needed for the project; various other environmental effects caused by effluent, which is high in nitrogen, phosphorous and sodium, were raised; and the capacity of the developer to rectify the problems caused some discussion. It is interesting that the Environmental Protection Authority has already said:

SPEECH.PARA: .the proposed site has obvious limitations for a conventional development on the issues of odour and waste management—
one would not know that from listening to the ABC apologise for an issue that it should not have—
but the proponent has stated that it is his intention to implement state of the art technology to address these limitations; and
the environmental management of a 10,000 sow piggery and associated abattoir at the Parkville site will need to be exceptional in order to minimise odour generation.
The issues that the EPA was concerned about were:
.identification of groundwater resources that may be potentially impacted by the proposal;
.determination of the level of protection required for the groundwater resources;
.details of the control measures to achieve the protection of groundwaters; and
.details of carcass disposal, including contingency plans for mass mortalities.
It goes on:

Furthermore, the EPA considers that, if the piggery is to be expanded in a conventional manner, then the emission of odours could not be managed and controlled satisfactorily, and that the consequential impacts on the environment would be unacceptable to the community. In these circumstances the EPA would recommend that development consent be refused on these grounds.
The EPA cannot yet provide an opinion on whether odour emissions, given best available technology, could be managed and controlled satisfactorily.

All this came out before the journalist wrote that there were some environmental problems, and yet the ABC apologised. I will be fascinated to learn what happens when the matter comes before a commission of inquiry in New South Wales on 28 September. I will be interested to see what the Environmental Protection Authority's response is to the latest environmental impact statement. That can be inspected in Scone or in Sydney from 21 September.

PARA.TAB: I have every confidence in this commission of inquiry. I believe it will be a fair and proper commission of inquiry. But I am concerned that there are real problems which have to be resolved. A preliminary report from very reputable consultants engaged by the local residents shows some major problems in the environmental impact statement that Danpork has put out. For example, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply incorrect to describe nitrate concentrations of 24-54 mg/L—
whatever that means—

TALK.START.PARA: —Milligrams a litre.
—I thank Senator Panizza—

SPEECH.PARA: compared with non-detectable background concentrations, as `minor' groundwater contamination. It is serious contamination, amounting to pollution in the case of Bore 8; and

The statement that `the proposed development is likely to allow improvement of the groundwater condition at the site and reduce the likely-hood of off-site contamination migration to Kingdon Ponds' is not justified.

I spoke to these consultants. They say that the environmental problems are major concerns which, in their view, are not adequately dealt with in the environmental impact statement. In another report, the Environmental Protection Authority states:
Given this background and if the proposed development were to proceed the EPA expects that there will be a definite potential for odour complaints.

Remember that this involves a great collection of piggery units extending back towards Scone, which is certainly putting Scone within the eight kilometre safety area which is supposed to apply to major piggeries. Of course, the threat to tourism and so on in the area in that event would be very significant. That is why the EPA places great importance on siting guidelines. It states:
Preliminary estimates by NSW Agriculture indicate that the site would be unable to accommodate the expected nutrient load . . .

The use of contour irrigation on the `high country' does not conform with EPA guidelines on irrigation of wastewaters . . . To be acceptable to the EPA the proponent would have to demonstrate that effluent utilisation by pastures is effective and that the pollution of waters would not result.
The conclusion reads:

The environmental management of a 10,000 sow piggery and associated abattoir at the Parkville site will need to be exceptional in order to minimise odour generation and to prevent land degradation and water pollution resulting from the on-site utilisation of wastes. There is inadequate suitable land to effectively utilise, or environmentally acceptably dispose, abattoir and piggery wastes.

All of this is coming out although the ABC apologises for daring to suggest that there may be some pollution problems. Of course, the locals have been protesting non-stop about this. I certainly do not want to say anything that would discourage any organisation—if it does not do this kind of apparent damage locally to the environment and to other industries—from setting out on a proposal that would advance Australia's capacity to earn export income. That is why I raise for the first time in this chamber the question of the environmental problems generated by this matter.

PARA.TAB: All I want to stress is that, if we have the same sort of standover tactics that have been used against the media in this whole question—the threats of legal action, the actual taking of legal action, the sacking of journalists and so on—then I would hope that none of that sort of thing will interfere in the proper process being undertaken in New South Wales. I hope it will proceed only if the proper concerns of the residents and the requirements of the Environmental Protection Authority are fully met.

This takes me to another matter; that is, the unsatisfactory resolution of the problems I have raised dealing with the breaches of the Corporations Act by this group. Mr Hartnell, the then chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, wrote to me on 26 November last year, assuring me that if any contraventions of the corporations law by the Brown and Hatton group of companies—they are the ones, honourable senators will recall, that are half-owned by Mr Keating—were uncovered by the examination that the Securities Commission was to undertake at my request, the ASC would take appropriate action. Since then I have not been advised of any action whatsoever, if any, that has been taken by the ASC—apart from requesting that they file decent returns at last—over clear and undeniable breaches of corporations law and reporting requirements.

I have received no further correspondence. Apart from a telephone conversation that I instigated with Mr Hartnell's successor, in which I got no indication of any intended action, I have no knowledge of any action on my request of 13 November that the Australian Securities Commission examine the group's breaches of the law that I had outlined in the parliament to that date.

All I officially know, as a result of searches of corporate records, is that the Brown and Hatton group of companies had to make extensive corrections to their false and misleading company returns for the years to June 1990 and 1991. The companies were forced by my actions eventually to submit the audited returns required by law. These showed that there were multi-million dollar understatements of losses and multi-million dollar overstatements of financial strength of the companies as measured by their shareholders' funds.

The auditors reports, which were eventually and reluctantly submitted, revealed that five of the seven of the group's companies could only survive with the support of the Commowealth Bank because they were technically insolvent with liabilities exceeding their assets—a fact concealed in the false returns to the Australian Securities Commission that remained unchallenged by the ASC until I raised these matters in the parliament.

What is the point of having requirements for companies—in this case with assets allegedly totalling $30 million or so—to report when company directors tell lies in them and the owners of the companies have a reckless indifference as to whether or not lies have been told, and appear to do nothing to correct these lies even after they have been outlined in this parliament? There are no sanctions imposed by the regulators on this kind of activity.

When proper company reports are not filed for years after their due date and are falsely claimed to have been presented at annual general meetings allegedly held months previously, and when false and misleading excuses are made by company directors to the Securities Commission for this contemptuous treatment of corporations law, no action is taken. At the same time, thousands of secretaries of small family companies struggling to survive in the recession that we had to have are being fined for failing to file their piddling reports on time.

A letter dated 29 July last year from the Securities Commission to a constituent of mine at Parkville, the location of Mr Keating's half-owned Parkville piggery near Scone in New South Wales, in response to her request for access to Brown and Hatton's 1990 annual return—that is, more than a year after balance date—said that the Securities Commission had written to the company demanding that it resubmit its grossly inadequate 1990 annual return. This letter in July 1992 went on to say that any 1991 returns—that is not 1990 returns which they had not filed properly, but 1991—not lodged by August would receive penalty notices, and if no response then either legal action or deregistration would follow.

SPEECH.PARA: A correct 1990 annual return was not lodged for this group until December 1992.

PARA.TAB: What I want to know is: did a penalty go out to the group? If not, why not? There were clear breaches and a compliance program was allegedly under way involving penalties, but nothing apparently happened to this group. Was it because of a ludicrous and deceptive letter written to the Securities Commission on 21 December 1992 by Mr Constantinidis, who signed it as Director of Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd and who is Mr Keating's 50 per cent partner in the group? This letter pretends that the uncontested breaches of the law—that is, failures to lodge audited returns as required; ridiculously late returns; inadequate returns and false returns—were because:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . accounts previously lodged by the company with the Commission for the years 1990 and 1991 were prepared and signed by the former directors and then principals of the company, before their resignation in August 1991. The present directors did not enquire further into those accounts until questioned by the Commission on them. It now appears that the former principal directors misunderstood some accounting principles of consolidation which, with some minor typographical errors, led to inaccuracies in the accounts previously lodged.

The writer became a principal shareholder of the company after the accounts were settled by the former principals. Once the company was notified by the Commission of these inaccuracies steps were immediately taken to rectify them. In this regard the company lodged draft audited accounts with the Commission recently. These accounts were lodged as a sign of good faith by the company to the Commission.

They happen to be false, and when audited accounts came out later they were shown to be false. Nonetheless, that is their indication of good faith. The letter pretends a whole series of things because the writer of the letter, Mr Constantinidis, is shown in the annual return for 1990 as a director and he was also the only ordinary shareholder, the only shareholder with full powers. The other shareholders, described as the previous principals, only had redeemable preference shares at that point.

PARA.TAB: The unaudited 1990 annual return and accounts are not signed by anyone, but Mr Constantinidis himself did sign the lodgment sheet. He also signed the original proprietary company return, which was totally inadequate and did not meet the law. Mr Constantinidis has signed these returns that he says were inadequate because the previous owners did not understand. Is he saying that he did not tell himself that he did not know he had not filled in the forms properly, even though he was a qualified accountant and had previously been manager at the major accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick in Sydney?

Mr Constantinidis falsely claims that he became a principal shareholder after the accounts for 1990 and 1991 were settled by the former principal, but he was the only ordinary shareholder with full entitlements and he signed the forms covering these accounts. Mr Constantinidis signed the 1991 accounts and is listed as a director—accounts he now says were wrong because the former directors did not understand. Some of the false returns were filed as late as December 1992, just a few days before he sent this letter to the Australian Securities Commission.

The letter is a travesty. I cannot understand how it could be accepted by the Securities Commission as enough to justify not proceeding against this group for clear and blatant breaches of the corporations law, particularly breaches involving massive overstatements of its assets and multi-million dollar understatements of the losses of various members of the group. The so-called apology—if one can call it an apology—that Mr Constantinidis has made to the Australian Securities Commission is, in effect, an insulting gesture. What astounds me is that it has been accepted.

I am concerned that I have not heard from the Securities Commission about these enormous breaches of the act that have taken place. I suppose some members of the government will say, `That is because these breaches happen every day and, in any event, you can't say it was because the Prime Minister was involved because he has taken no interest'. In fact, the Prime Minister had in fact a massive indifference to the question of whether or not these returns were proper. No action was taken in correcting these things until the ASC itself approached the companies as a result of my request. The group has basically admitted in this letter that it was only after the ASC approached the group that it set out to fix these things up.

I have had many discussions with leading accountants in this country who tell me that the accounts are an absolute disgrace. It is incredible that the Securities Commission has not taken positive action against people who simply breached the law in a disgraceful and clearly unacceptable way. Unfortunately, I will be away on parliamentary duty and will not be able to attend the meeting in the Hunter Valley or examine the matter when it comes up in September. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight to explain some of the effects on my state of the cost increases arising from the budget, particularly the fuel excise. Of course, Tasmania is an island state and the freight component is particularly significant. Therefore, any increment to the government freight charges has a significant impact on costs and prices in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: In the past few weeks the comment about the budget has really been quite negative. It was a budget that lacked vision, ducked all the hard decisions on spending cuts and tax reform, and it is definitely not about creating too many jobs, or indeed reducing the budget deficit—despite its misleading title in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill.

My own state of Tasmania has been severely affected by this budget in many ways. First, I wish this chamber to take note of the increase in the fuel excise tax, both in petrol and diesel fuel, and the impact of the increase in the wholesale sales tax on Tasmanian industry costs.

Tasmania is an island state with a small market and an economy reliant on exports. At the end of the day, our ultimate success depends very much on the effectiveness and efficiency of our island's and our nation's transport systems. This government has increased the everyday running costs of our transport system by increasing the basic cost of fuel, tyres, spares and rigs, which will all go up as a result of the increase in the sales tax.

This afternoon my colleague Senator Boswell mentioned that throughout Australia the transport industry will have to cover a 5c per litre diesel excise and a two per cent wholesale sales tax increase. This means that ordinary Tasmanians—in fact, all Australians—will have to pay at least an extra $2 to $3 for the average trolley of groceries going through the check-outs each week. Why will this occur?

The National Transport Federation has estimated that it will cost an extra five per cent to transport a raw product, such as fruit, vegetables or other grocery-type products, to the manufacturer. Then it will cost a further five per cent to transport the manufactured product from the manufacturer to the wholesaler, and possibly a further five per cent from the wholesaler to the retailer. That is quite a significant increase in terms of the transport component on the everyday items in the grocery basket. It is interesting to note that the government feels that there will be only a 0.5 per cent inflationary effect from this price increase. This may be the effect across the board, but the government seems to have forgotten the effect industry by industry or even state by state—particularly the effect on the more remote states.

Tasmania already suffers from lower earnings on average than the rest of Australia. It has the highest unemployment rate, as well as some of the highest grocery prices in Australia. This government is now asking the average Tasmanian family to pay another couple of dollars per week just to put food on the table. Tasmanians will be more adversely affected than perhaps most other Australians.

Because Tasmania is an island state, it is also an importer of many of the goods it needs. There will be an increase of tens of thousands of dollars for every ship berthing in Tasmania arising from fuel increases alone. The goods carried in these ships will have to bear these costs, and these costs will naturally be passed on to Tasmanian consumers.

Tasmanians use around 265 million litres of diesel each year. The immediate grab from the proposed budget is estimated to be $7.7 million this financial year, rising to something like $13.2 million once the increase has fully passed through the system. But it will not stop there because the state tax is based on the retail price which includes the federal tax. The state tax of 6.2 per cent per litre will also increase.

Tasmania is a small, compact island, easy to traverse and covered with fine roads and highways. As my Tasmanian colleague Independent Senator Harradine has noted, we should have the cheapest road and shipping costs in the world. However, this government seems intent on creating a situation where state taxes on fuel are piled upon federal taxes and our hapless exporters then have to recover those taxes from overseas markets. The extra taxation on business inputs should not occur. I remind the Senate that the Fightback GST proposal took off all of these costs.

Another one of my colleagues from the other House has estimated that the average Tasmanian family of four may have to find an extra $1,360 a year due solely to this budget. So not only are the families and the low income earners the losers in this budget because of the increases in fuel and the wholesale sales tax, but also rural Tasmania will be affected. The increase in fuel, both leaded and unleaded, and diesel will impact on our rural community. On the one hand, the government urges the rural community to become efficient and then, on the other hand, it deliberately increases one of the rural sector's major costs.

The job market in Tasmania, already devastated by this government's induced recession, will be further affected by the budget. The so-called budget to create jobs will cause Tasmanians to lose their jobs. One example that springs to mind is the Savage River iron ore mine. This north-west mine faces closure at an earlier date than originally intended, and with it will go 300 jobs and the $24 million spent in the state annually by the mine and its workers. Savage River mines has stated that the full impact of the fuel excise increase in 12 months will bring forward the planned 1997 closure of its open cut mine to as early as next year. This will cause an underground expansion which may have prolonged the mine for another 10 years to be abandoned.

Promising and flourishing businesses have also been hit. Tasmania has seen the development of a burgeoning wine industry over the past 10 years. Many small Tasmanian winemakers fear for their viability as many have just commenced and this 55 per cent hike in sales tax could affect their sales.

I note the comments by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) today to a journalist about an excise on wine. I suggest that this would be a very dangerous path to tread because, although he might be given an opportunity to raise an excise without legislation for perhaps up to 12 months, within that 12-month period it would be assumed that legislation would be brought down. Given the composition of this house, there is no certainty that that would pass. The consequence would be that the government would have to refund such moneys. So it would be brinkmanship and folly for the Treasurer to pursue the line that he was canvassing with a number of journalists today.
As it is late, I do not wish to take up any more time of the Senate. The coalition has vowed to oppose key elements of the federal budget in both houses of parliament.

In conclusion, I wish to draw this chamber's attention to the fuel tax. Before the election, the coalition promised to lower fuel taxes; but the government has raised them in this budget. Tasmanian senators, for the benefit of Tasmania, will oppose the fuel tax. Senator Harradine, the Independent from Tasmania, has stated publicly that he will oppose the fuel tax. On the other hand, the Tasmanian Democrat, Senator Bell, has been strangely quiet on this issue. So will the Tasmanian family face extra costs in all facets of everyday living because one Tasmanian senator will not oppose the fuel tax? Put simply, the imposition of the fuel tax on Tasmanians will come down to whether or not Senator Bell is concerned about the effect of this budget on Tasmania. I look forward to seeing how he votes on this issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in question time I missed an opportunity to bring to the attention of the Senate comments made by Senator Richardson, the Australian Labor Party's eminence grise and senior powerbroker. In the recent ABC docudrama Labor in Power there is a scene which the ABC has chosen to run many times since it was first screened. It shows Senator Richardson saying, `Keating now has more power than Hawke ever dreamed of'. Given the events of the past two weeks, unprecedented in the history of government in this country, I doubt that Bob Hawke would ever have wished for such power.

PARA.TAB: Let us examine the magnitude of the power of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He produces a budget that does not even make it past his own backbench; his own faction disowns it. The ACTU's Martin Ferguson is quoted as saying, only hours after the budget's delivery, `How can you defend the indefensible?'. Even the husband of a new Labor backbencher, himself a powerful Labor and union figure, Michael Easson, is quoted as saying, `It's an act of bastardry'. He originally applied that comment to retrospective full taxation of lump sum and long service leave payments, but he was happy to have the media extend it over the whole of the budget.

We had the rather desperate situation of the few remaining true believers peddling, a little unconvincingly, the `good news' budget story. That is what they were saying back in their electorates. They must have felt like the proverbial pork seller in the synagogue. They came back to Canberra and told their leader what they thought—and, by all accounts, it was a ripper of a telling. Chapter and verse, the Prime Minister and the cabinet got the message. In the face of this, we have Senator Richardson saying that the leadership and the cabinet have been given a sharp jolt and that he was confident they would consult more as a result.

I ask honourable senators: will this expanded consultation process include listening to the concerns of the small winegrowers who, with the imposition of an increased sales tax, will be forced out of business? Will this expanded consultation process include listening to the concerns of woolgrowers who have demonstrated unambiguously that they cannot afford any increase in government taxes or levies by leaving the industry? Will this expanded consultation process include listening to the concerns of the leaded petrol users and the diesel users in rural areas who will not only have to pay the additional levy but in most rural towns will be paying up to 20c a litre more than their city counterparts? I suppose the government will consult. It has been told by its ACTU controllers that it must consult. But I wonder whether it will just be consulting more with the ACTU.

For good measure, we have the ACTU throwing in a few cabinet agenda items. But that will not silence the restless back bench and it will not put them back on the boat. The Prime Minister said that he was alone on the deck before the election. That is one thing that has not changed. Captain Courageous will go down with his ship. I think the budget has changed more times in the last week or so than the members of the cabinet have changed their underpants. The Prime Minister is still alone on the deck of the ship and even his own faction has ratted on him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from my colleague Senator Watson, I would like to draw the Senate's attention at this late hour to the Road Transport Federation conference that was held in Hobart on 27 and 28 August at the Sheraton Hotel. That Australian Road Transport Federation meeting is an annual event and I was lucky enough to visit that same conference in Surfers Paradise last year.

PARA.TAB: Before the election, of course, a lot of promises were being made. I was pleased to be there and our leader, Dr Hewson, was there. He had the pleasurable task of telling the delegates what a reduction in fuel excise would mean, not just to them as owner-drivers and operators but also to Australia.

Having been to this particular conference and having talked to the delegates there, I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that they know very well the effect the government's raising of fuel excise will have, not just on their industry but on everybody else in Australia. The difference to the people of Australia between what we were going to do and what the government in fact is doing is something like 26c a litre on leaded fuel. I was most interested to hear Neil O'Keefe MP who was representing the minister, Bob Collins. He tried to defend the indefensible.

There is no doubt that the measures announced in the budget regarding fuel taxes are regressive and will have a huge effect on my state of Tasmania. I noted that at the same conference my Tasmanian colleague Senator Harradine was the guest speaker. He drew attention to the fact that families and low income earners in regional Australia are the losers from this budget. He also went on to say that the disregard for the consequences of the budget's fuel excise measures in Australia as a whole and for regional Australia in particular shows how insulated policy makers are from ordinary Australians.

Senator Harradine also pointed out—this is what I am on about tonight—that Tasmanians will be more adversely affected than most Australians because everything we get has to be freighted into our state and then it has to be moved around the state, in some instances by rail but mostly by road. Tasmanians use something like 265 million litres of diesel fuel a year and the immediate grab from the proposed budget will be $7.7 million in this financial year. That will rise to something like $13.2 million once the increases flow through.

It will not stop there because the state tax is based on the retail price, which includes the federal tax. The state tax of 6.2c per litre will also increase. Tasmanians who still use oil to heat their homes will notice that the heating oil tax increase is nearly 80 per cent, from 5.5c a litre to 8.5c a litre. This adjusted figure that the government is imposing on all Australians will mean that ordinary Australians will have to pay at least an extra $2 to $3 for an average trolley of consumables.

As we all know—you would know particularly, Mr Acting Deputy President, representing the National Party which represents a lot of people out in the bush—everything that moves around this country and that we use has a freight component. What better way to increase the cost of goods than to increase freight cost by increasing the fuel cost?

Not only was Senator Harradine showing concern about this matter; our state Premier, Mr Ray Groom, was also. He made the point that our island state was a small market and an economy reliant on exports. At the end of the day, our ultimate success depends very much on the effectiveness and efficiency of this nation's transport system. He said that Tasmanians will be looking to the Senate to protect their interests.

There is no doubt that Senator Harradine has nailed his colours to the flag and made his points well known. Like my colleague Senator Watson, I call upon Senator Bell to do the same thing. Senator Bell, since being elected, has repeatedly urged Tasmanians to reject party politics in favour of a free thinking, democratic viewpoint. I believe that this is a very good time for him to show the electors of Tasmania just how well his free thinking, democrat viewpoint in fact works. Senator Bell knows that by joining the coalition and the Independents he can ensure that the most regressive budget in this country's history can be overturned. He knows that Tasmanians will be paying more for everything from cleaning aids to ice cream. The fact is that the increase in petrol taxes hits Tasmania more than any other state. I would call upon Senator Bell to reconsider his position on this matter and vote with the coalition to get rid of this impost that is going to affect not just Tasmania but all of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my voice to others that have been raised in opposition to the government's proposed increase in tax on wine in this country. Much has been said in relation to this debate, but nothing has yet been put to this chamber in relation to the Western Australian point of view. I will take just a few brief moments to bring to the Senate's attention the plight of winemakers in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The wine industry in Western Australia is a fledgling industry. In some areas it has been in existence only in the last 10 years. An increase in tax of this sort will be sorely felt by such an industry. That industry is worth some $60 million to Western Australia, and some 15 to 20 per cent of the produce there is exported. That leaves some 80 to 85 per cent subject to domestic consumption and subject to the increase in tax on wine. It therefore makes it very much a victim of this proposal by the government.

I recently met with some winemakers in Western Australia and I can tell honourable senators that they are struggling to make ends meet. They have small vineyards which employ on average some half dozen people, and 80 per cent of them are young people who face the prospect of losing their employment.

Apart from that, the wine industry in Western Australia contributes greatly to tourism and cottage industries in the areas where those vineyards are situated. Should there be any winding back of the wine industry in Western Australia, those areas also will sorely feel the effects.

I ask the government to consider this because, although Western Australia is a small state in population, it is a great state with respect to the percentage contribution it makes to this country by way of national export and gross national product. The wine industry in Western Australia could really be a great industry for the future and could contribute greatly to exports to come. Yet we have small winegrowers who have to pay a levy of $6.10 per tonne of grape they harvest; that is merely for the privilege of growing the grape—and that levy applies to small vignerons who produce less than 5,000 tonnes a year. Those are the people who should not be hit; they are the ones who are the contributors of the future; they are the ones who are still waiting to get a full return on their vines.

I would just remind the Senate that it takes some 15 years for a winegrower to break even. In fact, it takes at least five years to get a vintage from the average vine. We cannot compare the wine industry with the beer or spirits industries. Winegrowers rely on one harvest a year. Such things as a bad season and other market factors can affect them greatly. Brewers can brew beer all the year through, and distillers can distil spirits any day of the year. But the winegrower has only that one harvest a year. He also does not have the economies of scale of the brewer and the distiller. I think it is completely erroneous to compare those industries to the wine industry.

For all those reasons, I oppose the increase in the tax on wine. I implore the government to reconsider this increase and bear in mind the situation as it affects my state—the state of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am well aware of the hour, I will be very brief in what I have to say. I am very pleased that the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, is still here because I am hoping that what I have to say will be music to his ears, in a manner of speaking. I listened with interest to the lunchtime news today and heard that the minister had launched a new trade union choir today here in Canberra.
—I didn't sing in it, though.

—I can understand that. I have had a lifelong love of music having been involved in choirs for some 30 years, particularly in stage musical productions. I guess my thoughts wandered as to what the possibility would be of a choir formed by the trade union movement actually singing in harmony. Perhaps it might give some indication that the trade union movement will be singing a new tune in the future. But, on reflection, perhaps I could offer some suggestions.

PARA.TAB: I would suggest that the choir look to some favourites of the past for inspiration. I think immediately of the line from that old coal mining classic: `Sixteen tonnes and what do you get? Another day older and deeper in debt'. This is exactly what is happening to the Australian economy under this government's regressive, uncaring and, in some ways, anti-business policies.

Having been in this place for some 12 months and having looked across the other side at the Labor Party's front bench, I thought that, if it were looking for a signature tune that this choir might perform for it on some special occasions, that old favourite, He ain't heavy, he's my brother, might be one which would suit it.

I reflected on the negotiations that have been taking place between Bill Kelty from the trade union movement and Mr Brereton, the Minister for Industrial Relations, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I do not know whether or not Bill Kelty can sing. But I bet that if he could, he would immediately have thought of the old Guys and Dolls favourite, Sit down, you're rocking the boat.

Of course, we have heard mention made of the Prime Minister and his involvement in his piggery and whether or not things are turning out as well as they might. I remember, certainly with some affection, the old musical, Fiddler on the Roof, in which at one time I was fortunate enough to play a part. In that musical, the song I had to sing was, If I were a rich man. I think that probably it would be very appropriate if the choir could perform that occasionally at official functions.

I would not want to delay the Senate any longer but, as I said earlier, I have a tremendous interest in choral singing and I certainly hope that this new trade union choir can add some much needed harmony to the labour movement. I for one certainly would wish it very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —At a quarter to 12 I would not normally respond to such speeches, and I will not waste the time of the Senate by responding to the speeches by those who spoke on normal budget matters. They are legitimate contributions, part of the normal give and take of debate, and there is no case for response here. I enjoyed Senator Ferguson's contribution, but I will resist any comment in response.
—I'll take you home again Kathleen.

—No, if we start quoting song titles we could be here a long time. Very briefly, I would say two things about the contributions made by Senator Kemp and Senator Michael Baume. They were sort of mirror images. It seemed to me that Senator Kemp made a genuine attempt to lift the intellectual substance and tone of the debate and Senator Baume made a conscious effort to reduce it.

PARA.TAB: Of course I did not agree with a lot of the things Senator Kemp said, but I thought it was a very thoughtful contribution.
I have a very strongly different view from his about both the role of Professor Manning Clark and his history and its contribution.
I think Professor Manning Clark's contribution will withstand a critique by Senator

SPEECH.PARA: Kemp, but I welcome the fact that he at least made that contribution in a thoughtful way.

PARA.TAB: I sincerely regret the fact that Senator Baume chose as his parting gift to us on his way to New York another tour through the gutters of Australia. All I hope is that he has a wonderful time examining the sewers of New York.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 6 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) In July or August 1993, did Comcare post payment cheques to recipients in Tasmania for costs which had been incurred as early as 1988 and which had previously been paid by Comcare.
(2) In which other States and territories did this overpayment problem occur.
(3) Australia-wide, how many individuals received the cheques for claims which had previously been paid by Comcare.
(4) What was the total value, Australia-wide, of the cheques issued in error by Comcare.
(5) To date, what is the total value of the cheques recovered by Comcare.
(6) What was the total cost of the postage for the cheques issued in error by Comcare.
(7) What steps have been taken by Comcare to recover the cheques issued in error and what is the likely cost of this exercise.
(8) What was the reason for the overpayment of Comcare cheques.
(9) Have steps been instigated to ensure that the problem does not occur again.
(10) Will Comcare make available the findings of any investigation into this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) The overpayments occurred in all States and Territories.
(3) 1226 cheques were incorrectly issued.
(6) Approximately $500. This figure is based on an average postage rate of 40.5c for 1226 cheques.

(7) On discovering the error on 26 July 1993 Comcare Australia took immediate steps to stop payment on the cheques. However, 200 cheques were unable to be stopped and Comcare Australia is proceeding with recovery action.

It is not possible at this stage to state a likely cost for seeking recovery for the 200 cheques which were unable to be stopped. The administrative costs of recovery are not considered likely to be significant as there were no bank charges or other costs for stopping payment on the other cheques.

(8) The overpayments were caused by a one-off programming error with the migration of data during the changeover to Comcare Australia's new workers' compensation computer system `PRACSYS' from Comcare Australia's previous workers' compensation system `COMPENSE'.

(9) The problem occurred through a one-off programming error related to the migration of data from the old system to the new system. The data transfer has been completed and therefore the particular problem can not occur again.
(10) See the answers to Questions (8) and (9). These findings were made by senior Comcare staff within 24 hours of the problem arising.
